abstract: The statistical finding that the lowest SE groups are the most fertile is specifically applied to Belgium. Surveys conducted in 1930 & 1947, based on the occup'al status of the father, are compared, though such variables as the depression & the post-war era cannot be overlooked. The 1930 survey revealed that the farmers had the highest birth rate; other groups, aiming at professional self-improvement, had more limited fam's. By 1947 a general decrease in the birth rate occurred, though the farmers still had the most children. Since 1951, a slight rise in the birth rate has been noted, due in large part to increased econ security. These statistics, however, do not take into account the % of childless fam's. A. Chapman.

title: Het café, verwaarloosd onderwerp van sociologische beschouwing
abstract: The interests which the cafe (CF) (a generic term denoting any public place serving liquor in Holland) holds for the sociol'st is in indirect proportion to the limited studies in existence on this subject. In a leisure-time study conducted in 1955-1956, it was found that the mean/average time spent in CF's was dependent on many factors, such as geographical distribution & religion, & that it was mainly a recreation of the Wc. Historically, the CF provided a neutral atmosphere in which to conduct business affairs, though this is less the case today. Many pol'al org's, as well as crime & prostitution, were also linked with the CF. Diff types of CF's fulfill diff needs. Prolonged interviewing & observation in Haarlem (1961), revealed: (1) the neighborhood CF, catering to the immediate vicinity & generating a friendly atmosphere; (2) 'category' CF's, catering to more limited groups, such as students; & (3) transient CF's. Though today TV presents an enormous threat to the continued welfare of the CF, this instit plays a sufficiently vital role in the life of the average person to warrant additional sociol'al analysis. A. Chapman.

title: S.R. Steinmetz als volkenkundige
abstract: A eulogy delivered on Dec 6, 1962, at the U of Amsterdam, in commemoration of the birth, 100 yrs ago, of S. R. Steinmetz, whose contributions to sociol & anthropol were considerable. (See also SA 0206-B0795). A. Chapman.

title: De jeugd als nieuwe leeftijdsgroep in ontwikkelingslanden
abstract: A description of how age groups change according to the demographic structure & the soc functions attributed to them. The youth group in western countries since WWII has been extended, & is now divided into teenagers, twens & young people (in large org's & pol'al affairs, from 30-40 yrs old). In developing countries youth as an age group originates with the profound changes in the demographic structures, with the dying out of older functions, & the emergence of new ones. This new age group (14-19 yrs), has in general no soc functions to fulfil, & thus constitutes a problem group. No youth policy developed in the West is of any help to set a pattern for a youth policy in developing countries. Perhaps the youth aliiah of Israel is of some value, but should be adapted to the particularities of each nation. AA.
tags: YOUTH, AS NEW SOCIAL PHENOMENON IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES,

title: Het Nederlandse geboortepatroon en de godsdienstfactor gedurende de laatste halve eeuw
abstract: A comment on E. W. Hofstee's statement re the causes of the relatively high birth rate in the Netherlands (See SA 1837-B2107). According to Hofstee, this phenomenon was chiefly caused by the geographical isolation of the southeastern part of the country re Dutch & foreign cultural centers & also by a mentality, in that region resulting from the fact that in the 17th & 18th cent's it didn't belong to any of the 7 states of the Federal Dutch Republic, but was governed directly by the central gov. Van Heek first remarks that the birth level in the Netherlands is still + 15 - 26% higher than in socially comparable WestEuropean countries. Hofstee's above-mentioned theory is rejected because it is not thought possible to separate the influence of the religion & isolation factors in the region mentioned, as non-Catholic municipalities do not exist in the southeastern part of the Netherlands. Considerable diff's are noted in birth & human fertility rates between socially comparable municipalities in the eastern part of the country, where Roman Catholic & non-Roman Catholic municipalities are situated in close proximity. Socially, this eastern region is very isolated from the cultural centers of the western & northern Netherlands. Hofstee is deemed right re locating the beginning & the geographical spread of the decline in the Dutch birth rate, but he has paid little attention to the strong resistance of the Roman Catholic church to this decline, esp in the predominantly Catholic parts of the country. (See SA 1837-B2107, -B2108, & -B2131). Modified AA.
tags: RELIGION, FACTOR & DUTCH BIRTH RATE PATTERN,

title: Het proces der geboortendaling in Nederland 1850-1960. Een antwoord aan Van Heek
abstract: A response to the critical remarks of F. van Heek re Hofstee's study of the process of the decline of the birth rate (DBR) in the Netherlands, in Drift en Koers, (1961, 13-84). In that study it was demonstrated that the DBR shows a remarkable geographical pattern. It starts in the northern & western parts of the country, before 1875; moves in the next 50 yrs gradually, but regularly, to the southeastern parts, so that there the DBR begins only after 1920. It is demonstrated that neither the wellknown theories re the DBR nor the regional diff's in religion can explain this geographical pattern sufficiently. It is hyp'ed that the period in which the DBR starts, & the pattern of the DBR in the various parts of the Netherlands, is related to the period in which the modern pattern of culture was more generally accepted. An essential characteristic of the modern pattern of culture is considered the willingness to accept change. This hypothesis is discussed at length. In his criticism, Van Heek argues that the influence of Roman Catholicism is underestimated, & disputes the hyp. In response, it is pointed out that: (1) Van Heek shifts the problem from the process of the DBE to the level of the BR, so that his arguments are not to the point, (2) Van Heek disregards the statistical material before 1900, so that he cannot get a clear picture of the process as a whole, (3) Van Heek misinterprets the essential elements of the theoretical framework used to explain the geographical pattern mentioned before, (4) Van Heek gives no unknown geographical pattern, & (5) Van Heek presents his statistical data in an unacceptable way. By additional statistical material, it is shown that the country, generally speaking, can be divided in 3 regions; viz, in an early, a middle-late & a late DBR & that in each of these regions Roman Catholics & nonRoman Catholics show essentially the same pattern, even if after about 1910 in most areas (not everywhere) the BR of the Roman Catholics is somewhat higher. This 'Roman Catholic accent' which comes in the western & northern parts of the country, long after the beginning of the DBR, is not yet sufficiently explained. (See SA 1837-B2108, -B2130, & -B2131). AA.

title: Vier wegen naar de analyse van politieke opvattingen
abstract: In the study of pol'al opinions & ideologies 4 things deserve more attention than they have so far received: (1) The nonnormative approach should be separated clearly from the normative, (2) the historical, the sociol'al & the psychol'al approaches should be integrated, (3) the structure, functions & is of pol'al ideologies should be analyzed systematically, & (4) pol'al ideologies should be compared in a systematic way. Many useful concepts & theories for the analysis of pol'al structures & processes are to be found among these 4 steps. This is illustrated by referring to internat'l literature & by discussing 4 books, among which are 3 Dutch publications & POLITICAL IDEOLOGY, by R. E. Lane (1962). AA.

title: De werkbevrediging van lager en middelbaar kaderpersoneel in continudienst. Onderzoek verricht in de Chemische Bedrijven der Staatsmijnen te Limburg
abstract: An investigation of shift-work foremen (N=158) in charge of production teams in 5 chemical plants, attempting to ascertain the r between their opinion-patterns re their jobs & job situations, & a number of criteria according to which the S's had been previously classified. The methodology consisted of rankordering 21 empirically collected job aspects re their urgent need for improvement. The investigation yielded information re the method to be followed in improving the S's job satisfaction, whether this initially was high or low. Statistical analysis of the results revealed a number of r's, some of which are discussed. Esp important were diff's in the total/sum opinionpattern among S's employed under various wage systems (eg, hourly, weekly, or monthly pay), & among S's employed in diff plants. The influence of the immediate job environments on the formation of the S's opinions proved to be rather strong. This enabled the preparation of a survey of all 34 plants, each with its own special opinion-pattern & relevant considerations. The reliability of the method employed was examined in an indirect manner. AA.
tags: WORK, SHIFT, JOB SATISFACTION OF SUPERVISORY PERSONNEL,

title: De gezinsfactor bij het sociaal onderzoek
abstract: One of the main sources of data in soc surveys is the fam. It represents a valuable combination of viewpoints, & takes into account the cultural factor. The interviewer can check verbal behavior against observed behavior. These advantages, however, are counterbalanced by 2 drawbacks: (1) the difficulty of determining who in the fam is best suited to be interviewed, & (2) the various domestic distractions which might interfere with the interview. Though some areas of inquiry are better suited to one member of a fam than another (husband: cars, wife: household expenses), this is not a serious obstruction, since total objectivity cannot be obtained. A more problematic difficulty is the limited possibility of obtaining individual interviews. While various factors such as season & time of visit are to be considered, it is unlikely that one member of the fam can be isolated. If the object of the study is to determine group norms or values, this is not a negative influence. On the other hand, if individual preferences or opinions are sought, they might be hampered by the presence of other fam members. Some corrective measures are recommended: (1) correlating the subject matter to the R, (2) the careful selection of an appropriate interviewing team, adapted to the R; & (3) the choice of subject matter fitted to group discussion. When this is impossible, it is nevertheless useful to observe the effects of outside influences & distractions on the individual. A. Chapman.

title: Nogmaals: het Nederlandse geboortepatroon en de godsdienstfactor gedurende de laatste halve eeuw. Een antwoord op het commentaar van Hofstee
abstract: An amplification of an earlier criticism of E. W. Hofstee's article on Dutch pop growth (See SA 1837-B2107, -B2108, & B2130). The main objection is that Hofstee has overlooked some aspects of the problem under investigation by ignoring the nature, f & intensity of factors responsible for the check on the decline of Dutch birth rates during this cent, esp the soc background of the comparatively strong resistance against the decline of birth rates found among Roman Catholics (RC's). The following aspects of the problem are indicated: (1) The marked diff between RC & non-RC fertility figures does not set in until the 20th cent, when the Church & the RC pol'al party started their strong campaign against the decreasing fertility rates in the Netherlands. Methods included strongly propagating their views on the subject, establishing anti-neo-Malthusian org's, & issuing local by-laws prohibiting the sale of contraceptive articles. (2) The modern dynamic pattern of culture, so valuable to Hofstee,-is characterized by a positive appreciation of soc change. Soc change, however, may remove traditional resistance against any decrease in the fertility rate, as well as originate new forms of such resistance. In the RC provinces of Brabant & Limburg provision of fam allowance was first introduced into Dutch wage-agreements; new org's promoted & protected the large fam; & new means of COMM facilitated contacts between priest & layman. (3) Little or no mention is made of the indicators necessary to register exactly what is meant by the modern dynamic cultural pattern. Consequently, it will be difficult to determine exactly the relation between decreasing fertility rates & this pattern. (4) Hofstee does not mention the most energetic efforts made by the Dutch RC Church to fight neo-Malthusianism & promote the increase & interests of the large fam. Nor does he pay any attention to the soc, cultural & pol'al consequences of the constant rise in the % of RC's in the total/sum Dutch pop figure. This RC share is steadily increasing from 1947-1960;this rise is even greater than from 1930-1947. (See SA 1837-B2107, -B2108, & -B2130). Modified AA.
tags: RELIGION, FACTOR & DUTCH BIRTH RATE PATTERN,

title: Nogmaals: het proces der geboortendaling in Nederland 1850-1960. Een antwoord op het antwoord van Van Heek
abstract: A reply to a critique by F. Van Heek (see SA 1837-B2130) of a study by E. W. Hofstee (See SA 1837-B2107). Hofstee has shifted the emphasis of the problem when dealing with the birth level rather than its actual decline. Exception is taken to Van Heek's assumption that there is a typically Catholic pattern of birth rate. Actually, the Catholic pattern & the non-Catholic pattern are considered quite similar. Rather, other regional factors must be considered, such as the emergence of certain cultural patterns. However, it is agreed with Van Heek that this process is still in progress, & that for the moment no final evaluation can be made. (See SA 1837-B2131). A. Chapman.

title: Rechtsnorm en sociale werkelijkheid
abstract: A sequel to SA A1980, & to the rebuttal appearing in Mens en Maatschappij, 1962, 57, by J. F. Glashra van Loon & E. W. Vercruijsse. An attempt is made to explain once more Wertheim's view of legislation as influencing society by indirect, psychol'al motivation. Most of the scholars who have tried to assess the impact of law on society have not sufficiently succeeded in freeing themselves from a normative, legalistic outlook. Even where recent legal measures are involved, the psychol'al effects on society may be very complicated. Recent agrarian reform in certain parts of India which resulted in large scale eviction of tenants is referred to. The existing soc structure granting a few landowning castes an overwhelming power in Ru society determined this effect of the reform legislation. An attempt is made to assess to what extent Wertheim's opponents were right in stating that the main function of law is to provide a structural frame to society. While this aspect is of importance, Wertheim can not agree with an identification of the legal frame with the structure of society. Such a view wrongly takes the legal frame for soc reality. Society shows many structural elements which are not legally determined. On the other hand, in as far as norms are operative, they can only be so through their mental acceptance in society or in definite layers of it. Legislation may influence human society by mentally imposing certain norms on the members of society & on the admin'ive apparatus. But other structural & hierarchical value systems may also persist within society & provide a kind of counterpoint to the dominant system of norms & values. Only by taking account of these contrapuntal elements within each society can we develop a sense for soc dynamics, including the phenomenon of revolution. (See also SA A1960, 1636-B2923 & -B2925). Modified AA.

title: Sociologie en cybernetica
abstract: Based on the booklet: COMMUNICATIE, KERNPROCES DER SAMENLEVING (Communication, A Central Process of Society) by G. A. M. Vogelaar (Haarlem, 1962), questions are discussed concerning the application of cybernetical tools. It is felt that this application will be fruitful & will have a clarifying effect on sociol. However, whereas Vogelaar stresses the notion of COMM as a tool of sociol'al analysis, the study stresses the general concepts of control theory & gives applications in sociol. Society is seen as a complex totality of a great many 'controllers', all of which have specific 'criterion functions' which try to influence, by means of their 'control action', the behavior of entities in such a way that their criterion function assumes a maximal (or minimal) value. As a result COMM loses its priority & is placed on an equal footing with other notions, all important for the explanation of the functioning of soc 'control mechanism'. Not COMM but the criterion functions of diverse controllers should be the starting point of an analytical study. From these relatively static functions influences result which will move society; control theory provides an adequate language for the analysis of this process. A methodological consequence is that soc dynamics need not be explained re dynamical entities alone; static entities, too can explain changes. Modified AA.

title: Er staat niet wat er staat. Korte repliek aan Glastra van Loon en Vercruijsse
abstract: A brief rejoinder to SA 1636-B2923. Though the interaction between law & community life is ultimately on a psychol'al level, the main area of inquiry for the legal sociol'st remains soc behavior, which is not structureless. E. V. W. Vercruijsse maintains that the principal function of legal norms is the 'differential distribution of scarce 'goods" within a presumably stable society. This concept is too limited in scope & linked to traditional thought. What must interest us is the dynamics of law as a force of soc engineering. When we read between the lines of law we see what is truly written. (See also SA A1980, & 1636-B2924). A. Chapman.

title: De demografische 'taalgrens' in België
abstract: Demographic parameters raise the problem of the character of the pop of which they are characteristic. In Belgium, for instance, the demographic situation is not the same in northern & southern regions. The northern part of Belgium, Flanders, is Dutch-speaking, & the southern part is French-speaking; Brussels can be characterizes as a bilingual area. The demographic situation in Belgium is completely diff in these 3 parts. As a result there is not only a linguistic frontier but also a demographical one. Both frontiers are congruent. In Belgium the distribution of the pop has changed between 1910 & 1960. There is a relative increase in Flanders, a relative decrease in Wallonia. This means that the Dutch-speaking pop is outgrowing the French-speaking one. Demographical statistics are cited in support of this hyp. Modified AA.
tags: DEMOGRAPHY, LANGUAGE FRONTIER IN BELGIUM, THE

title: Notes on the Sociological Study of Language
Taalsociologie?
abstract: A knowledge of the sociol'al aspect of a language community is necessary to understand its language and to be able to translate into its language. Conversely, lexical peculiarities in its historical development provide data concerning the sociol'al development of a community. There are other linguistic features, however, which can be of great soc significance, such as deviations in idiom, & in pronunciation. These can be described only by a trained linguist; the diff's are mostly very subtle. Little systematic work has been done in this field, perhaps because the phenomena are too short-lived & ephemerous to attract the linguist, & he does not always quite know where to 'place' them in the soc scheme. Yet it would be worth-while paying more attention to them, because of their sociol'al & linguistic significance. For among the deviations to today are the rules of tomorrow. Tracing the deviations may eventually give us an insight into the constellation of factors which make a language Into what it is at any one moment. The linguist & the sociol'st have to cooperate. AA.

title: Homo sociologicus. Een kritiek op Dahrendorf
abstract: In R. Dahrendorf's HOMO SOCIOLOGICUS (See SA 6516), which attempts to present a broad conception of sociol, the point of departure is a value-judgment tending to the negative. Dahrendorf cultivates the characteristically German antithesis between `interior' & `exterior'; society compels man to play a variety of roles, which alienate him from his essential being. The `outer' man can always, however, fall back on a private domain which exists independently of society. The problem is that Dahrendorf considers man's freedom outside the sphere of sociol, yet simultaneously claims that freedom is ultimately destroyed by society's interference. This contradiction is the inevitable result of the marriage of sci'fic approaches & value judgments. Dahrendorf sees an incompatibility between mass & individual sociol. Yet, as J. Ortega y Gasset asserts, individuality is the basis of many soc relationships. Man, isolated from his self-created instit's, is like a 'fish out of water.' A. Chapman.

title: De wetenschap der politiek in de Verenigde Staten sinds 1950
abstract: After a sketch of the controversy among US pol'al sci'ts on 'behaviorism', based partly on R. Dahl's article (see SA A8220), an enumeration & brief review of about 60 books, published in the US in or after 1950, re voting, legislative, & judicial behavior, the US pol'al system, local pol, democracy, authoritarianism, the systematization of pol'al sci, & the study of pol'al doctrine, is given. The survey does not cover the fields of comparative pol & internat'l relations. AA.
tags: UNITED STATES, POLITICAL SCIENCE IN, SINCE 1950,

title: Community development in Afghanistan
abstract: Because Afghanistan numbers among the most underdeveloped nations in Asia, it presents a challenge for community development projects. The first 5 yr plan, instituted in 1956, aimed at developing the farming land. The UN provided technical assistance. A Ru Development Dept was created, & a High Council, which makes major decisions. Each project area, with pop's ranging from 30,000-80,000, has its own staff & headquarters. 2 principles are stated: (1) the work must reach the ordinary villager, & (2) it may not be imposed on the people, but must result from native co-operation. However, the self-help principle is more theory than fact. Local workers are trained In a rapidly expanding program which is handicapped by the lack of basic educ in the country. The UN Community Development team, composed of 12 members, is also training personnel, though progress is slow. A concrete approach is utilized, with emphasis on the most pressing needs, such as water purification, plant diseases, educ, & pre-natal care. Problems include: (A) unqualified local personnel, (B) the conflict between local culture & the community development approach, (C) low salaries, (D) bur'cy, & (E) problems of COMM. The UN expert is in an esp difficult position, & is often resented. A. Chapman.

title: De sociale werkelijkheid van rechtsnormen
authors: Glastra van Loon,J. F. G.,   Vercruijsse,E. V. W.
abstract: A reply to SA 1636-B2924. W. F. Wertheim perceives law as an abstraction, affecting society only through psychic means. This concept leads to subjective criteria which are not sociol'ly operable. Required are objective standards rather than a personally experienced psychic phenomenon. Norms should be based on behavior patterns, which are in turn relative. Res in this area is based not on a specific event but on a specific type of event. Even so, sci'fic hyp's can only be tentative. (See also SA A1980, & 1636-B2925). A. Chapman.

title: Het onderwijs in de wetenschap der politiek in de Verenigde Staten
abstract: Observations from a European point of view on the org & method of teaching pol'1 sci (PSC) in US, mentioning the wellestablished position of the PSC dept's, the high degree of specialization within these dept's, the heavy stress on sci'fic methodology, & the absence of fixed requirements re basic educ in the soc sci's (students are admitted for graduate study in PSC who have never taken courses in sociol, while in Amsterdam, the study of PSC includes obligatory courses in sociol, econ's, history, & law.) Comparing the US & the Dutch systems it is concluded that the US student gets far more extensive instruction in PSC proper, & enjoys a large freedom to choose courses corresponding to his tastes & abilities, but on the other hand this freedom of choice, the absence of requirements, & the short duration of the separate courses, prevent US professors from building in each phase of instruction on what their students have learnt in earlier phases of their study. AA.

title: Het buurthuis als mogelijk integratie-kanaal voor de nieuwe wijkbewoner
abstract: A pilot study conducted in Rotterdam, Netherlands, in 1961, proposing some tentative conclusions. The meeting house is considered to be a criterion of: (1) the degree of club membership of newcomers, (2) the degree of soc integration, (3) the degree of familiarity with the meeting house. After an initial period of participant-observation in the meeting house, data was collected, taking into account pop changes (due to births, deaths, moving away, etc). The study was conducted over a period of 3 months. F's were esp questioned, as well as local leaders. All were blue-collar workers. The uncertainty of their jobs implied an irregular mode of existence, poverty being 'denied' by a few expensive acquisitions. Diff's in terminology & Ls presented some problems in COMM. It was found that: (A) there was a high % of club membership, (B) there was some measure of soc integration, (C) there was little or no familiarity with the meeting house. Children had more contact than their parents. While at present the meeting house seems to function only incidentally as a means of integration, it could, in the future, play a more active role. Areas for further res are suggested. A. Chapman.

title: Formele vorming. Kritische kanttekening bij Ten Have's Sociale Agogie
abstract: A critical footnote to T. T. Ten Have's SOCIALE AGOGIE (Social Agogics), (Gronigen, Netherlands: 1962). Ten Hage distinguishes between individual & soc educ'al training, then further categorizes into diff age groups. The difficulty stated is that while neat compartments & categories are formulated, they do not actually deal with substance & content. Included are a rebuttal by Ten Hage, & a final comment by Turksma.

title: Sociodialectologie
abstract: If language is regarded as an important soc medium, linguists are concerned with many problems of a soc & psychol'al nature. Changes of sounds & phonetic systems can be considered & explained in a phonetic & phonemic way. Changes of words & names are nearly always influenced by soc relations in the widest sense. Examples are given of these soc relations & their consequences in diff parts of the Netherlands, to illustrate the theoretical explanation. Motives of some regional movements for the rights of regional languages & dialects in soc life are discussed & character of these movements are described. AA.

title: Stedebouw en publieke controle
abstract: Urbanism aims at creating a physical environment which has a utilitarian, S-cul, & aesthetic function. For practical reasons, the S-cul & aesthetic aspects can be taken together, as the visual aspect. Public administration is able to understand & control the utilitarian aspect, but not, at least not sufficiently, the visual aspect. Quoting K. Mannheim, it is argued that, in a democratic society, all knowledge is supposed to be essentially comprehensible to everyone. Art, however, belongs to a domain of 'connoisseurship', that is not accessible to all. A democratized culture therefore is inclined to devalue this type of knowledge as not communicable & demonstrable, ie, not 'exact'. 2 means are discussed, by which competent public control of the physical planning process might be furthered: (1) To adopt more 'objective' methods in presenting the visual aspects of a plan. According to Mannheim, this may be done by directing the attention of the public & the decision-makers to the visual elements which constitute the whole (articulation). In that way, those elements gain in communicability. (2) Educ in 'connoisseurship', eg, by MM of COMM. AA.

title: Het gezin als object en als factor in enkele onderzoekssectoren. Samenvatting discussies Woudschotendagen V.S.W.0./S1SW0 - 1963
authors: Vereniging van Sociaal-Wetenschappelijke Onderzoekers,   Jolles,H. M. (red.)
abstract: Voor de samenstelling van dit verslag is gebruik gemaakt van de zes in het verslag genoemdeschriftelijke inleidingen, van de verslagen der gevoerde discussies over vier van de zes sub-schema’s(over consumentenonderzoek en bedrijfssociologisch onderzoek waren geen verslagen beschikbaar),en van de samenvatting van Prof. De Moor. De samenstelling en redactie van het verslagwerd verzorgd door H. M. Jolles.

title: Een aantekening naar aanleiding van enige deining rondom het probleem der Haagse stations
Ontwikkeling in de richting van ongodsdienstigheid
abstract: A study conducted in Amsterdam from 1962-1963, to determine to what extent the decline in church membership reflects the degree of religiosity or irreligiosity. F's between 18 & 30 yrs, married, & from 12-29 weeks pregnant for the first time (E= 250) were interviewed 3 times. Characterized as 'religious' were those who were church members, & those who, while not members, professed belief in God. A distinction was drawn between 'active-religious' (those attending church) & 'passivereligious' (those who did not). 'Non-religious' were those who neither belonged to a church nor believed. It was found that: (1) 11.6-26.8% of the parent generation (both parents religious) had not registered their offspring in a church. (2) The % was higher when 1 parent was irreligious. Whether the other parent was active or passive-religious was found to be immaterial. (3) In both parental & present generations, the passive-religious tend to marry irreligious spouses. (4) Irreligiosity is most frequent among the Wc's. It is concluded that a definite deve lopment toward irreligiosity can be detected among the present generation; no counter-acting tendency is evident. A. Chapman.
tags: DEVELOPMENT, IN THE DIRECTION OF IRRELIGIOSITY,

title: Patroon der sentimenten in de arbeidssituatie
abstract: An attempt to discover some pattern in the att's of factory workers to their environment. A 2 level pattern of interest & concern is suggested: (1) re the immediate environment, the dept & working conditions, & (2) the factory as a whole. Between these areas of interest is a zone of relative disinterestedness. This can be explained by the pattern of worker interaction with their dept & with representatives of the factory as a whole. Modified AA.
tags: WORK ENVIRONMENT, PATTERNS IN THE ATTITUDES OF FACTORY WORKERS TO THEIR,

title: Sociologie van de arbeid; een poging tot plaatsbepaling
abstract: A description of the ideological causes of the rise, & the structural conditions of the scope & limits of a sociol of work. Its 'lack of an unique identity', as stated by T. Caplow, is not only a matter of historical development of sci's, but deals with a more interesting problem: the internal structure of elements of sociol'al knowledge re 'work' & 'occup'. The sociol of work is a vertical specialism by its very object, but a horizontal specialism by its comparative approach to this object. It consists of a heterogeneous, inconsistent number of diff sociol'al approaches to some aspects of work. For that reason, efforts to identify the sociol of work with a sociol'al study of the labormarket, job-satisfaction, etc, are invalid from a sci'fic point of view. AA.

title: Studentenbevolking en verschuivingen in de sociale hiërarchie
abstract: A brief statistical survey of the breakdown of the student pop, which has greatly increased in the past 10 yrs, in Holland, re SC. Despite some upward mobility in the soc hierarchy, esp from Lc to Me, the Lc's still have only limited access to higher educ; the increase in student pop was mostly among the Mc's & Uc's. It is hoped that increased 'democratization' of educ will result in more Lc participation. A. Chapman.
tags: STUDENT, POPULATION IN HOLLAND, MOBILITY REGARDING SOCIAL CLASS,

title: Ideologische invloeden bij selectie van parlementsleden in de DDR
abstract: The dominating value system in East Germany, as typified by W. Ulbricht, is Stalinism, ie, soc & pol'al change, achieved by the priority of the Wc's, in turn attained via the Staatsmacht (power of the state). This value system is seen to influence directly the selection of members of parliament, ie, Volkskammer [VK] (the highest org in the Deutsche Demokratische Republik [German Democratic Republic]. The VK is a manipulated rather than manipulating org. Its ideology, ie, that of effecting soc change, is implemented via employment of full-time functionaries, favoring people of proletarian origins. The Wc's attain vertical SM via certain channels, ie, the old-guard Communists & socialists, anti-nazi's, former Russian prisoners of war, etc. Thus the composition of the East German parliament is seen to directly reflect the pol'al ideology. However, it is concluded that future unexpected reactions to effected change might require more complex explanatory models. A. Chapman.
tags: PARLIAMENT, IN EAST GERMANY, SELECTION OF MEMBERS

title: Sociale status van de gymnastiekleraar
abstract: A prestige-hierarchy of 16 Sch branches, taught at HSch's, is presented. The hierarchy was brought about by 4 groups of HSch teachers: (1) exact group; (2) language group; (3) physical teachers group; & (4) others group. A mail questionaire was used. In this way 4 ordinal scales in which the Sch branches according to soc prestige were arranged. The rank r between the scales was high (rs=+ 0.96). The hypothesis that the place of the physical teacher in this hierarchy is low was confirmed (in every scale the 14th place). There is no diff in appreciation for the physical educ between the diff religious groups of the sample. 4 essential causes of the relatively low soc prestige of the physical teacher are given: (A) the Dutchman overvalues the intellectual activities & undervalues the physical activities; (B) though physical educ & sports are important for the mental & physical health of the people, the society asks for brains; (C) physical examination is not a subject of examination; & (D) physical educ is more recreative than creative. Modified AA.
tags: TEACHER, PHYSICAL EDUCATION, SOCIAL STATUS OF THE,

title: Community development and land reform. Preliminary observations on some cases in Latin America
abstract: It is shown that CD projects, which are accompanied by such radical measures as land reform, have a greater chance of success than those which are carried out in a static soc environment. The most difficult obstacle to effective CD has been the peasants' distrust of gov agents, based on past experiences of bad treatment & oppressive measures from the gov to maintain the status quo. Such distrusts tends to disappear when the gov takes such measures as land reform, which indicate that the soc climate is changing in favor of the peasants. A project of the Instituto de Colonizacion Rural (Instit of Ru Colonization) in El Salvador, & the program of the Cornell U in Vicos, Peru are small-scale exp's which support this hyp. Large-scale positive effects on peasants' att's of land reform were observed by R. N. Adams & other scholars in the early 1950's in Guatemala, under the Arbenz regime. Difficulties encountered in largescale land reform programs, ie, in the Laguna region & the Bajio in Mexico, were partly due to not using sufficient CD as a complementary measure. AA.
tags: LATIN AMERICA, COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT & LAND REFORM IN,

title: Landhervorming in een Westsiciliaans Latifondo-dorp. De bestendiging van een feodale structuur
De componist in sociologisch perspectief
abstract: The SS of the composer in diff types of societies & the effects of his role obligations on his artistic production are investigated. The position of the composer working under patronage is contrasted with the contemporary 'free' composer. Using the concept 'soc control', it is shown that a considerable shift in pressure on the composer has taken place; at present, due to the fact that most composers are not integrated in the society & hence do not write their music for a specific occasion, the composer is almost entirely free of soc control. For the contemporary composer, the only 'signif others' are his colleagues. This situation is highly favorable to musical experiments which increase the gap between the composer & the public because the public cannot keep up with a rapid musical development. (See also A1432). AA.
tags: SOCIAL STATUS, OF THE COMPOSER IN DIFFERENT TYPES OF SOCIETIES,

title: Muzieksociologische notities
abstract: The sociol of music must be based on a philosophical understanding of art; S. Langer & M. Dufrenne are cited. It is felt that art is a peculiar 'symbolic system' & hence a means of interpreting our subjective human reality. The adequate perception of music requires that the listener direct his attention to the musical forms that are presented to him, not to what he expects to be 'behind' these tonal structures. 'Popular' music, the greater part of all produced music commands the interest of the sociol of music no less than 'serious' music. The functioning of both types of music in our modern society is discussed by citing the writings of T. W. Adorno. Modified AA.

title: Overwinning van de drempelvrees
abstract: A comment on 2 studies conducted in Holland: (1) 'The Audience Heard', (U of Utrecht, 1962), & (2) 'Public Attitudes to the Opera', (Amsterdam Council of Culture, 1963.) (1) was based on questionaires sent to 509 S's, to determine the nature of concert audiences. 40% was found to be over 50 yrs; 30.2% of those under religious affiliation were important factors. (2) was less voluminous though more ambitious. Out of 350 concert-goers, 33 were selected for exhaustive interviewing having a psychol'al orientation. Various types were delineated, ie, the all-around music lover, the 'culture-inclined,' etc. 2 questions must be answered: (A) how to maintain the present audience, & (B) how to attract new concert-goers. It is felt that neither study (1) or (2) answers these questions adequately, for neither takes into account the occasional, or `selective' concert-goer; both deal only with 'regulars.' It is concluded that the 'threshold fear', determined by S-cul factors, must be analyzed & overcome, esp among the young & the Lc's, if concert attendance is to improve. A. Chapman.

title: Muzikale differentiatie en sociale stratifikatie
abstract: Music is regarded as a part of the cultural value system, inherent to certain SC's. Investigated are the diff's between the SC's re the nature & forms of their musical activities. Insofar as these diff's are due to soc stratification itself, music can be transformed in its reception. Channels of COMM between composer & public can be such that there appears a distortion In the ultimate musical perception by the public. 3 factors contributing to this distortion are distinguished: (1) habits of listening (typology of listeners); (2) motives of the socialized individual (Mainly 'non-musical'); & (3) structural constraint. AA.

title: Persistence and disappearance of aboriginal languages
Radio en televisie als studieveld der sociale wetenschappen
abstract: A list of previous studies in the area of MM, esp re radio & TV, is presented. COMM is defined as the process whereby the communicator sends a message via a particular channel to the communicant. The signal must attract attention, be correctly understood, & satisfy certain needs of the communicant. The very nature of mass COMM implies messages disseminated among a heterogeneous & anonymous public which has limited possibilities for `feedback'. Areas for further res are outlined, ie: (1) the societal framework within which forms of mass COMM are found, ie, added leisure time, (2) the instit'al forms in which COMM occurs, esp the types of radio &TV org, ie, state-run, privately run, or a combination of the 2, (3) the communicator as a programmer, ie, the role of competition, (4) programs re potential of the media, ie, content, (5) audience as consumers ('ratings'), & (6) direct & indirect effects of these forms of COMM on personal & S-cul life. A Chapman.

title: Beroep en kerkgenootschap opnieuw bezien
abstract: Dutch census of 1960 admits cross-tabulation of occup & church-membership. Besides cross-tabulation of church-membership, data on educ'al level (for U training) & income are given. This makes it possible to follow the process of the decline in church membership in the various occup's, the emancipation process of the Roman Catholics & the members of the Neo-Calvinistic Reformed Church (gereformeerden). The former had no full civil rights from the 16th up to the 19th cent & the latter Church, formed in the 19th cent, at first consisted of LMc members. Both were underrepresented in the UMc & Uc, the academic professions included. The emancipation process of the Reformed people is almost complete. The same process seems to have been taking place among the Catholics since 1947. Modified AA.

title: De beleidsproblematiek van een niet-erkende vakorganisatie
abstract: A study of the problems confronting a nonrecognized labor union in a welfare state with full employment, centered upon the OVB, a radical & anti-communist org of Rotterdam dock workers & based upon interviews with a sample of 514 in SepOct 1960. The sample included 123 members of recognized unions & 42 members of the OVB. The latter proved to have more radical opinions, as seen in an analysis of their answers to 6 questions, presented in tables: (1) In a tight labor market, some workers tried to obtain wage increases directly from the employers. Do you approve? (2) Should employers try to lower wages when conditions worsen? (3) How do you judge the share of the workers in the benefits of the welfare state? (4) Are strikes or negotiations more effective in obtaining higher wages? (5) When negotiations are snagged, should workers go on strike? (6) Are unions effective in obtaining higher wages? It is held that 'the instit'ization of class divisions is one of the pillars of the welfare state.' The recognized unions have become a part of the Dutch 'industr establishment'; they make it difficult for outsiders to take any part in labor negotiations. Criticisms of the existing soc order are thus limited & so are the possibilities of large-scale strikes. The unions left out of the quasi-monopolistic structure of the recognized have a useful corrective function, esp when the econ situation worsens & they can act as crystallizing agents of workers' protest. I. Langnas.
tags: WLEFARE, STATE, POLICY PROBLEMS OF A NON RECOGNIZED LABOR UNION IN,

title: De micro-structuur van de bejaarde en een macro-sociale invloed hierop
Sociologisch onderzoek in Polen
abstract: Centers of sociol'al res in Poland include the Instit of Philosophy & Sociol of the Polish Academy of Sci's, the Instit of Sociol'al Res of the Soc Sci's Coll at Warsaw & the Dept of Ru Sociol of the Instit of Agri'al Econ. Res is also conducted by the Center of PO Polls (connected with Polish radio & TV) founded in 1958. Basic techniques & res approaches are described. It is concluded that res is done primarily for its soc value, not for profit. Res reports are used by SP instit's & by the Polish Radio. Modified AA.RECTIFICATIEln het artikel,Sociologisch onderzoek in Polen”, dat in ons vorige nummer verscheen,zijn helaas enkele onjuistheden geslopen, waarvoor wij lezers, auteur en vertaleronze verontschuldigingen bieden.De naam van de schrijfster moet luiden: Anna Pawelcynska.Op p. 29, regel 17 v.o.: ,arbeidsraden”, moet zijn „arbeidersraden”. Pag. 30 regel6 /7 v.b.: „partijaktief” moet zijn „partijkader”, regel 10 v.o.: „Centraal Intituut voorArbeidsveiligheid” moet zijn „Centraal Instituut voor de bescherming van de Arbeid”.

title: Onder de slagschaduw van De Tocqueville
abstract: A comparative critique of (1) SA 0508-A9476, & (2) R. Dahrendorf's DIE ANGEWANDTE AUFKLAERUNG. GESELL - SCHAFT UND SOZIOLOGIE IN AMERIKA (The Applied Enlightenment. Society and Sociology in America) (Piper, Muenchen, 1963). Lipset presents 2 basic themes, ie, 'Amer exceptionalism & the conditions required for a stable democracy, while Dahrendorf offers a kaleidoscopic picture of the US of sociol'ts. Dahren dorf is the more objective of the 2, since his is the perspective of an outside observer while Lipset sees from the inside out. For Lipset, the main point of departure is cultural, ie, 'equality & achievement'. Dahrendorf sees the underlying rationality & pragmatism in US society. Despite diff's in their approaches & objectives, 2 common points are seen: (A) the undeniable influence of A. de Tocqueville's DE LA DEMOCRATIE EN AMERI- QUE (Democracy in America), which strengthens Lipset's thesis of equality & achievement while having in common with Dahrendorf the quality of 'outside observer'; & (B) by virtue of their analysis of fundamental values, not merely instit's, both writers contribute to those values. A. Chapman.

title: De invloed van veranderingen in de landbouw op de samenleving in ontwikkelde en in ontwikkelingsgebieden
abstract: An account of the 1st World Congress of Agri'al Sociol, held simultaneously with the 4th Congress of the European Society for Ru Sociol at Dijon (France) in Aug 1964. The organizer of the congress, M. Cepede of Paris Nat'l Instit of Agronomy, presented the theme of the gathering. Following the scheme of C. Zimmermann, he held that there are at least 3 diff types of Ru society; Ru sociol dealt with their interrelations. The contributions to the congress dealt with 4 special themes. (1) Demographic changes & their influences on soc structures. J. A. Beagle (Michigan) presented his views on the influence of the growth of pop in the US on the patterns of Ru & Ur occup; J. Poirier, J. Pautard & J. W. Lapierre all dealt with Madagascar: the difficulties for patriarchal societies through a relative increase of youth; problems created by the introduction of new techniques & org'al forms; difficulties of individual parcelling of lands traditionally held in common. (2) The influence of agri'al changes on values & aims. F. Petrini (Sweden) noted a falling religiosity accompanying technological improvement; Fukutaki (Japan) contrasted prewar conditions, when the gov was influenced by physiocratic ideas, & the postwar yrs when complete modernization of agriculture became the aim. (3) The functional changes in agri'al societies. Here the issue was whether the polarization Ur/Ru was a static or a dynamic one. H. Williams (Swansea) presented the problem theoretically; R. Stavenhagen (Brazil) outlined the possibilities of studying diff types of 'folk society' by the method of 'comparative statics.' (4) The influence of agri'al changes on pol. H. Mendras (Paris) tried to explain the apparent paradox that agri, as it becomes a relatively less important part of the economy, has an ever larger influence in nat'l & internat'l pol, by the growing politization of the peasants. The final session of the congress was devoted to the role & function of agri'al sociol. It was defined as an applied sci with 3 phases: (a) description of practical problems; (b) sociol'al investigation of the data; (c) practical application of these investigations. G. T. Castillo (Philippines) presented a practical application of this theoretical scheme to problems of an underdeveloped country. I. Langnas.
tags: VALUE, INFLUENCE OF AGRICULTURAL CHANGES ON,

title: Thuisloosheid, een vorm van afwijkend gedrag
abstract: The etiology of homeless men (men without SR in the field of living & working) is studied by several sci's. A review of literature shows the following approaches: (1) psychobiological-the influence of physique & instincts; (2) psychol'al-character, regression etc; (3) psychiatric-deviant behavior is a manifestation of abnormalities in the structure of personality; (4) sociol'al-homelessness has its roots in soc org. Each approach is seen as inadequate by itself. There is a need for an interdisciplinary approach to the interaction of the above factors. These should be investigated by statistical-clinical res on homeless men. AA.

title: De verhouding tussen de sociologie der niet-westerse volken en de sociologie en de culturele antropologie
abstract: This is the text of a speech read on the Academic Day of the Free U on Oct 3, 1964. Before tackling the problems of a sociol of non-Western peoples, it is necessary to clarify the relations between sociol & cultural anthrop. The following diff's between them are pointed out: diff work area & study object; greater emphasis on primitive & `strange' societies in anthrop; sociol prefers to study classes, anthrop fam relationships; greater concern of anthrop with the general, of sociol with the particular; diff's in preferred methods; diff relations with other sci's; the existence of anthrop'al museums. However, the changes which primitive societies are now undergoing indicate a Miff relationship between sociol & cultural anthrop in the future. To study underdeveloped countries, cultural anthrop will have to accept some of the limitations of today's sociol & will have to use more & more the concepts, theories & methods of Western sociol & adapt them to the problems of complex societies. Finally, the nature of non-Western sociol is discussed by commenting on the 3 methods of studying the process of modernization proposed by P. Heintz in a 1961 UN publication, 'Report on the World Social Situation;' a 4th method is added. Heintz distinguishes between: (1) a static method of studying the characteristics of certain types of society; (2) a dynamic method of studying the processes of change; (3) the study of non-Western societies as societies in a state of rapid soc change. To these is added the study of specific problems of development through an analysis of practical experience & the application of sociol'al & anthrop'al theories. Thus, non-Western sociol will produce a greater integration of sociol & cultural anthrop. I. Langnas.
tags: SOCIOLOGY, AND CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY, RELATIONS BETWEEN,

title: J.P.B. de Josselin de Jong (13 maart 1886 - 15 november 1964)
Qu'est ce qu'être normal?
abstract: In a literature on psychol'al normality which is much too rare, the established criterion of normality is often paradoxical or contradictory, leading to a negative approach. Where normality is discussed in a positive sense, definitions vary greatly. The need for a positive criterion, esp in analytical treatment of neurotic patients, calls for definition not only of normality but also of what is considered normal activity. Definitions depend on the established cultural & soc norms, & on the group or individual adjustments made to a society. This holds esp true in an industr society, as in the US, in which adjustment & integration are considered necessary to the pursuit of definite aims. Pathological studies revealed, however, that often what is considered normal in an adjusted individual is attained at the loss of spontaneity &/or creativity. The need is discussed for individual determination of what adjustments to make to the society's required normality, suggesting that personal value judgments will have to play a decisive role in the choice between soc stability, ie normality, & the freedom to be unconventional, ie abnormal, but to obtain the feeling of making a definite contribution to certain envisaged ideals. Normality is further examined in its relationship to talent & genius. The points are made: (1) that an exceptional talent is often paid with a deviation from normality; (2) a complex personality, as evidenced in geniuses, runs a greater risk of deterioration than the average person; (3) it is more difficult, if not impossible, to reconcile great interior contrasts than those of a less complex, less contradictory nature; (4) while a pathological disposition need not produce something valuable, it can act as a stimulant toward increased productivity; (5) a number of geniuses have functioned perfectly normally within the realm of their proper pathologies, & even despite them, by establishing their own norms; (6) in some geniuses pathological abnormality is a means to expand their proper functioning. The conclusion is reached that a society depends as much on its `normally' functioning members as on those who transcend this normality. M. Farber.
tags: TREATMENT, PSYCHOTHERAPEUTIC, NEED FOR CRITERIA OF NORMALITY,

title: Het belang van de Algerijnse trekarbeiders in Frankrijk voor de kadervoorziening van Algerije
abstract: As one of the underdeveloped' countries, Algeria has a shortage of trained manpower. To what extent can the necessary qualified manpower be recruited from the migrant-laborers in France, where only 1% of the Algerians are employed in the agri'al sector of the French economy? An analysis of (1) the evolution of the migration, (2) the training of the migrant laborers & their vertical mobility, (3) their housing situation, (4) the signif of the migration for the Algerian nat'l income, & (5) for the development of the Algerian people shows that, in general, the Algerians in France are unskilled & find themselves on the margin of French society. They have little opportunity for educ & training, & are confronted by the racist attitude of the greater part of the French. The unskilled Algerians can only get the undesirable & dangerous jobs which the French laborers avoid. A process of selection is taking place. A large part of those who, in spite of these circumstances, succeed in getting on, apply for naturalization & do not want to return to Algeria. It is clear that under these circumstances, the Algerians employed in France cannot furnish Algeria with skilled laborers & experts. The transfer of money to Algeria is limited by West European standards. The conclusions of the analysis are far less optimistic than those of Michel Massenet, whose point of view can be found in an article in L'ALGERIE DE DEMAIN (Algeria of Tomorrow), Paris, 1962. His conclusions are summarized & commented upon. AA.

title: Over nazificatie, neonazisme en sociologische theorie
abstract: A report on a book by G. A. Kooy HET ECHEC VAN EEN `VOLKSCHE' BEWEGING, NAZIFICATIE EN DENAZIFICATIE IN NEDERLAND, 1933-1945 (The Failure of a `Folkish' Movement: Nazification and Denazification of the Netherlands, 1933-1945), a monograph on the rise & fall of Nazism in the Dutch town of Winterswijk. The writer has previously reviewed the book (see SA A4807). He now tries to place it in modern sociol'al theory. Kooy is himself a sociol'st; though his book is the result of several yrs of field studies it also bears the mark of several theoretical approaches to sociol (Marx, Loomis & Begle, Lipset, De Kadt, Adorno & Fromm). In a letter to the author, Kooy stated that he (Niezing) had reduced his theoretical approaches to 2 dimensions (econ & psychol'al) which was an oversimplification. The author replies that Kooy should have first attempted to verify his hyp's & then place them within the framework of the 2 dimensions, stressing their overlaps. He criticizes in detail Kooy's application of the macro-sociol'al approaches of Marx (econ) & Adorno (sociol'al). He also criticizes Kooy's 'ethical agnosticism'. In this, says the author quoting R. Dahrendorf, the book 'only contributes to the strengthening of existing tendencies' & the author 'is no better than the society in which he lives.' Finally, he considers whether Kooy's 'ethical agnosticism' could not be replaced by a purely sci'fic approach-the 'iceberg theory' (based on Adorno) which would view Nazism as the top of the iceberg, as a 'soc crystallization of authoritarianism.' I. Langnas.

title: De ontwikkeling van rechtssociologie
abstract: The text of a lecture given in Jan 1965 at the Center for Juridical Studies of the U of Leiden. The sociol of law is defined as 'an empirical sci which can uncover facts & connections between facts.' It should be distinguished from the pol of law, which is concerned with the practical effects of such knowledge. The teleological & sociol'al interpretations of law should be kept apart to prevent confusion. The 3 most important currents of the sociol of law are examined: (1) the historical Sch of E. Ehrlich (GRUNDLEGUNG DER RECHTSSOZIOLOGIE, 1913); (2) the US realistic jurisprudence (R. Pound, K. N. Llewellyn, B. Cardozo, Stone, J. Dewey, Cohen, etc); & (3) the Scandinavian realism (K. Olivecrona, A. Hagerstrom, Lundstedt & V. Aubert). The historical Sch, represented in the Netherlands by Hamaker & Hijmans, is critical & speculative. It views law as 'decision norms' for gov officials. The US realists clearly distinguish between 'dogmatic, systematic sci of law' & 'empirical sci of law' as '2 separate sci'fic disciplines.' In the Netherlands, W. F. Wertheim showed that 'consciously or unconsciously, the causal effects of the law are identified with the content of the norm.' The section on Scandinavia is wholly devoted to the work of the Norwegian jurist Vilhelm Aubert whose outlook is summarized by a quotation: 'What is most signif about law, from the point of view of sociol, is not that legislators & judges are human, group-oriented, class-directed or even irrational.... The real signif of law to the sociol'st is to be found less in deviations from formal patterns than in the law itself. The legal profession applies a structured style of thinking, conceptualization, & decision-making to the solution of particular tasks.... A fruitful starting point for a systematic study of the sociol of law would be to ask ... what are the sociol'al characteristics of the applied theory of legal thinging.' I. Langnas.
tags: SOCIOLOGY, OF LAW, DEVELOPMENT OF THE,

title: De industriële sociologie in Nederland sinds de Tweede Wereldoorlog
abstract: A survey of Dutch industr sociol since WWII, with some general considerations followed by a review of work done in diff areas. Dutch industr sociol largely depends on commissioned work; it tends therefore to be problem-centered & empirical rather than speculative. It reflects the problems of an affluent society with full employment & a general weakening of soc tensions, as examplified in the Labor Foundation in which representatives of employers, workers & Mc assoc's cooperate. Hence, the problems of labor peace are very prominent, esp since the pioneering work of M. G. Ijdo, PLEASURE IN WORK (1956). A number of enquiries into teamwork, HR, & workermanager relations are reviewed. The problems of org & leadership were first seriously tackled by J. A. A. Van Doorn (org, 1956) & D. Horringa (leadership & org, 1959). Their pioneering studies were followed by many studies in the field of 'factory sociol.' The problems of workers' participation in management (medezeggenschap) have come up more recently; they were first systematically tackled by E. C. H. Marx & E. H. de Waal in 1960. The integration of the labor unions into the nat'l society of the welfare state was first studied by M. van der Vall in 1963; the reality & desirability of enterprise integration by H. J. van Zuthem (1961). The old problem of manual vs intellectual workers continues to be the subject of enquiries; but automation has so far produced only an investigation of 6 automated factories by G. Brenninkmeyer (1963). There are notes on current res & the instit'al framework. I. Langnas.

title: Sociology in Secondary Schools
abstract: Sociol should be introduced into HSch's through teachers of mathematics, history, & literature rather than as an independent subject matter. This should eliminate the thorny problem of selecting special teachers for autonomous sociol courses, & the even thornier task of providing contents for such courses. Sociol is basically a humanistic discipline. Its methods of inquiry are, however, sci'fic rather than intuitive or impressionistic. This pronounced dual character places sociol beyond the grasp of the immature & the poorly educated. The injection of sociol into the teaching of history, literature, & mathematics in HSch's should help to place it within the reach of a larger number of students earlier in life. Also, the infusion of sociol into diverse disciplines might well serve to bring them closer together in the students' mind, because the overlapping of the subject matters should undo some of the dept'al fragmentation of the educ'al experience. Observations made by E. Sibley & others re the quality of undergraduate educ in sociol raise further doubts about the advisability of introducing sociol in secondary Sch's as a subject of instruction. Instead, an infusion of sociol'al concepts & methods of inquiry into established subject matters congenial to sociol should provide the solid basis of a well-rounded educ. AA.

title: Valkuil der driedeling
abstract: A critique of the 3-fold typological division preferred by so many soc analysts. E. W. Hofstee's 3 types of pop increase (agri'al-craft, proletarian intermediate, & modern-dynamic or charismatic & rational), impose too much abstraction on empirical situations, which could be avoided by a more multiple division. A 3-fold division of 2 polarities & an intermediate, which can be further split into 2 subdivisions each, as applied by J. Kruyt & Hofstee to Le Play fam types, Kruyt to religiosity & atheism, Josef Pieper to soc groupings of the G&G types, could be just as well, if not better, be replaced by a 2-fold or 4-fold division. Finally considered is D. Pater's division of pol'al systems of developing countries into mobilization systems, reconciliation systems & modernizing autocracies; the middle category is then split into 2. I. Langnas.
tags: WEBER, M., CRITIQUE OF THREE-FOLD TYPOLOGY OF,

title: Conflict in Formal Organizations
abstract: 7 This is an examination of the role of conflict in soc org's which was read at the symposium 'Conflict in Society' organized under the auspices of CIBA in London in Jun/Jul 1965. A historical summary of sociol'al att's is presented. Positive evaluation of conflicts as agents of soc progress by the European schools of K. Marx, G. Mosca, & G. Simmel & of the founding fathers of US sociol were succeeded under the influence of structuralism by a view of conflict as a 'dysfunction.' These tendencies were reinforced in the US by Elton Mayo's emphasis on HR in industry & T. Parson's theoretical approach. But, more recently, there has been a reaction, with Lewis Coser in the US & Ralf Dahrendorf in Germany reverting to the positive evaluation of conflicts by Simmel & Marx. 'The organismic concept of org' is rejected in order to define org's as soc systems in which 'the basic structural condition for contradiction & conflict is a certain degree of independence of the constituent parts.' There is no simple straightforward relation between the degree of functional autonomy & the f of intra-org'al conflicts; but the degree of functional autonomy affects the patterns of conflicts. This hypothesis is applied to 2 contrasting types of soc org's: the loose 'coalition' & the more tightly organized 'soc movements.' In the former, some degree of internal conflict is natural; in the latter, internal schisms cause more trouble, esp when ideology is at stake in soc movements called `sects.' Changes in org'al structure have an immediate effect on the pattern of conflict, as when slackening of ideological control paves the way to a coalition or a 'mildly dichotomous structure.' Conflicts within org's assume a disruptive role when the combination of dependence & autonomy is replaced by the formation of 2 hostile camps. When the conflict becomes `total' it jeopardizes the very existence of the org. The pluralistic soc order of democracies is a major safeguard against `total' conflicts. I. Langnas.
tags: UNITED STATES, SOCIOLOGICAL VIEWS ON CONFLICT IN

title: De boeddhistische monniken als instrument van regeringspolitiek in Thailand
abstract: An evaluation of the potential role of the Buddhist Monkhood as an instrument of gov policy in processes of guided soc change in the Thai countryside. On basis of the literature, it is shown why it seems that the Buddhist Monkhood may be successfully employed in processes of guided soc change & how the central gov employs their influence. It is questioned if active support of the Monkhood can really contribute to the success of the gov in the execution of its programs of modernization, & what consequences such active support may have on the position of the Monkhood. Tendencies are observed which indicate that it will be gradually more difficult to motivate mundane action with religious arguments. It is tentatively concluded that the Monkhood's engagement in nontraditional extra-religious activities may weaken its influence not only in extra-religious affairs, but also in religion. It is therefore recommended that modernization activities should instead be channeled through Sch's, teachers & cooperative socieites, modern instit's from which modern activities are expected, so as not to undermine the position of the traditionally useful instit of the Buddhist Monkhood. AA.
tags: THAI, BUDDHIST MONKS AS AN INSTRUMENT OF GOVERNMENT POLICY IN,

title: Doorkegelen dus
abstract: If Using the terminology of bowling, the author acts as a 'pinsetter' arbitrating a dispute between 2 bowlers. J. Niezing & G. A. Kooy (see SA 0206/C5474, SA 0925/C5845, & SA 0925/C5849) It is noted that Kooy's eyes are fixed upon the past, while Niezing looks towards the future. This is a fundamental cause of their methodological dispute, or rather misunderstanding. In other words, Kooy describes a concrete phenotype, while Niezing wants to establish a general genotype. The second underlying cause of their diff's is their lack of agreement on the role of empirical sociol. However, it is concluded that there is no clear-cut diff between Kooy's `ethical agnosticism' & Niezing's `evaluating' sociol, but rather a diff emphasis. I. Langnas.

title: Rapportcijfers op de H.B.S.
abstract: An investigation concerned with the tracing of the r, if any, between the performance in HBS's (State Secondary Sch's) & the various subjects taught in this type of Sch. Basic data comprised end-of-term report marks of 2nd form students of 25 Dutch HBS's, & a list of 7 characteristics of the relevant Sch, such as size, % of academics, sex, authority. In addition to a r assessment, a factor analysis was carried out in order to isolate a number of group factors. An assessment was also made of specific characteristics of the subjects ('unique factors') so that it could be established for each Sch subject to what extent the specific skills required for a certain subject are independent of those required in other subjects. Findings are as follows: (1) Performance in the 4 languages (Dutch, English, German, French) is highly & positively r'ed. R's appeared to vary from +0.500 to 0.732. (2) Performance in algebra & geometry is highly r'ed (+0.686). (3) Performance in the subjects of geography & history reveals a high positive r (0.537). (4) The specific skills required for physical exercise are independent of those required in the so-called subjects of instruction. The r appeared to be low, varying from 0.01 to 0.145. It was also found that there is a low r between physical exercise & drawing (0.100); influence of size of Sch on the figures showed no signif r; the greater the authority (religion) in the Sch the higher the marks (a low but signif r); & the more academics among the teachers, the lower the marks (signif but low r). The `unique factors,' as calculated from the multiple r's, were as follows: Dutch 0.53, French 0.33, English 0.39, German 0.36, Algebra 0.42, Geometry 0.40, Physics 0.45, Biology 0.67, Geography 0.55, History 0.54, Drawing 0.88, & Physical Exercise 0.92. Modified AA.
tags: SCHOOL, STATE SECONDARY, PERFORMANCE & SUBJECTS TAUGHT IN, HOLLAND,

title: Reactie op Kooy's repliek: de regels van het kegelspel
abstract: A reply to SA 0925/C5845. After a general defense of engagee sociol against `ethical agnosticism' Niezing answers Kooy's 6 specific charges. Charges 1, 2, & 3 are based on a misunderstanding of Niezing's `evaluating' sociol'al method. According to Niezing, Kooy also `evaluates,' eg in his testing of sci'fic hyp's against reality. Charge 4 is refuted by stressing that reliance on both K. Marx & T. Adorno excludes a monocausal approach & a too strict dichotomy into right & left. Charge 5, that a multi-dimensional theory of right-wing extremism based on knowledge of HB is possible & testable, is answered with the assertion of the additional need for such a theory of explanation, a need that has not yet been filled. Finally, in answer to Charge 6 the need for a sociol'al & socio-psychol'al theory that would explain both right-wing & left-wing extremism does not mean that the 2 should be 'shorn over the same comb' (ie treated in the same way). I. Langnas.
tags: SOCIOLOGY, ENGAGEE, DEFENSE OF, RE A REPLY TO KOOY'S REPLY,

title: Reactie op Niezing's vertoog: toch doorkegelen?
abstract: A reply to J. Niezing's review of Kooy's book THE FAILURE OF A 'FOLKISH' MOVEMENT (see SA 0206/C5474). After a general presentation, Niezing's criticism is reduced to 6 theses which are replied to: (1) Ethical agnosticism-this does not exclude a critique of society & its instit's. (2) A sociol'al investigation of right-wing extremism serves the cause of ethical agnosticism-but it is also a safeguard against the sociol'st's emotional sympathies & antipathies. (3) Ethical agnosticism reduces the investigator to the exclusive use of the empirical & inductive method-it by no means excludes deduction or the investigation of structures. (4) Sociol requires a constant checking of theories against reality-this is exactly what Kooy has done with his rich empirical material. (5) A sociol'al theory can be empirically tested only if it takes into account the econ man & the psychol'al man-Kooy's theory is not only based on the 2 but also takes into account the sociol'al man. (6) An explanation of right-wing extremism must also be applicable to left-wing extremism-Kooy does not deny this & gives examples of communists who became Nazi's & vice-versa. I. Langnas.

title: De Nederlandse sociologie bekeken vanuit Indonesië
abstract: This is -inspite of its title-a survey of sociol in Indonesia. 'Dutch sociol' is defined as sociol as taught, studied & practiced by Dutchmen; some data is added on the development of sociol in Indonesia-its teaching was started at the U of Jogjakarta in 1946 & developed rapidly since Independence (1949). In the 1950's, pol'al conditions were not favorable to fruitful contacts between Dutch & Indonesian sociol. The 2 countries were in almost continuous conflict; there were few cultural contacts; the Dutch language became practically unknown to the younger generation-& yet it was in those yrs that Dutch sociol acquired its dominant position in Indonesia. The only Indonesian textbook of sociol, by Hassan Shadily (1948/49) was based on the Dutch textbook of P. Endt. This & other Dutch textbooks still circulate in Indonesia. The 2nd important influence is US sociol, brought back by the thousands of Indonesian students who studied in the US. However, since the restoration of diplomatic relations between the Netherlands & Indonesia, Dutch sociol has regained some ground, with the Dutch gov making its publications available in Indonesia. The 3 main influences today are: prewar Dutch; US sociol; post WWII Dutch sociol. Of particular interest to Indonesian is the sociol of non-Western & developing countries. Here the Dutch have some advantages, because of their old ties with Indonesia & a number of recent specialized studies on that country; though such studies have also been, of late, made by Amer's. Indonesian sociol today is still less advanced than the Dutch; it is also more generalized. The Indonesian sociol'ts expect from their Dutch colleagues 'a finer analysis & a deeper penetration of the subject-matter.' I. Langnas.

title: Die ersten zehn Jahre Soziologie in Göttingen
abstract: An account of the author's first 10 yrs as Professor of Sociol at the U of Goettingen. Whereas the resistance of the traditional academics confined the teaching of sociol after WWI to the U's of Cologne & Frankfurt, sociol was widely welcomed in postWWII German U's as a means of currying favor with the Amer's. At Goettingen, the whole dept of sociol had to be organized from scratch. The author's chief concern was the training of new sociol'ts; this he did first by organizing demoscopic (PO) enquiries, then by training PhD candidates. Cooperation with the Frankfurt Instit for Sociol'al Investigations (Max Horkheimer & T. Adorno) was close, & an enquiry was organized into the past & present position of German U professors (1956), based on statistics & interviews. It was intended as a contribution to the reform of academic teaching in West German, & it was utilized by the Sci Council (created in the late 1950's) to formulate its reform proposals aimed at adapting the U to the needs of an industr society based on higher educ for all. It was felt however, that 'big sci,' sci'fic investigation turned into a kind of industry, itself needed investigating. This he did by organizing an extramural dept at Goettingen modeled on the English U, which was fully incorporated into Goettingen U in 1966. Among its investigations was one devoted to the municipal problems of the city of Wolfsburg, created to house the employees of the Volkswagen works. I. Langnas.

title: Gesien vanuit Suid-Afrika
abstract: To ascertain the image of Dutch sociol held by South African sociol'ts, open-ended questionaires were sent to heads of sociol Dept's at the 10 (white) U's & 5 (nonwhite) U Coll's. On the basis of returned data: (1) the total/sum 1965 academic-sociol'al pop of South Africa (graduate-, post-graduate students & lecturers) is estimated at 5,300; (2) it is concluded that the 2,500 non-Afrikaansspeaking undergraduate students cannot or do not read technical publications written in Dutch; that the small group (+ 250) of Afrikaans-speaking post-graduate students & professional sociol'ts is the only group for whom Dutch is not a language barrier; (3) the prescribed use of Dutch publications, subscription to Dutch periodicals, collegial contact, study & publication in the Netherlands by South African sociol'ts is shown to be very limited; (5) it is found that South African sociol'ts generally debunk the idea of a nat'1 sociol & do not think that `Dutch sociol' is in any way esp relevant to `South African sociol,' though there is appreciation for Dutch sociol'ts' interpretation & criticism of current developments in the field; & (6) it is suggested that an improvement of the academic relations between South Africa & the Netherlands calls, inter alia, for greater Dutch interest in South African sociol. AA.
tags: SOCIOLOGY, DUTCH, IMAGE OF, HELD BY SOUTH AFRICAN SOCIOLOGISTS,

title: Sociology in the Netherlands: Problems and Opportunities
abstract: Nat'l & local diff'iation is characteristic of sociol. Dutch sociol is discussed as a nat'l specialty, & as a part of the worldwide discipline, based on observations made while the author was a visiting professor at the Sociol'al Instit of Utrecht. Dutch sociol is characterized by: (1) a high rating on the ladder of academic respectability; (2) excellent resources in men, instit's & equipment; (3) easy input from the global literature, due to the multilingual reading abilities of the Dutch scholar, but low output due to lack of translation; (4) personal & soc responsibility to the established order. Future contributions of Dutch sociol to the parent discipline might include: (1) analytical sociography-sociol'al theorizing about large-scale, unique historical phenomena, with the aid of statistical data & computers; (2) replication of signif studies made in other modern societies that are less amenable to controlled observation than the Netherlands; (3) the circulation of Dutch res findings in other languages. AA.

title: Some Animadversions on the Americanization of World Sociology
abstract: An examination of the process of Amer'ization as experienced by sociol the world over. US sociol, the latest comer of the soc sci's in the US took over fields to which older-establishments did not lay claim; later, they also invaded these disciplines. US sociol can therefore be more easily defined by what it does not include than by what it includes. It is a heterogeneous discipline, & its influence on other countries is determined by what part of it they take over. Thus, Israel's sociol was molded on the model T. Parsons. Objections are expressed to Parson's theoretical & positivistic sociol: it runs against the pragmatic & practical bent of the best of US soc studies; it is of not much use in analyzing a society, primitive or sophisticated; it vitiates our understanding of soc causation (this is illustrated by the effect of Burgess' study of parole prediction on parole officers who tend to swamp the individual candidate for parole in all kinds of data, relevant & irrelevant); it leads to the invasion of soc studies by people not necessarily well qualified to conduct them; it makes it difficult for sociol'ts to control their own bias. However, it is not theory that is most characteristic of US sociol as a method based on polling, a statistical approach pioneered by the US Census Bur. It is argued that there are signif diff's between the work of the Census Bur & sociol'al enquiries founded on the poll method: census officials are civil servants subject to law; there are no such limitations on sociol'ts. They may not respect the privacy of responses (example: A. J. Vidich & J. Bensman, (see SA 8299); they arouse resentment abroad (Project Camelot in Chile); their range of questions is not based on an understanding of the soc & cultural background of the subjects (a SE survey organized by the U of Ceylon); they may distort reality by sacrificing depth to width (James S. Coleman, THE ADOLESCENT SOCIETY). A sampling of some odd papers read at 1965 meeting of the Amer Sociol Assoc illustrates the dangers of the heterogeneous approach. I. Langnas.

title: Bij de voltooiïng van de veertigste jaargang
Errata, betrekking hebbende op Jaargang 40, No.1, van Mens en Maatschappij
Aspects of the Community Development Program in Thailand
abstract: In order to improve living conditions in the northeastern & southern regions of Ru Thailand, its gov introduced a CD program in those 2 regions in 1960. Compared to other nat'l programs in Asia, Thailand's version of CD is not so much conceived to increase food production as to build up the infrastructure of Ru areas & to integrate existing minority groups into the Thai nation. By giving the villagers opportunities to participate in local projects & by extending technical services, it is expected to raise their standard of living. Apart from a formal, coordinated approach of development activities, informal ways of cooperation between officials & villagers are attempted.
