Outside assistance is introduced through patanakorns (village workers), who prepare the villagers for cooperation in local projects & thereby act as agents for change. A critical point in CD is the degree of COMM with the people; results in this respect depend largely on the att's, training & performances of the village workers & the org'al structure of the supporting agency as a whole. AA.

title: Venster op de conflictologie. Nabeschouwing van een internationaal symposium
Vredesonderzoek onder de loupe. Terugblik op het eerste IPRA-congres (Groningen, 3-5 juli 1965)
Het achtste internationale godsdienstsociologische congres 2-4 juli te Barcelona
abstract: A report on the Barcelona Congress on Religious Sociol of Jul, 1965 whose theme was 'Religion in the Transition from a Pre-Technological to an Industrial and Urban Society.' It is felt that the use of the word religion may be misleading here because the congress was more concerned with ecclesiastical org than with faith. Some papers did concern themselves with the borderland between empirical sci & theological & philosophical problems, esp the introductory remarks of Schreuder (the Netherlands) on developments in religious sociol since 1962, but they did not change the prevailing emphasis on instit'al questions, as expressed in the remark of the Secretary of the Congress, Doucastella, who hoped that it would prove of help in pastoral work. This emphasis may have had something to do with the presence of many Catholics from Mediterranean countries for, except for France, religious sociol has not made much progress there. Of the chief speakers, Kirk (US) talked on the role of the churches in the changing US South; Simey (UK) on the responsibility of the sociol'st in an age of changing values; Pin (Italy) surveyed & schematized religious motivations (primary & secondary, with subdivisions); Prades (Belgium) dealt abstractly with religious values in an Ur environment; Remy (Belgium) criticized Ur church instit's; Greeley (US) reviewed the problems of Catholic educ. The discussions of the Englishlanguage group were found more stimulating than the formal sessions of the Congress. I. Langnas.

title: Nog eens: Marx, Marxisme en Recht
abstract: A review of K. Stoyanovitch, MARXISME ET DROIT (1\larxism and Law), Paris, 1964. The contents of Stoyanovitch's work are compared with Valkhoff's thesis as expressed in THE MARXIST CONCEPTION OF LAW AND STATE (Amsterdam, 1928). The important structural changes of law in relation to the state in the 20th cent are discussed. Stoyanovitch's criticism against the class character of law & state is endorsed. Stoyanovitch's view that the Marxist theory of law is mainly a sociol'al one is acknowledged. Modified AA.

title: Uitgestelde bevrediging, ondernemersgedrag en economische groei
abstract: The pattern of deferred gratification which is a necessary condition for econ growth is intimately associated with Me categories. The private entrepreneurs, embodying the spirit of capitalism, are usually looked upon as the initiators of the first process of econ growth, & attention is focused on these groups in the discussion of the weak position of the Mc in developing countries. With the widely accepted assumption of parallel development goes the implication that econ transition is dependent on the existence of groups of private entrepreneurs. They are the soc concretization of the desired value orientation, although due to the type of entrepreneurs in developed societies, more stress is laid on managerial att's than on satisfaction-deferring att's. The importance of a pattern of behavior committed to capital accumulation in the first stages of econ growth should, however, not be underestimated. The quest for the nontraditional type of private entrepreneurs in developing countries is hardly encouraging & the Japanese case is analyzed to support the thesis that, compared with the Western model, there is a diff in the soc category which played a leading role in the process of growth, in the motivation to defer gratification, & in the way this behavior originated. The usual interpretation of econ growth presupposes not a collective-coercive, but an individualvoluntary pattern of deferred gratification originally limited to private entrepreneurs. Esp in new nations characterized as mobilization systems (D. Apter), plain living & hard working is a doctrine, a binding norm for all. As in the past in Japan, this behavior is partly enforced, partly also an expression of loyal self-discipline. Imposition of deferred gratification is experienced to a lesser degree as coercion if the legitimacy of the power elite (party officials, bur'crats, army officers) is acknowledged & their commitment to econ development as an end in itself or as a means to another end is internalized as a more general norm. AA.

title: De Nederlandse Vakorganisaties in het sociologisch onderzoek: Enkele recente verkenningen
abstract: A study of the changing role of the Dutch unions. Data were obtained by interviewing members of Protestant unions. Fluctuation of membership was investigated. Former members turned out to be marginal persons in several respects. A study of internal integration revealed that 59% appeared to be highly integrated, 31% moderately integrated & 10'70 slightly integrated. 67% appeared to be very loyal re their leaders. The Discriminatory Power Technique was employed. Areas such as SD between leaders & members, willingness to strike, employers protest, perception of wages, consumption aspirations & conservative or radical behavior were studied in the light of the changed position of the Dutch unions since WWII. Unions have come to accept responsibility for the nat'l econ policy (unionism of policy vs former unionism of control). It is remarkable that indoctrination of members with leaders' ideas is rather strong, notwithstanding the greater SD between leaders & members in the present-day system of SE relations. Modified AA.

title: Een evaluatie van het "Rural-Urban Continuum"
abstract: The hypothesis of the Ru/Ur continuum, in sociol was an attempt at joining the process of soc change & soc structure to spatial dimensions. An attempt was made to discover a flowing transition between town & country by r'ing the size of settlements with soc characteristics moving along the continuum as dependent or independent variables. But the hypothesis cannot be made operational & there is no question of a movement of interdependent, variables along a continuum. The relation between town & country is rendered too static & the hypothesis must be looked upon as a form of geographical determinism. The typical characteristic of Ur'ism is that it cannot be geographic-hierarchically localized. Thus the hyp cannot be a starting-point for any further discussion. Along both methodological-theoretical & empirical lines, the shortcomings of this approach have been demonstrated. AA.

title: Evaluatie-onderzoek op het gebied der medische sociologie
abstract: An annual address to the Netherlands' Sociol'al Assoc. The development of Dutch Med sociol shows that the institut'ization of a new sci may be sacrificed to its systematization. No link exists with the older study of soc pathology; the sociol of medicine & psychiatric sociol form 2 distinct, isolated res committees of the Internat'l Sociol'al Assoc. A plea is made for integration. There seems to be a patent need for evaluation res in both major subdivisions of Med sociol. Functional analysis can be used to evaluate existing instit's & provisions. The terms `functional under-institut'ization' & 'over -institut'ization' are coined to describe the lack of hosp's & Med provisions, & the existence of competing Med instit's & org's respectively. These & other functional concepts (latent functions, dysfunctions-if appropriately operationalized) can be used to analyze the intricate field of public health. Statistical evaluation of causal hyp's is also imperative. Both subdivisions of Med sociol tend to converge in more elaborate res programs, eg a soc epidemiological study of smoking habits resulted in an evaluation of a public health instruction campaign, & an extensive absenteeism study shifted from the role of the working-group morale to the evaluation of Med control (see I. Gadourek, ABSENCES AND WELL- BEING OF WORKERS, Assen, 1965). Modified AA.

title: Collectieve houdingen jegens lichaams- en geesteszieken in onze samenleving
abstract: It is stated that there is a definite change in Dutch att's to physical & mental illness: the mentally ill are no longer treated as `mad' or possessed by the devil & phrases like 'lunatic asylum' have been replaced by the Dutch equivalents of 'mental hosp.' There still exists an appreciable discrepancy between the att's of the Med avant garde & those of the general public. In supportofthis contention, US sources are quoted, esp J. C. Nunally Jr's POPULAR CONCEPTIONS OF MENTAL HEALTH (New York, NY: Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 1961), based on an investigation in Ill. Att's towards physical & mental illness do not necessarily go hand in hand; they may be determined by diff historical precedents & operative structural factors. 'The role of the sick' is considered. They have 2 chief rights-exemption from soc duties, ie, educ or military service, & right to special care & attention-& 2 chief duties-not to hinder attempts to help them & not to be sick more than necessary. An examination of collective att's towards physical & mental illness yields 4 conclusions: (1) the behavior of the mentally ill is less easy to regulate soc'ly than that of the physically ill; (2) people are more familiar with the role of the physically ill than of the mentally ill; (3) physical illness is more amenable to prognosis & is usually more transitory than mental illness; & (4) physical & mental illness differ in collective att's towards their 'guilt problem' -these tend to be more negative on mental illness. It is believed that the Med profession should not accept this state of affairs fatalistically but should take definite measures to improve it. I. Langnas.
tags: MENTAL ILLNESS, & PHYSICAL-, COLLECTIVE ATTITUDES TOWARDS,

title: Het afwijkend gedrag als sociaalcultureel en sociaal-psychologisch probleem
abstract: The text of a lecture given to the Central Assoc for Internal Missions & Christian Soc Work in 1963. It is held that values should be examined as to their content, degree of universality, weight & spread; norms as to their precision, adaptability, acceptance, source of authority, transmission, conformity & deviation. The sanctions that may punish or prevent deviant behavior are discussed & the opinion of J. A. A. Van Doorn & C. J. Lammers that sanctions are most effective through expectations is quoted. In a society with conflicting norms, expectations & aims, it is not easy to determine what is normal or what is deviant behavior. 2 conceptions of normality are distinguished: (1) biologic-functional & Med-psychol'al; & (2) statistical, based on the X. Soc reactions towards deviant behavior may be positive or negative. The positive approach is favored here. It is concluded that: 'It is only through rejecting [primitive reactions] & consciously developing practical measures from definite theoretical insights that we can deal positively & adequately with deviant behavior.' I. Langnas.
tags: SOCIAL, CULTURAL & PSYCHOLOGICAL PROBLEM, DEVIANT BEHAVIOR AS A,

title: Sociale problematiek in de psychiatie en geestelijke gezondheidszorg. Nederlandse literatuur uit de periode 1956 t/m 1965
abstract: There is little mutual influence between psychiatry & sociol in their approach to soc problems. Sociol'ts normally have easier access to the internat'ly oriented sociol'al literature in this field than to publications from (semi)-Med & psychiatric sources. To stimulate the COMM between psychiatric sociol & soc psychiatry, a systematically arranged Bibliog of Dutch literature in this field, published by Med or semi-Med instit's, is presented. AA.

title: Kanttekeningen. Scientiae honoris causa
abstract: sjg wrs Sj. Groenman

title: Max Weber - de politicus
abstract: A study of Max Weber's pol'al activities, read as a paper to the Max Weber memorial meeting of the Dutch Sociol'al Assoc on Feb 11, 1964. To be a politician was Weber's ideal: 'No, I was born for the pen & the rostrum, not for the U chair,' & 'All ultimate questions are touched, without exception, by pol'al events, however external they may seem.' Weber's active pol'al life was reduced to his unsuccessful attempts to become a candidate to the German Parliament & his role as consultant to Hugo Preuss in drafting the Constitution of the Weimar Republic (Preuss rejected his suggestion that the President become, as in the US, the head of the gov instead of the Federal Chancellor). He also joined the movement of Friedrich Naumann for a conservative renovation of German pol & investigated the situation of the German agri'al laborer for the Soc Policy Assoc. Weber's pol'al views are grouped under 3 heads: (1) the nat'l power state (Weber wanted Germany to be one); (2) internal German pol (Weber was disturbed by them); & (3) parliamentary democracy (Weber was for it). I. Langnas.

title: Over de omgang met theorie in de praktijk
abstract: A study of the practical uses of theory, with the following themes: (1) the need of theories to justify topical ideas (eg of the Bible in debates on property); (2) the use of theories in public discussions (Adam Smith & John Kenneth Galbraith in econ's); (3) the demand for soc ideas by the educated public (sociol'al ideas about advertising); (4) the sociol'st & his sci in the play of supply & demand (good theories save res costs). I. Langnas.

title: Urban local government in the South Pacific
abstract: A study of the special problems of municipal gov in the South Pacific area. Anglo-Saxon & French approaches to local gov are presented; the historical, pol'al, soc, econ & cultural characteristics of South Pacific towns are examined; & the powers & functions of Ur local gov & its financial & representative aspects are discussed. It is concluded that the central gov in that area has created & initiated municipal gov & is responsible for educating the citizens towards it, with adequate staffing being the key factor for further development. I. Langnas.
tags: URBAN, LOCAL GOVERNMENT IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC

title: Sociologie van de vakvereniging. Kritische opmerkingen bij G. Kuiper's overzicht van het sociologisch onderzoek der vakorganisaties
abstract: CriticLSm is presented on the lack of historical dimension in G. Kuiper's res on unionism (see SA 0621/C6444). It is argued that sociol must utilize the historical approach if it is to lead to understanding the major problems of contemporary unionism. These should be seen against the background of the historical process, in which unionism takes on new forms to fulfill its central function in a changing society. Opinion polling among unionists does not reveal the more profound motivations for union affiliation. Modified AA. DUPLIEK G. Kuiper

title: Vrijheid van beroepskeuze: ideaal of ideologie?
abstract: Occup'al choice is both a temporal (Sch, occup, org) & a spatial (micro, meso, macro) process. Attention is paid to the cultural determination of the process: the diff'ial values & expectations on the one hand; the structuring of those orientations on the other. N. S. Timasheff's kinetic process is applied; the occup'al choice process is an important factor towards the stabilization of society & the occup'al structure. This is the matrix for ideologies: choosers apply a set of standard expectations to a situation which is unique only from their point of view. The freedom of occup'al choice is often stated in terms of individual or parental value orientations, partly because the prevailing ideologies prevent us from seeing the real determinants of the choice process. In the course of time there is a shift away from individual & parental toward org'al & societal influences. This is a development crucial to the individual & society. There are 2 sets of ideologies: ideologies concerning the content of the choices (eg craftsmanship, or the service ideal), & ideologies concerning the choice process itself (eg equality of opportunity, or the irrevocability of choices). These ideologies effectively block the way to new patterns of expectations following soc & technological change, & they are dysfunctional at all stages & levels of the process. AA.

title: United Nations' peace-keeping operations as a politico-sociological problem. Some preliminary evaluations and hypotheses
abstract: From an org'al-sociol'al point of view it is more meaningful to compare the internal functioning of UN force with that of other internat'l forces than with that of other UN org's. From politico-sociol'al point of view there are important parallels be tween processes of internalization among members of UN forces & that of members of other UN bodies. More relevant yet are questions dealing with the external functioning of the Ul force. Concerning the relation between UN force & pol'al process, the nature of its 'politico-activity,' given a certain pol'a process, is dependent on the purposes the UN forces dictate to themselves. In this respect one should distinguish between isolation of conflicts & interposition. Furthermore, the roles of the UN force might be categorized into an 'O-role' vs 'constabulary-role.' These classifications lead to the followin hyp's: (1) interposition in the case of a local dynamic process leads to a local dynamic equilibrium; (2) interposition in the case of a local dynamic equilibrium leads to a local static equilibrium; (3) interposition in the case of a local or intercom munal dynamic pol'al process stresses the 'constabulary role' (4) interposition in the case of a local or intercommunal dynam equilibrium stresses the 'O-role'; (5) the greater the effective ness of the UN force the stronger, relatively, its 'constabulary role' will be accentuated; & (6) the lesser the effectiveness of the UN force, the stronger, relatively, its 'O-role' will be accentuated. On the basis of these classifications & hyp's more detailed observations might be accomplished. AA.
tags: UNITED NATIONS, POLITICO-SOCIOLOGICAL PROBLEM PEACE KEEPING OPERATIONS OF, AS A

title: United Nations Forces: on Legitimacy and Effectiveness of International Military Operations
abstract: A study of the military operations of the UN. It is held that its internat'l peace-keeping operations are 'a new problem.' Since the UN is a coalition, there arises a problem of legislation, a very delicate matter because the degree of instit'ization is very low. Another serious question is that of effectiveness; it is rendered more acute by the ad hoc character of UN forces & their multi-nat'l composition. Traditional solutions are of little use for this new type of military force; hence the need of further discussion & exp'tion by professional military men. I. Langnas.
tags: UNITED NATIONS, FORCES, LEGITIMACY & EFFECTIVENESS OF

title: Macht en Sociale beheersing
abstract: A study of soc control & its constituent elements. Soc control is defined as 'the process of limiting behavior alternatives of members of a soc system with regard to certain determined behavior areas on the basis of a complex of normative concepts, sanction expectations & power acceptances linked to that system. (1) Normative concepts are analyzed with regard to conformity, (2) sanction expectations with regard to adaptation, & (3) power acceptance with regard to the characteristics of power (power implies an agent & a recognized source & a purpose-its exercise is never 100% certain) & its means (enumeration of 11 categories). I. Langnas.
tags: SOCIAL SYSTEM, RE SOCIAL CONTROL & POWER

title: The organizational role of the military in the modernization-process
abstract: A study of the role of the military in modernization of underdeveloped countries, with special reference to Indonesia, based on M. Janowitz's THE MILITARY IN THE POLITICAL DEVEL- OPMENT OF NEW NATIONS (see SA 0623/B5070). The background of military involvement in pol is studied with the aid of Janowitz's 'civil-military model.' An evaluation is presented of military performance in various fields of modernization (polity, economy, burley, stratification of elites, norms, behavior, & orientations). The specific case of Indonesia is examined, & it is concluded that '...the military in Indonesia has so far failed pol'ly...failure has also been noticed in the field of economy ... military involvements in administration or bur'cy have caused ... more confusion than efficient & coordinative action.' However, 'in spite of its apparent failure as a major modernization agent ... a variety of advantageous circumstances ... could make the Indonesian army capable, in the future, of helping to stabilize & develop its country.' An Appendix offers a res design for further investigation. I. Langnas.
tags: ROLE, OF MILITARY IN THE ORGANIZATION PROCESS

title: Opmerkingen over de machtspositie van het maatschappelijk opbouwwerk in grote steden
abstract: The problem of coordination of welfare services is esp urgent in the Netherlands because of the verzuiling ('pillarization,' on a religious basis). In 1964 the central gov created the possibility to instit in large towns, agencies for consultation & cooperation in the welfare area. However, the agencies which came into being were actually, at least in part, a continuation of the so-called Armenraden (Council of Soc Agencies). At the time the latter had been engaged in some activities in this area of consultation & cooperation. The success of these attempts is doubtful. The question arises at this moment whether the activities of the new agencies will, in the near future, have a greater probability to suc,;eed. Some hyp's are developed to make this question more appropriate for empirical testing. This process can be subsumed, following Ronald Lippitt, under the concept 'planned change' (see SA 7702). Further it is said that, in studying the effect of help, whatever the form of it may be, a close examination of the soc positions of the change agent & the client system involved, will be indispensable. It is suggested that the power position of the change agent has to be stronger than that of the client system, at any rate with those aspects that are closely connected with the functioning of the SR between the 2 systems. Next it is pointed out that this thesis will in particular hold with the special type of help that is discussed, viz community org, for in this case the client system is generally very complex & the demand for help will seldom be initiated by the system itself. The thesis just mentioned has the implication that the power position of a co-ordinating agency has to be above a certain minimum in order to function effectively, a minimum which in its turn is determined by the power position of the client system. This gives rise to the hyp's that the probability of success of a co-ordinating agency (1) will be greater in small than in large towns, (2) will be greater in Ru areas than in towns, (3) will be greater in activities directed to new endeavours with the pop itself (eg, settlement work) rather than in activities directed towards co-ordinating the work of other agencies. Eventually, some suggestions are offered in order to enhance the power positions of the newly established agencies. AA.

title: Over indiceren
abstract: An examination of the theoretical aspects of indices, a discipline shared by sociol & philosophy of knowledge. E. V. W. Vercruysse attempted to combine both these points of view; but the result is 'very disappointing.' The theory of P. Lazarsfeld's approach is considered 'nothing more than an analysis of the practice of indexing, with the logical problems remaining unsolved.' It is concluded that insufficient attention has been paid to theorizing on indices. I. Langnas.

title: Vriendschapsrelaties in Swifterbant. Enkele aspecten van informele relaties in een nieuw dorp in Oostelijk Flevoland
abstract: A study of the role of friendship among the inhabitants of the village of Swifterbant, established in 1954-1962 on the land won from the Zuiderzee & peopled mostly by former workers employed in its creation. It is based on the author's residence in Swifterbant (Jul 1964-Sep 1965) & on a M admin'ed in the winter of 1964-5 to 105 fam's. Statistics are offered on N of friends per fam (0 for 5; 1 for 15; 2 for 25; 3 for 22; 4 for 20; 5 for 11; 6 for 4; 7 for 3); use of evening hours by 70 couples; ways in which friends were met; selection of friends in function of variables (work situation & church membership; soc contacts). A Bibliog of 50 items. I. Langnas.

title: Huwelijksadvertenties in India
abstract: A critical appraisal of 2 studies on the same subject (see SA 1941/C0712 & C2601), & a comparison (a) with the outcomes of an analysis of 305 advertisements in The Hindustan Times, Feb, 1964, (b) with the results of an earlier analysis (see SA A4998), & (c) with the outcome of res done among F students of the Rajasthan U at Jaipur in 1964 & 1966 (unpublished). Variables taken into consideration were the same in all cases. It is possible to compare the wishes & expectations of parents, as expressed in the advertisements, with those of the girls, as expressed in interviews. Emphasis on caste & dowry in the advertisements & the high % of girls preferring marriage arranged by the parents are indicative of the influence of tradition in a persistently closed marriage system. Both the advertisers & the F students stressed the necessity of high academic qualifications & the ability of earning an income independent of the prospective husband. The increased emphasis on higher educ for girls, as apparent from the advertisements, was explained by the F students as a necessary prerequisite for better marriage chances. AA.

title: Automatisering, socio-technische systemen en organisatiesociologie
abstract: A study of the relations between changing technology & industr org, based on an examination of the existing literature. After defining & explaining automation, an evaluation of the 'classical theories of org' is presented (Thomas, Fayol, Mooney, etc). These theories are found to agree with C. J. Haberstroh, & are primarily efficiency-oriented. But the challenge of automation has found such theories inadequate because they overconcentrate on formal aspects of org with neglect of technological aspects of the enterprise. Hence the rise of 'socio-technical system theories' (E. L. Trist, A. K. Rice, R. Dubin, J. Woodward, I. R. Bright, etc), which are 'open' & aim at a complete task structure, including changing technology. A 70-item Bibliog. I. Langnas.
tags: SYSTEM, SOCIOLOGY OF ORGANIZATION SOCIO-TECHNICAL, AUTOMATION &

title: Zelfmoord bij niet-westerse volken ; een socio-psychologische benadering
abstract: In order to achieve a comparative study of suicide in diff societies, an approach which combines soc & psychol'al points of view is necessary. The following factors have to be considered where diff's in the nature & the f of suicide in diff societies are found: (1) The acculturation pattern in a society will breed more or less aggression in the individual & will influence the direction of this aggression. (2) As an individual belongs to a certain soc category within a society, he will have to play certain soc roles, which carry greater or lesser risks & frustration. In this way an individual is soc'ly predestined to suicide to a certain extent. (3) Belonging to a certain soc category exposes the individual to a smaller or larger measure of soc control, & the influence of this control will depend on the extent to which suicide has been instit'ized as a behavior pattern. A continuum was found with individual suicide on one side & instit'al suicide on the other, & a place on this continuum was considered for a number of non-Western peoples, including the Maria in south India, the Bugosa & the Joluo in Africa, North Amer Plains Indians, Eskimos, & Japanese. Modified AA.

title: The indirect questionnaire as a tool for sociological research
abstract: An account of a new type of questionaire developed by Bulgarian sociol'ts. The 'indirect questionaire' is filled out not by the S but by the investigator. The latter acquaints himself with the S's life, work, fam situation etc, talks to at least 2 or 3 people who know him well, &, if necessary, interviews the S without revealing his purpose. This method was first worked out in an enquiry into the religiousness of the Bulgarian people led by Zhivko Ochavkov (1962); it was also used in an investigation of Sofia youth in 1966. It is claimed that the method produces results comparable to the use of the direct questionaire. A comparative check for 20,675 S's whose religiosity was investigated produced a discrepancy of only 2%. The indirect questionaire method has certain specific advantages: it is specially useful for facts which are both part of individual consciousness & of the consciousness of others & in cases where a negative evaluation of the S is possible; it makes possible the investigation of persons selected according to a certain criterion; it may be used in small pop centers where people know each other intimately & in Ur areas where individuals have multiple org'al ties; it synthetizes information produced from varied sources. I. Langnas.
tags: SOCIOLOGICAL, RESEARCH, THE INDIRECT QUESTIONNAIRE AS A TOOL FOR

title: Europese sociologie voor het oprapen. Naar een 'Instituut voor Europese Sociologie?'
abstract: A discussion of 3 books on France: (1) on conspiracies by J. R. Tournoux, L'HISTOIRE SECRETE (The Secret History, Plon, 1962); (2) on access to diff kinds of power by M. Drancourt, LES CLES DU POUVOIR (The Keys to Power, Fayard, 1964); & (3) on the history of the pol'al right wing by R. Remond, LA DROIT EN FRANCE (The Right Wing in France, Aubier, 1963). Using these books & briefly citing other relevant literature, an attempt is made at a socio-psychol'al analysis of French soc & pol'al character in terms of authoritarian vs democratic. It is concluded that French nat'l character, in conjunction with French soc structure, is still highly authoritarian. The analysis also demonstrates: (1) That nat'l character analysis is perfectly feasible at the present stage of development of the fields of sociol & psychol, & that an abundance of material is available. (2) That this type of analysis is necessary to an understanding of the changes in European integration. (3) Along with other types of res, this kind of analysis can constitute the discipline of 'European sociol,' a field which is virtually nonexistent at the present time. Modified AA.

title: Het monster van Lac Léman
authors: Doorn,J. A. A. van,   Ellemers,J. E.,   Jolles,H. M.,   Kooy,G. A.,   Matthijssen,M. A. J. M.

title: What We Still Owe to Auguste Comte
abstract: A presentation of the life & work of A. Comte & an evaluation of his contributions to sociol in relation to their development in more recent sociol'al literature. The following subjects are discussed & analyzed: (1) the internal dynamics of Comte's psychic condition in relation to his achievements; (2) Comte's contributions toward the founding of a sci'fic sociol (positivism); (3) Comte's work in the classification of the sci's & his positing of the inextricable connection between them; (4) the law of the 3 stages-theological, metaphysical & positive-& its relation to the sociol of sci & the SofK; (5) Comte's pioneering insights into the SofK-taken in itself & in relation to the work of K. Marx, M. Scheler & E. Durkheim; (6) Comte's contributions to & insights into comparative history & soc change; (7) the formulations of society as organism & system & of the relationshi between social structure ('Statics') & soc change ('Dynamics') (8) Comte's ideas on the relationship between psychol ('cerebral biology') & sociol & their relevance to S. Freud's; (9) his vision of the Religion of Humanity in which positivist priests were to interpret the doctrine of love, order, & progress through educ & preaching; (10) his res methodology of observation, experiment & comparison. The major thesis is that sociol still owes an everlasting debt to Comte which needs to be re-evaluated at important turning points in sociol's orientation & consequently that an analysis of the implications of his theories is still a required task in today's perspective. R. J. Rosen.
tags: SOCIOLOGY, CONTRIBUTIONS OF A. COMTE TO

title: Over jeugdwerk en onderzoek
abstract: It is stated that the concept of 'youth' is absent in most primitive societies, at least as a category of 10-22 yr olds who present a special S-cul problem or subgroup agglomerate. Children & youngsters in Western European societies first obtained special attention during the industr revolution. The early forms of private European youthwork took root at that time & can be diff'iated from the later outgrowths of societal movements. A survey & analysis of the development of public youthwork in the Netherlands sponsored by gov & municipality re its org'al setup & the nature of its activities indicates: (1) a solid loss of members of youth org's since 1961, (2) the after-effects of an ambivalent 'youth movement' ideology which cut young people off from society, (3) still widespread naive stereotyping of youth among leaders, officials, & authorities, (4) still sparse & generally weak contacts on all levels with outside agencies or res & information, (5) the absence of an internal informational structure to counteract the above problems-this situation is painfully reflected in the overall quality of youthwork periodicals; (6) no agreement or historical perspective about the nature of the work to be done; (7) strong positions held in the framework of a bur'tic system by senior authorities or officials with vested interests in the older branches of work. Public fictional views of youth & the youth concept are being commercially exploited more & serve to bolster false personality identities re age-groupings; this hinders the emancipation of young people & prevents them from being soc'ly engaged in a more conscious, critical way. Their encounter with the instit's of their society is often by necessity & is dysfunctional due to a lack of societal power. This power can also be withheld from them by group consensus of a repressive nature which is associated with rigid beliefs about their soc role as grownups (erwachsenen). Modified AA.

title: Community development in the Arab world
abstract: An account of CD in Arab countries as of mid-1966 & an examination of the underlying concepts. Data are offered on CD in Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Syria & Kuwait. There is no agreement on the underlying concepts of CD, esp in their application to the area under review. 'The process of change should, for instance, in the eyes of some traditional religious leaders, not be looked upon in the sense that it means emancipation ... That would be identical with rejecting Islam.' Again, Lebanon 'for pol'al reasons, rejects the idea of seeing CD as a movement' because it might upset the delicate Christian/Muslim balance. The real test of the effectiveness of a program is said to be not the changes achieved but the increased willingness of the people to plan, organize & apply themselves effectively to the achievement of their own welfare. In Arab countries, CD should aim at 3 things: (1) the promotion of willingness at the local level to accept CD & to contribute to it, (2) the creation of a link between the gov & the people to foster CD, & (3) the encouragement of cooperation in order to avoid duplication & unnecessary gaps in CD efforts. I. Langnas.

title: A comparative study of the problem of multi-lingualism
abstract: Conflicts between language groups within pol'al systems emerge with universal literacy when multi-lingual societies undergo Ur'ization & industr'ization. The failures of successive pol'al systems to resolve language conflict in Central Europe are contrasted with the successful solution of the language problem in other parts of Europe, with special attention given to bilingualism in Southern Denmark. Bi-lingualism in Canada shares certain characteristics with multi-lingualism in pol'al systems that succeeded in accommodating their language problem, but it also shows features which marked pol'al systems that failed. Multi-lingualism is likely to disrupt a pol'al system when pressures to learn the languages used within the system are distributed unevenly. This is the case when the more important language within the pol'al system is also the more important one outside. Multi-lingualism is also a source of conflict when the direction &/or intensity of pressures to learn other languages are changing. Tensions over official recognition of language use may be compounded by class conflict, religious disputes, racial strife, & by foreign relations that involve pol'al interference from across the border. Multi-lingualism does not become a disruptive issue when the members of diff language groups are under comparable pressures to learn one another's languages. This is the case in agrarian societies under elites that share a lingua franca, when languages in question are of comparable rank, or when the language of higher rank within the pol'al system is of lesser rank abroad-provided no irredentist pressures are exerted from across the border. Language conflicts are more likely to be resolved when at least the well educated of all language groups know the languages of their fellow citizens than when only one of the language groups is bi-lingual. Multi-lingualism is not a source of conflict where most of the people are fluent in the languages spoken in their society. Modified AA.
tags: LANGUAGE, GROUPS, CONFLICTS BETWEEN, WITHIN POLITICAL SYSTEMS

title: Enkele hypothesen omtrent de samenhang tussen kerklidmaatschap en convivium. Naar aanleiding van een onderzoek onder gereformeerden in Osdorp
abstract: In the Netherlands there exists a rather strong r between the religious composition of an individual's circle of friends & church membership. This cannot be explained entirely by the f of contacts with nonmembers. From an explorative interview survey (closed & multiple-choice questions) of a sample of 104 members of an orthodox calvinistic denomination in a modern suburb (Amsterdam-Osdorp), data were collected which make it possible to hypothesis that some kind of attraction of fellow church members makes for selection of friends. In accordance with the findings in this (select) sample of strongly & less strongly committed church members, specific hyp's can be developed: (1) the stronger the religious commitment of an individual, the stronger the attraction of fellow-church members as friends; (2) if there is any attraction between church members, this is more relevant for more intimate forms of interaction; (3) it is possible to postulate a relation between the intimacy of interaction & the selection of the partner of interaction. In conclusion, it is stated that where there exists any soc attraction between church-members, the more intimate friends of an individual will more often be fellow church members. Modified AA.
tags: NETHERLANDS, CHURCH MEMBERSHIP & CONVIVIUM IN THE

title: Political radicalism and social change
abstract: A r'al analysis of 22 quantitative variables was applied to a sample of 95 communities (drawn at random out of 1,014 communities in the Netherlands) in order to determine the main structural variables & the structural is of pol'al radicalism. The latter was indicated by the % of votes for the radical leftist parties & for the Boeren Party, a rightist radical party. In addition to 2 factor-analysis programs (with the standardized Varimax & Promax rotations), a new program for the computation of high-order partials was applied to the matrix of 22 inter-r'ed variables. Results were analyzed along the lines devised by H. M. Blalock for the causal inferences from nonexp'al res. Findings indicate an intensive association of secularization with pol'al radicalism & a high inter-connectedness of various indicators of leftist radicalism. Another cause may be seen in industr'ism (earlier industr'ization) which is, in its turn, r'ed with initially lower income level as resulting from migration of Ls strata to industr'izing communities & from pop surplus (as indicated by large tam size). Both industr'ism & secularization result in a decrease in fam size which opens the possibility of applying the model of cyclical soc change to the present situation in the Netherlands. Contrary to expectation, no positive association could be found between industr'ization or Ur'ization & secularization. Neither community-growth, nor more Sch educ r with radical att's when a more controlled design of study such as this is applied. AA.

title: Futurologie
abstract: Futurology is child of the cybernetic revolution which confronts man, in a new way, with the old problem of means & ends. The concept of culture denotes the great detour which man has to make in order to realize himself. He is the only living being that, in order to reach its ends, has to break ways which at the same time threaten to become blocked by the accumulation of means as the products of his inventiveness. That is why he is always 'on his way' & subject to the dialectics of means & ends, to the tension between what 'he' aims at & what 'it' results in. Sci & technology are the main causes of the rapid changes that have taken place in recent times. With the help of these means, futurology tries to predict & to direct developments that may be expected over a shorter or longer period of time. However, philosophers & theorists disagree on the predictability of soc events. Cooperation between diff fields of study is a primary prerequisite for any sci'ly reliable futurology. History shows that man's simple & rectilinear predictions are again & again frustrated by the irrational, the contingent, the not-thought-of. The question is not whether sci is able to formulate predictions or forecasts about itself, but about the whole of soc reality with which it is closely interlocked. The main problem for any policy starting from the findings of futurology will be the problem of preferences & allocations. AA.

title: Knowledge and Action in Sociological Theory
abstract: Soc action & soc change are related to tensions arising out of: (a) incongruities among various forms of knowledge, (b) antagonistic cooperation between individual &. collectivity: (c) the dialectical relationship between knowledge & action. All forms of human knowledge are considered legitimate objects for sociol'al inquiry since they may be needed to explain conduct. Knowledge as the conceptual basis for action is divided into 3 forms referring to values, norms, & empirical facts. Values state what is desirable, facts state what is possible, & norms state how to do it. Interaction models involving 2 individuals (G. H. Mead) or 2 classes (K. Marx) are merged into a model of interaction between individual & collectivity. The individual is described as having primacy in action, the collectivity as having primacy in knowledge. (Soc definition, W. I. Thomas.) Knowledge not applied in action becomes false, action not related to knowledge becomes meaningless. It is concluded that the soc structure disintegrates or becomes inflexible if free interplay among the 3 forms of knowledge, between individual & collectivity, or between knowledge & action, is hampered. AA.

title: Brieven uit benauwde vestes
abstract: An analysis of letters which were sent in reply to an advertisement in Amsterdam newspapers on Oct 26, 1965, in which the Amsterdam Municipal Housing Service offered 4-room apartments (apt's) in a new housing estate in the Amsterdam suburb of Purmerend, with preference given to people who could offer in exchange an apt in Amsterdam or could prove an urgent need. Some 2,000 letters arrived in reply, of which 1,870 were analyzed, with the following conclusions: (1) the great majority of inquiries came from people living in overcrowded apt's or with no apt's of their own. (2) 1 out of 5 inquirers with apt's of their own had fam's with a membership larger by at least 2 than the N of available rooms, but only 17% could prove urgency. (3) Almost 50% of the inquirers had fam's with 2 or more children; 66.6% had children under 15. (4) 50% of the inquirers with apt's of their own had 3-room apt's, a particularly awkward size. (5) An unusual number of inquiries came from the Western parts of Amsterdam, for a number of reasons-housing shortage, prevalence of young fam's, too many 3-room apt's, familiarity with long travel to job, etc. (6) Only 4% of the inquiries came North of the river IJ & the North See Canal. (7) Only 7% of the inquiries came from people with apt's of 5 or more rooms. I. Langnas.

title: Schoolprestaties en beroepscarrière
abstract: In order to establish a connection between Sch results of HSch students & their professional careers in later life, the records were studied of some 900 boys & girls who had been admitted to the 1st yr of the Lorentz Lyceum in Eindhoven between 1930 & 1949. Complete data were assembled as to age, N of classes repeated, & courses completed. The SL's of fam's were determined by fathers' profession & ranged into 4 groups: lower, middle, high & very high. It was possible to trace the whereabouts of all but 8 of these former students &to send out a questionaire to all living alumni; response was 87%. It was found that the N of children attending this type of Sch increased with SS: in the Ls group 73% had no brothers or sisters in the Sch; in the Hs group 18% had siblings at the Sch. Practically all of the dropouts attended other HSch's. 80% of the total/sum group obtained a degree in 1 of the 4 courses offered, which enabled them to enter a U. Those who were admitted at the ages of 11 or 12 (some were only 10) did much better than those who entered at the ages of 13 or 14. There was a small diff in Schleaving between soc groups, due to a tendency in the Ls groups to leave Sch after 3 or 4 yrs. U attendance increased since 1945, esp for boys. Girls have tended more towards professional Sch's, which provide training for non U-level professions (teachers, nursing & secretarial Coll's). Only 63% of the boys & 49% of the girls who had entered U's completed the 1st course in which they enrolled. Those who attended professional schools (technical & naval Coll for boys) had much better results: only 10% failed to obtain a degree. All U-educated alumni secured high-level jobs, but those who did not possess a U degree were not excluded from high-level jobs. 33.3% of those without a U degree were working in high-level jobs, 3% in very high. For those who did not complete the lyceum the same %'s were found: 33.3% in high-& 66.6% in middle-level jobs. Only 6 men held jobs that could be classified as lowerlevel. Among those who had been asked to leave the Sch because of insufficient progress, 33.3% held high-level jobs, & 3 were in top-managerial functions. Alumni living abroad (20%) had slightly better records than those who had remained in the Netherlands. AA.

title: De plurale samenleving: debat en verwarring
abstract: A symposium on A. F. J. Köbben's paper on the plural society presented to the Internat'l Sociol'al Congress of 1966 at Evian. W. F. Wertheim, 'One Society, Plurality of Values and Cultures,' suggests that the concept of 'plural society' is meaningless. (2) H. Hoetink, 'Eight Old Request Theses on Segmented Society,' defines 'segmented society' as a society which lacks both racial & cultural homogeneity. (3) O. D. Van Muizenberg, 'New Weapons in an Old Fight,' presents a schema of plural societies based on the interplay between culture (single culture; culture with subcultures; several cultures) & culture (upper/lower strata; co-ordinate strata). (4) J. D. Speckman, 'Power-, Prestige- and Reference Structure,' applies this schema to Indonesia & its racial groups. (5) A. N. J. den Hollander, 'A Tough Misunderstanding,' suggests that the concept of 'plural society' is not wholly useless; but it must be very carefully defined. (6) A. J. F. Köbben, 'Once Again: The Plural Society,' presents a schema applying 5 pairs of concepts (coordinate & hierarchic; culturally homogeneous & heterogeneous; racially homogeneous & heterogeneous; geographically separate or mixed; with & without competing positions) to South Africa, India, Miss, the Netherlands; Surinam & Nigeria in 2 diagrams, & makes critical remarks on previous contributions. I. Langnas.

title: Instituties en geschiedenis
abstract: Instit's can be conceived of as frozen products of the past (tradition). Sociol, as the study of soc instit's, therefore, very easily ends up in conceptual reification & a society-model that looks like the cosmos-concept of antiquity or the Middle Ages. This cosmos-model is opposed to the post-medieval intellectual trend of explaining reality in terms of processes, developments & changes. This trend is at the same time expressed by a world view which is conditioned by historical awareness & has its roots not in ancient greece but in ancient israel (prophetic tradition). From this point of view a sociol'al cosmosmodel of society is no longer adequate for a modern intellectual frame of reference & should be replaced by a dynamic model which leaves room for history & changes. The problems of such a model are discussed & a solution is sought in a dialectic theory of soc reality. A dynamic sociol'al theory, therefore, is claimed to be necessary not so much because of rapid soc changes in modern society, but because of the necessity to keep sociol'al theory outside the pre-modern, inadequate frame of reference of a cosmos-model. AA.

title: De wisselwerking tussen sociologie en sociale arbeid in de Verenigde Staten
abstract: A discussion of the relationship of sociol to soc work, based on conferences held with professors of sociol at 10 Sch's of soc work in the US. The past 8 yrs have seen an increase in & more direct contact between the 2 disciplines. Programs related to the 'war on poverty' employ many sociol'ts & a sci'fic approach is required of soc workers involved in community action programs. The strategy of the 'war on poverty' is based largely on the theories of R. Cloward & L. Ohlin, as detailed in DELINQUENCY AND OPPORTUNITY (see SA A4411). Younger soc workers display a growing interest in purposive structural change. It is noted that impressive results are not seen as far as individual psychoanalytically oriented soc work is concerned. The so-called soc system approach leans more & more on a conflict type of societal model which is used not only by practitioners such as S. Alinsky, but also in sociol'al theory. Modified AA.

title: De Amsterdamse burgemeestersrol. Verslag van een sociologische verkenning onder Amsterdamse kiezers
abstract: Due to unusual pol'al circumstances, the city of Amsterdam went without a mayor for a short period in Spr 1967. An investigation was made into the public's general expectations for the mayoral office, based upon interviews with a representative sample (N=324) of voters of Amsterdam. The res focused on 2 questions: (a) Do the R's' expectations manifest one or more distinct patterns? If so, what are the dimensions of these patterns? (b) May these diff patterns of expectation (role profiles) be explained by relating them to major soc variables (eg, sex, age, pol'al party)? A number of single sentence items, with closed response formulas, were chosen. These reflected diff types of imaginable personal attributes or elements of behavior which could be associated with this office. It was expected that these items would group together to form a limited number of role profiles. The method used to analyze the data was factor analysis (+ Varimax rotation). Major findings include: (1) The patterns revealed were more heterogeneous than was expected. Only a few clusters were found & these explained only a small portion of the total variation. (2) Most background variables were not signif'ly related to these patterns. (3) Role clusters were composed more frequently of expectations for personal attributes than expectations for behavior. A possible explanation for this result could be that the role was vacant; this would make specific patterns of behavior difficult to visualize. (4) The patterns that the res'ers had expected were probably related to more permanent attributes of the mayoral role, whereas the responses seemed to indicate a more situational orientation. AA.

title: De sociale wetenschappen in Indonesia na de tweede Wereldoorlog
abstract: A survey of soc sci res about & in Indonesia, based upon an examination of the relevant literature. Dutch studies of Indonesia failed to recover the prewar level; most of the work done is a continuation of studies initiated before 1941. The main reason is that Indonesia, after it obtained its independence, ceased to be of special interest to the Dutch, & Indonesian studies became a mere part of 'nonWestern sociol.' To compensate for this, a new interest in Indonesia arose in the US (at the U's of Cornell, Yale, California & the Massachusetts Instit of Technology) & Australia (Australian Nat'l U, & U's of Sydney, Monash, & Queensland). The chief interest of the Indonesian programs of these U's is SE. 1 to 3 yrs' field work is considered a sufficient foundation; this has been criticized by Dutch sociol'ts. However, this inadequacy is compensated for by strict adherence to deductive-quantitative methods & by an emphasis on soc processes rather than static underlying forces. Indonesian soc sci'ts have found it difficult to engage in independent work. The first generation of holders of soc sci chairs at Indonesian U's were trained before the war. A 2nd generation, US trained, began to take over in 1956-60. It has a more pragmatic & practical outlook, but its teaching load leaves it little time for res. Moreover, the present deep-going structural reorg of Indonesian U's burdens it with additional org'al & admin'ive duties. The best hope for an Indonesian soc sci ('Indology') lies in a combination of foreign methods with the contribution from participation in the nat'l cultural heritage. The present conditions are not unfavorable to such a development. A 250-item Biblioa. I. Lanenas.

title: Forum van het boek
authors: Vrijhof,P. H.,   Smits,P.,   Scholten,R. G.,   Goddijn,H.,   Goddijn,W.
abstract: Commentaries are presented by 3 writers on the book SOCIOLOGIE VAN KERK EN GODSDIENST (Sociology of Church and Worship) by H. & W. Goddijn (Utrecht, the Netherlands: Spectrum, 1966). (1) P. H. Vrijhof says that the authors incorporate religious sociol into cultural & epistemological sociol; they fail to study secularization as a S-cul phenomenon; they reduce religious sociol to an inductive-empirical sci; & they unconsciously reflect certain theological views while consciously ignoring theology. (2) P. Smits queries the authors' tendency to reduce religion to soc interaction & their emphasis on the instit'ization of worship. (3) R. G. Scholten objects to the reduction of the analysis of religious worship to the worshipers' participation, to ignoring more diffused forms of worship, & to neglecting the normative functions of theology. I. Langnas.

title: Zoeklicht op 'Peace Research'. Enkele kanttekeningen bij het tweede IPRA-congres (Tällberg, 16-19 juni 1967)
Schoolprestaties en beroepscarrière. Opmerkingen naar aanleiding van het onderzoek van mevrouw H. Verwey-Jonker
abstract: A critique by W. F. van Eekelen of H. Verwey-Jonker's report on a survey designed to establish the relation between Sch achievement & professional career (see SA 1432/D1885). Van Eekelen suggests that the article should be expanded into a PhD dissertation but he voices his disappointment that VerweyJonker's conclusions are not fully justified by the data she presents. He then tackles her 8 conclusions: (1) only parents of the upper income strata can be certain to send their children to HSch's; children of parents of middle & lower income groups are more sharply selected at the end of their elementary educ to go on to secondary educ (this conclusion is not fully justified by the data & is stated in a confusing way). (2) This upper-income 'certainty' of the parents is accepted by the Sch's & by middle & lower income children (quite unsupported by the data). (3) The parents & pupils have a strong preference for better-class jobs (this may be true but is not supported by the data). (4) U studies are more easily available for the young, children of parents in higher-class professions, & graduates of a gymnasium HSch with traditional curriculum (soc criteria prevail largely, though not entirely, & the argument given is unclear). (5) Prognognis is easier for good pupils but a good Sch career is no guarantee of a successful U career (true but tautological). (6) If there is a failure in a chosen U study, a 2nd or 3rd kind of U study may be undertaken (more precise details about 'failure' are needed). (7) Profession during the inquiry tended to be higher than the original profession (this is a true & valuable conclusion but it could be buttressed by more exact res). (8) The HSch is a good stepping stone for a U career but a HSch certificate is in itself valuable in selecting a career (this conclusion is viatiated by the fact that the majority of subjects are employed by the Philips Co, which is a special condition). REPLY, by H. Verwey-Jonker, rejects the suggestions that her survey should be explanded into a PhD dissertation because it represents a reduced version of the original & is based on dated evidence. The 8 specific criticisms are considered separately: (a) Not only do fewer children from Le's go on to a middle Sch, but also fewer children per fam. (b) Not only is it assumed at Sch that it is 'self-evident' that this happens, but the students themselves adopt this view. (c) Professional diff's between fathers & sons point to this conclusion, as well as professional diff's between men & women. (d) Not only do middle Sch's select for U's, but their selection is negative. (e) Criticisms (5), (6), & (7) are invalid because there was not attempt to look for new data. (f) Criticism (8) ignores the fact that an attempt was made to account for fathers who were not so employed. Finally, van Eekelen's suggestions that teachers are most likely to benefit from the survey is rejected; parents are most likely to do so. I. Langnas.

title: Evolution, Development and Progress
abstract: An examination of the changing concepts of evolution, development & progress since 1920. In that yr, J. B. Bury wrote his IDEA OF PROGRESS, which ended an historical account of this idea as an outgrowth of rationalism with the warning that the notion of progress could be turned against itself. The terms evolution, development & progress are examined. Evolution has been defined by biologists as a theory of the origin of species & as a movement from lower to higher forms of life; development, as ontogeny or the emergence of the adult organism out of the germ. Unlike evolution & development, progress cannot be defined in ethically neutral terms. As formulated in the 18th cent, the theory of progress implied a belief in human perfectibility, in the unity of mankind & in a movement towards breaking the barriers between men. The notion of evolution is now criticized, & anthrop'ts talk about 'the downfall of evolutionism'; but this criticism is largely misdirected. The concept of development was redefined in ethical terms in the 192questionaires by L. T. Hobhouse. 2 movements, Marxism & a redefinition of evolutionism to avoid its errors (J. Huxley & J. Needham) have reasserted the idea of progress. It is concluded that: (1) no laws of development or progress have so far been established; (2) important major trends can be discerned (growth of command over natural forces through knowledge; development of morals through clarification of ideals; fuller insights into human needs; tendencies towards universalism & human unity); (3) these various developments have been uneven & unbalanced; & (4) the difficulties & the failures must not blind us to the successes & the possibilities that remain open. I. Langnas.

title: Het priesterambt als een professie? De consequenties van een voorstel
abstract: An examination of the proposal that the Roman Catholic priesthood should become a recognized profession, with special reference to the Netherlands. This proposal was made by G. Schreuder who argues that the SS of the priests would thus be raised from its present lowly position. At present, the priest has no definite professional functions; his professional educ is deficient; he lacks the professional freedom he needs; & he has no professional org. Against this, it is argued that a 'profession' lacks a generally accepted definition, & that pro:- fessionalization may not necessarily lead to a Hs for the priest. He may lose his solid traditional status & acquire one that is very problematic. However, the proposal deserves careful examination, esp in view of the rapidly changing conditions in Dutch Catholicism. I. Langnas.

title: On Introducing Innovations in an Urban Setting
abstract: The introduction of innovation in an Ur setting is considered by examining the introduction of educ'al TV into the schools of Delhi, India. Whereas, innovations are introduced into Ru settings by personal contacts with individuals, a slow & difficult process, they are usually introduced into Ur settings by admin'ive fiats & through instit's. Sch TV was introduced in Delhi in 1961, after some preparation & with the aid of the Ford Foundation. 2 surveys were conducted by the author for its evaluation: (1) in 1962, by over 30 surprise visits to Sch's with observation & interviews; & (2) in 1964-65, by a systematic observation of 24 TV & 24 non-TV Sch's & 4 rounds of comparative tests in physics & chemistry. The results of the tests are not given, but it is noted that 'the 1st & overwhelming impression was that of a project not well received by a surprisingly large N of teachers who were supposed to be aided by it in their classroom teaching,' though this was counter-balanced by other, more favorable reactions. The reasons were: (a) teachers felt they should have been consulted beforehand; (b) the notion of team-work between class & TV teacher was not sustained; & (c) many teachers looked upon the experiment as an intrusion of an outside agency. It is concluded that: (i) the psychol'al preparation of the users is as important in Ur as in Ru projects; (ii) identification as 'ours' or 'theirs' will largely determine success or failure; & (iii) continuing contact between introducing authority & ultimate users is as necessary in Ur as in Ru settings. I. Langnas.

title: Probleemgevoeligheid en onderzoekbeleid in de sociologie
abstract: Problem sensitivity is discussed as a major variable in the development of sociol. 4 phases or types of sensitivity are distinguished: the capacity to see the separate identity of sociol within the broader spectrum of human disciplines; the capacity to distinguish new topics of sociol'al analysis; the capacity to program separate projects into larger wholes; & the capacity to conceive of sociol as a completed whole of integrated knowledge. Problem sensitivity is considered dependent upon a number of external & internal variables. Among the external variables are: soc recognizability of sociol'al problems, degree of gov'al influence on res, external responsibilities of sociol'ts, internat'l prestige of the discipline, & the wider intellectual climate of the epoch. Internal variables include: degree of codification of method, design & theory, neglect of cultural diff's, & degree of professionalization. It is concluded that sociol can only exist in the plural. The sow ciol'st bears a multitude of contemporary roles. Sociol can at best arrive at middle range theories for restricted areas. Problem sensitivity is one of its main varying forces. AA.

title: Similarities and Differences between the Social Problem and the Development Problem
abstract: After a brief survey of the similarities & the diff's between the problem of developing countries & the soc problem, it is concluded that lessons can be drawn for the solution of the former from experience of attempted solutions of the latter. Charity does not work; the victims have to help themselves, by organizing themselves & exerting pol'al pressure aimed at the establishment of an internat'l order which imposes on the world community the duty to raise the financial transfers, the technical assistance & the trade policies needed. Everything will become easier by a restriction in pop growth. AA.

title: Sozialarbeit und soziale Kontrolle. Bemerkungen zu einem umstrittenen Thema
abstract: An examination of 2 competing basic concepts of soc work. The first concept, which is the one most accepted today, views soc work as uncovering-or even discovering-the needs of persons or groups who require assistance with the purpose of filling these needs. The other concept views soc work as a form of soc control of others by the soc worker & is founded upon the realization that the behavior of clients is problematic. Behavior becomes problematic when it becomes deviant. There has been a strong resistance to the concept of soc work defined in terms of soc control, esp from those whose concept of the soc worker is founded upon a 'counselling' Philosophy. None the less, it is gaining ground because it puts the person of the 'poor' before the phenomenon of 'poverty.' I. Langnas.
tags: SOCIAL CONTROL, VS DISCOVERING NEEDS, SOCIAL WORK AS,

title: Illusions and Self Deceptions of Modern Man
abstract: An evaluation of modern man which contests his favorable self-evaluation. (1) Modern man views himself mistakenly as a man of peace, abhorrent of war, & a devotee of the 'ethical affirmation of life.' This view is refuted by the record of recent wars. (2) Modern man is convinced of his mental, moral, soc & creative superiority over the preceding generations. Actually, the superior creativity of modern man is shown in the field of sci & technological invention. In other cultural fields, eg religion, philosophy, ethics, law, psychosoc & humanistic disciplines, arts & literature, his creativity has been massive, but mediocre & largely vulgar; nor has he created a new & great theology, & his creativity in moral & ethical values, ideologies & behavior has been sterile. (3) Modern man believes that he is a free person, a fighter for freedom, liberator of all groups & persons from all forms of unjust limitation & suppression of their liberty & inalienable rights. This claim is belied by total war & totalitarian pol. (4) Modern man suffers from similar self-deceptions in other dimensions of life; he is actually a disharmonious & often schizophrenic bundle of contradictions (coincidentia oppositorum). I. Langnas.

title: Keller's visie op de ontwikkeling der economische elites, getoetst aan enkele Nederlandse gegevens
abstract: S. Keller's confidence in the efficiency of the welfare state (in BEYOND THE RULING CLASS, New York, NY: 1963) is based on the increasing diff'iation of efficient elites which check one another's activity. This variety of elites has, according to Keller, promoted the disappearance of the element of power, which was one of the main features of 19th cent capitalism. Keller also points to the increasing tendency to recruit candidates for the elites freely from all soc strata. It is, on this basis, possible for modern societies to develop into classless societies with a hierarchic stratification based on diff's in ability between the elites & the people led by them. Re the econ elite in the Netherlands, P. Vinke, in DE MAAT- SCHAPPELIJKE PLAATS EN HERKOMST DER DIRECTEU- REN EN COMMISSARISSEN VAN DE OPEN EN DAARMEDE VERGELIJKBARE BESLOTEN NAAMLOZE VENNOOTSCHAP- PEN (The Social Position and Origin of Directors and Managers in Open and Comparable Closed Corporations, Leiden, the Netherlands, 1961), has collected interesting data based on elaborate empirical investigations. Keller's views are checked against Vinke's data re the recruitment & retention of chief e9ecutives of public & private Co's in the Netherlands. It appears that the trend of development as described by Keller in which 'strategic elites are increasingly becoming nonhereditary' has hardly reached completion in the Netherlands. Vinke shows that among more than 66% of the chief executives of the board of directors of public Co's & nearly 75% of the boards of directors of private Co's which he investigated, some fam relationship existed with the founders of the Co's. The signif of fam relationships in the econ top stratum can also be expressed in the following way: 44% of the chief executives of all the Co's included in Vinke's study are related to one or more chief executives in the same Co. If the study is extended to the fam relationships between chief executives of the diff Co's investigated, mutual relationships were found for 70% of the S's. Therefore selection of new chief executives is restricted by certain influences. Modified AA.

title: De agrarisering van de proletarische revolutie
abstract: An examination of the switch which occurred in Communist thinking from K. Marx & F. Engels, who believed that the revolution would start in industr countries with a well-developed proletariat, to the Chinese thesis of Marshal Lin Piao (1965), that it would start in the 'world-village' & take over the 'world-city.' The beginning of the switch is traced to Marx himself, who believed that a revolution in Ireland, the source of cheap labor in England, would help to make the bourgeoisoriented English workers more eager for revolution. V. I. Lenin advocated a policy of smychka (alliance) between workers & peasants; J. Stalin, after advocating it for some time, switched to a belief in the primacy of the proletarian revolution. However, Mao Tse-tung's experiences in the 1920's convinced him that the Chinese revolution would be first successful in the villages & then take over the cities-as did, indeed, happen in 1949. Other advocates of a peasant role in the revolution included N. Bukharin, K. Kautsky, & the Dutch Socialist A. Pannekoek. I. Langnas.

title: De beheersbaarheid van het stedelijk erf
abstract: An examination of the problem of governability of Ur space; first presented in a larger version at the Woudschoten Conference of the Dutch Assoc of Soc Sci Res'ers in 1966. The city is viewed as a public space, in accordance with the view of M. Weber, modified by the German Ur'ologist H. P. Bahrdt & examined in the following 3 aspects: (1) areas of municipal publicness-pol'al power, soc production, consumption activities, & org; (2) modes & levels of functional/rational gov-roles of participant in the public domain, ways of organ forming, hierarchical integration of roles & organs, & management & control through the org; & (3) some functional problems-integration of interests in decisions on local affairs, participation in the administration of municipal public space, productivity of the municipal apparatus, relations between the org & other soc techniques. I. Langnas.

title: Alienation: some Conceptual Developments in Present Day Sociology
abstract: It is contended that alienation (Al) is an overworked concept used to cover anything & everything, & is today being used to avoid coming to grips with the complexities of the behavior of modern man. A review is given of some recent treatments of Al which make the attempt to explore human problems, yet only cloud the issue because they use a 'wrong' frame of reference. Louis Feuer's scathing attack on the abuse of the concept in SOCIOLOGY ON TRIAL is cited as a concurring opinion. A number of books & articles are cited as evidence of the distortion of the concept of Al at the hands of soc sci'ts. The nature & origins of Al are discussed in relation to Hegelian philosophy. K. Marx's Al of the worker is cited as an example. 2 articles by sociol'ts, Melvin Seeman & Marvin B. Scott, are treated. Seeman's article on the basic meanings of Al shows that there is no agreement in sociol as to just what constitutes Al. Scott's article concerns itself with soc conditions which are felt to produce a mental state associated with Al without delving into the inner workings of the psyche, a major error which makes the concept into a catch-all rather than a heuristic concept for understanding the human condition in our time. Erich Fromm's position on Al is considered, & it is alleged that psychoanalysis has been distorted by Fromm to bring it into line with his supposed Marxist precepts. In contrast, Eric Erickson & Norman Brown are felt to have some insightful & valuable thoughts on Al. F. von Pappenheim's THE ALIENATION OF MODERN MAN (see SA A1623) observes that Al is rooted in the soc structure of society, & much more deeply in technological society. Finally, some ideas concerning Al are proposed which show how Marxism & psychoanalysis may together provide a way out of the impasse by opening up a new broad area for theory & res in Al: Al is part & parcel of the human condition. Van must recognize its roots & seek to make them less formidable. The way out of aggravated forms of Al is through the struggle against their self perpetuating instit's, & through educ in the fundamental principles of psychoanalysis, the importance of early childhood training upon character formation, & the self knowledge that comes from recognition of our weaknesses. Modified AA.

title: Schoolprestaties door gezinsopvoeding; verslag van een onderzoek
abstract: This study deals with an investigation in the field of soc inequality of opportunities in educ. The basic assumption reads that the level of scholastic performance/ability is influenced by specific early soc'ization processes in the fam. As soc'ization in early childhood is steered by the parents via interactions between mother, father & child, diff's in Sch performances may be interpreted on the basis of diff's in interactions within the fam's. Parents of all children (N=388) of a primary Sch in the Netherlands were asked to fill out a questionaire about interaction processes in their fam. The questionaire consisted of short descriptions of situations in a fictitious fam. R's were requested to indicate how they would react to these situations in their own cases by means of a multiple-choice technique. The criterion of Sch performance was the quintile position on the scale 'good-bad student' according to the general opinion of the teacher. Factor analysis of the questionaire data produced 2 factors which were interpreted as referring to 2 diff syndromes of interaction in soc'ization, one representing mainly verbal interactions which would stimulate the child's intellectual development (the 'intellectual activity-syndrome'), the other one representing interactions which would support the child in being independent (the 'personalization-syndrome'). The parent's occup'al & educ'al level is highly r'ed with the 1st factor which does not hold for the 2nd factor. Relations of the levels of both 'intellectual activity' & 'personalization' in the fam with the investigated measure of Sch performance were found to be highly signif. An evaluation of the 'personalization syndrome' is included in which reference is made to the Parsonian basic 4-role pattern in early soc'ization in the fam (see SA 3307). AA.

title: De theoretische sociologie van bejaarden en ouderdom. Enkele problemen en mogelijkheden
abstract: 6 theoretical themes of soc gerontology are treated. There exists a good deal of disdain for res in this field because of the uselessness of local applied res for sociol. (1) The aging process is just as important a subject of study as the aged. The aged are not a sociol'al group. Is there a growing group consciousness among them? 6 diff interpretations of being soc'ly old are given & discussed. (2) The soc roles of the aged are analyzed in relation to former cultural periods & former stages in the individual's life. More res is needed on the qualitative aspects of roles. (3) The typology of the aged is a borderline field between sociol & psychol. The central theme is adjustment. Not enough is known about the personality & developmental psychol of the aged. The continuity aspect of an individual's life is often forgotten. (4) The activity- & disengagement-theories are known, but when is what model applicable? The aged of here & now are a specific phenomenon, not necessarily a general one. (5) The aged carry an image, are being stereotyped, possibly discriminated against or segregated. Do they stereotype the younger generations? The image discussed is based on former generations of the aged. (6) The analysis of the relationship of the aged with their children should benefit more from the findings of fam sociol; the study of their relationship with others should not be confined to the geographical area around them. AA.

title: Peace Keeping Forces: Public Opinion, Political Attitudes and Personality Variables
abstract: In the last 20 yrs a relatively large number of studies on polled opinion concerning the idea of a peace force, an internat'l police force, the role of the UN, etc, has been published. The various conclusions arrived at in these studies are surveyed & analyzed on 3 levels: opinion formation, pol'al att's & personality variables. The higher strata of society show themselves more in favor of UN forces than do the lower strata. In particular, level of educ is positively r'ed with favorable opinion. The exceptions are as follows: minority groups tend to be more in favor of a UN force than lower strata traditional groups, & persons who fear loss of protection tend to be less in favor than higher strata groups. Favorable act's toward the idea of a UN force, together with a relatively high level of information, maybe considered a function of personality. 20 statements, including some cautionary devices, are formulated in order to find some directions for use when interpreting findings furnished by the opinion polls. These statements all refer to important theoretical insights in the field of pol'al att's (conservatism, world-mindedness, nat'lism), personality variables (authoritarianism, dogmatism, acquiescence) & their interrelationships. The study was delivered as a lecture at the 2nd Pugwash Internat'l Sum Sch on Arms Control & Disarmament in Pavia, Italy in Jul 1968. Modified AA.

title: Enkele problemen rond de nonresponse
abstract: A discussion of some problems of 'non-response,' defined in terms of units of a sample used in surveys that have to be eliminated because of their insufficient or wholly negative response; it is based on a part of the author's book BIAS TEN- VOLGE VAN NONRESPONSE (Bias Caused by Non-Response, Nijmegen, the Netherlands: Sociol'al Instit, 1968). Non-response causes bias through the systematic absence of signif units from the sample which causes difficulties of control. An example of a survey of the Catholic vote in Nijmegen in 1968 is discussed. Mathematical methods to estimate such bias are presented, & 3 methods of eliminating it are offered: (1) the way factor method of A. Politz & W. Simmons; (2) the replacement method of F. F. Stephan & P. J. McCarthy; & (3) the extrapolation method of S. Reid & R. F. Ferber. I. Langnas.
