title: Typen van sociologisch onderzoek
abstract: The presentation of a proposed typology of sociol'al res. The 2 chief difficulties in establishing a generally accepted typology are: (1) there are serious divisions between individual res'ers as to what constitutes acceptable types; & (2) the dimensions of the proposed types fall short of 'ideal-types.' The following typology is proposed: (A) exploratory-formulating, primarily oriented towards the formulation of theories; (B) exp'al, primarily oriented towards the testing of theories; (C) descriptive, primarily oriented towards the 'individual case.' This typology is compared to other typologies, developed by I. Gadourek, H. Hyman, E. V. W. Vercruijsse, & H. Philipsen. I. Langnas.

title: The functions and dysfunctions of "fashion" in science: a case for the study of social change
abstract: A study of the meaning & importance of 'fashion' in soc sci. There is a good deal of misunderstanding surrounding the term 'fashion' due to lack of a satisfactory soc sci analysis, loose usage, & undue emphasis on negative implications. The essential element in the use of 'fashion' with regard to soc sci is 'changefulness.' The cultural & soc sources of 'fashion' in sci are examined & reduced to: (1) new ideas or concepts; (2) new methods; (3) new access; (4) new recruits; (5) new funds; (6) new professorships & other positions; & (7) 'soc problems' of the time. The dysfunctions of 'fashion' include failure to maintain norms of originality & autonomy; improper distribution of talents, efforts & funds; & a waste of talent, esp young talent. The functions of 'fashion' are stimulation of originality & useful work, & a better morale. The question of creating a 'functional calculus' of fashion is raised. These considerations explain why ambivalence is the patterned response of sci'ts to 'fashion' in sci. Notes on the 'fashionableness' of Med sociol since 1945 are appended. I. Langnas.

title: Doelen en middelen
abstract: A discussion on the relative functions of ends & means, centered on the condition of modern man. One of the diff's between man & other creatures is that he sets himself ends or purposes & devises tools or means to achieve them. In this process, the means are subordinate to the end: the hammer serves to knock in the nail, etc. But the modern development of sci has turned man into a means to an end that is beyond him. From homo faber, Man the Maker, he is turning into homo fabricatus, Man the Made. This process is studied through an analysis of the works of G. Simmel, M. MerleauPonty, B. Williams, M. H. Papworth, H. Plessner, D. J. Boorstin, J. Henry, H. Marcuse, J. P. Sartre, J. Ellul, & Z. Brzezinski. It is concluded that this is the existential problem that modern man must solve. I. Langnas.

title: La famille éducogène.Gezin en sociale aspiraties van kinderen
abstract: A resume is given of the main Amer & European sociol'al writings in the field of soc aspirations of young children. All those areas which concern occup'al choice, choice of the Sch, achievements at Sch, & norms & values are reduced to the concept of 'achievement motivation' (see D. C. McClelland, THE ACHIEVING SOCIETY, SA 0621/B8446). The influence of the fam on this achievement motivation is particularly investigated. It is asserted that a great part of sociol'al res is concerned with the isolated influences of some characteristics of the fam on the achievement motivation of the child, & does not offer an explanation of the many interrelated factors. It is concluded that a kind of ideal type should be constructed which proceeds from the concept of 'la famille educogene' (the educating fam, see J. E. Floud, 'Social Factors in Educational Achievement,' in A. H. Halsey, Ed, ABILITY AND OCCUPA- TIONAL OPPORTUNITY, 1961), a family which provides optimum achievement motivation for its children. This ideal type must include the diff interrelated factors that explain as a whole this aspect of the child's soc'ization. Modified AA.

title: Teach-in als vorm van politieke inspraak. Een eerste poging tot sociologische analyse
abstract: A report on a survey designed to determine the role of the teach-in as a new form of pol'al COMM. It covered 2 teach-ins organized by Erasmus House in Utrecht in Oct & Dec 1967 to rouse PO against municipal plans for the Ur renewal of Utrecht's inner city. It covered 200 out of 230 participants in the 1st teach-in & 137 out of 165 participants in the 2nd. The sample is analyzed according to sex (25% F's as compared to 50% of Utrecht pop; age (48% of 1st, 63% of 2nd between 20 & 39; Utrecht-29.5%); church membership (none: 49.5% & 46%; Utrecht: 20.8%); educ'al level (83.5% & 84.5%; no data on Utrecht); income level (58.5% & 47% above 'soc insurance level'; no data for Utrecht); pol'al parties (no Communists or right-wing Protestant party members). The following conclusions are drawn: (1) both teach-ins were pol'al; (2) they were effective in mobilizing persons of varied opinions; (3) they attracted the attention of the press; (4) they were hardly representative, since the participants were, in many ways, above the Utrecht average. I. Langnas.
tags: TEACHING, -IN AS A FORM OF POLITICAL COMMUNICATION,

title: Het anomiebegrip bij Émile Durkheim
abstract: The concept of anomie has drawn & still continues to draw the attention of sociol'ts of diff fields because of its soc relevance, its practical signif, its theoretical fruitfulness, as a test of methodological position, & finally as a challenge to the historian of sociol & the student of SofK. For these reasons it is felt to be appropriate to return to the original texts in which E. Durkheim discussed the phenomenon & the concept of anomie. In particular, the text concerning anomie in DE LA DIVISION DU TRAVAIL SOCIAL (On the Division of Social Labor, 1893, see SA 0206/B4861) has not received the attention it deserves. This & other Durkheim texts relating to anomie (eg, LA SUICIDE, Suicide) are recapitulated & analyzed. Finally, the importance of the concept of anomie for understanding the sociol of Durkheim is underscored. Modified AA.

title: Beleven en doen op niveau's
abstract: Perception & action, on the basis of individuals & instit's, are linked to a number of dimensions which do not constitute a continuum. Perception & action, meaningful in a situation with definite soc & geographical dimensions, are losing their meaning as the scale of the dimensions changes; eg, if dimensions are growing, originally meaningfully perceptions & actions disappear. It is emphasized, however, that in a new setting with enlarged dimensions, other patterns of perception & action become meaningful. These new patterns are diff from the original ones, & are not part of the same continuum. This phenomenon has practical importance for the or, of instit's & for regional planning. The plainer cannot choose the size of instit'al forms arbitrarily: there is the danger that he might plan in dimensions, either too large or too small, which are not meaningful. Modified AA.

title: Criminologie, strafrechtpleging en criminele politiek
abstract: An integral criminology is urged, extending res not only into criminality as an individual & soc phenomenon but into the instit'ized reactions of society as well. The results should be integrated in a body of practical knowledge which would enable the police, the courts & the prison service to adopt a rational criminal policy. The more this succeeds, the more efficient these instruments of soc control will become. But at the same time the need increases for action-res into the power-structure of the machinery of criminal justice. High priority therefore should be given to res-programs which develop the sociol of criminal law. AA.

title: Zur Integration von Theorie und Forschung in der Soziologie abweichenden Verhaltens. Eine Integrationsstrategie und ihre Anwendung auf die Anomietheorie
abstract: 3 major defects of most theories of deviant behavior are pointed out & the following strategy is proposed to overcome them: (a) The variables a theory of deviant behavior should contain, how these variables could be defined precisely & how they should be related to one another, must be explicated. (b) Theories which have thus been explicated must then be confronted with new or existing empirical res to find out whether they can be accepted or not. (c) Theories which have been explicated & corroborated by empirical data must be analyzed re their logical relevance to one another. This strategy is applied, to some degree, to R. K. Merton's theory on anomie. It is shown that this theory does not clearly specify which variables it contains. The following relevant variables are drawn from it, formulated more precisely & related to each other: (i) goal (a wish which requires at least one other wish by the actor if it is to be realized); (ii) regulatory norm (a wish which serves for the realization of at least one other wish from the viewpoint of the actor); (iii) intensity of goals & norms (the degree to which an actor desires to realize goals or norms); (iv) means (the knowledge which leads to the realization of goals); (v) deviancy (an actor is deviant if a characteristic of his or action or means used by him is not compatible with the expectations of most members of a society or group). The following hypothesis is suggested in the context of this analytical framework: The more intense the goals of a person are: (1) the more intense is the wish to choose deviant means (the more intense are the deviant regulatory norms); (2) the more deviant means will be employed; (3) the less nondeviant means will be used; & (4) the more likelihood exists that deviant activities will be indulged in for the achievement of goals. It is found that, on the basis of this framework, Merton's types of individual adaptation are theoretically irrelevant. Relevant empirical res was used to test & confirm the theoretical framework. The relationship between the present explication of Merton's anomie theory & 2 other theories is explored: (A) Deviant behavior occurs more frequently in the Lc than in the Me. This hypothesis is found to be valid only if those value-combinations which lead to deviant behavior occur more frequently in the Lc than in the Me of a society. Thus, findings may sometimes confirm & sometimes reject traditional class theory. (B) It is shown that D. R. Cressey's theory of embezzlement (OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY. A STUDY IN THE SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY OF EMBEZZLEMENT, no publication information, 1953) logically derives from anomie theory, but has to be extended to be valid. Modified AA.
tags: THEORY, SOCIOLOGY OF DEVIANT BEHAVIOR OF ANOMIE

title: De sociologie van Georges Gurvitch
abstract: In order to make clear the important contribution to realistic sociol'al thinking contained in the sociol of G. Gurvitch, some lines of his teaching are explained & their practical application illustrated. First, attention is given to the dialectical relation between the soc group, formed by the individuals, & the relations between individuals, which Gurvitch stresses in his 'microsociol.' This view makes it possible to combine the holistic approach & the inter-individual one & to see the double aspect of soc regulation: integration of the individuals in the soc whole & harmonization of their contacts, in a synthetic view. Secondly, it is pointed out that Gurvitch's 'depth-sociol' is of a great help in developing a sociol, which takes into account the diff 'layers' with their own determinisms that can be bound in soc reality. This is illustrated in simplifying Gurvitch's scheme of 10 'layers' (couches en profondeur) to 5: the org'al apparatus, the patterns of behavior, the role-sets, the collective att's, the values of society. Finally, attention is given to the effort of Gurvitch to combine the analytical description of details & the view of the totality of soc life by introducing the concept of the 'total soc phenomenon.' The reason that he did not succeed in developing a dialectical sociol, as he wished to, is that his typological method prevented him from developing concepts to express the dynamics of soc reality. AA.

title: De noodzaak van een formule. Kanttekeningen bij het vraagstuk van economie - sociologie - geschiedenis
authors: Holthoon,F. L. van,   Jong,Th P. M. de,   Kastelein,T. J.

title: De aanwezigheid van een ander tijdens interviews
abstract: A report on a study designed to test the results of the presence of a 3rd person at an interview. I. Gadourek suggested that this presence made itself felt in fam situations. In a previous study by the authors, published in Sociologische Gids, 1968, 15, the results suggested that the presence of a 3rd person tended to make women of 17 to 35 talk about their sex life in a more conservative fashion. In the study reported here, the results of the presence of a 3rd person were tested on a fam inquiry based on a nat'l sample of 1,432. A disturbing effect of the presence was noted; & the use of written cards instead of interviews failed to eliminate it. I. Langnas.

title: Proselitering als sociologisch begrip
abstract: The sociol of religion in general & the sociol of missions in particular have hitherto not paid much attention to the phenomenon of proselytization. This phenomenon is interpreted in sociol'al terms; it is conceived as a form of recruitment. In recruitment usually 2 forms of action are involved: (a) efforts to win outsiders for certain positions within a certain soc system (positional incorporation or enstructuration), & (b) efforts to win outsiders for the acceptance of certain values, norms, ideas, beliefs, etc (cultural incorporation: enculturation &/or acculturation). Accordingly, a distinction is proposed between proselytization in a structural & a cultural sense. AA.

title: Outline of a Theory of Occupational Associations
abstract: An attempt has been made to outline an 'exchange' theory of occup'al associations &, thereby, to demonstrate the usefulness of diff approaches to the study of such org's: conflict vs consensus & occup' al vs org' al approach. In particular, it has been tried to develop a simple l-functions-model which meets the current criticism against the Parsonian version of such a model, & to combine it with a typology of occup'at associaLions. Basic independent variables refer to types of occup' al positions & types of occup' a 1 associations, based on the extent of systematized special knowledge which is required of the incumbent of the position. Dependent variables refer to the 1 org' al problems: rise & intensity of coat liets about goat definition, the chance of the members to participate in the decision-making, types of means used for goal attainment, the motivation of members to participate in the org' al processes, & types of sue control of org'a1 behavior. Results of oceup'ul res Lire quoted to illustrate the lyvp's. AA.

title: Verandering in de frequentie van het gemengde huwelijk
abstract: A presentation & an analysis of the changing proportion of marriages between members of diff Christian denominations in the Netherlands after WWII. This proportion was 23. 1% of all marriages in 1946, fell steadily until it reached 19.9% in 1857, then rose again until it reached 23.5% in 1966. This rise is analyzed: it is noted that it is accompanied by a rise in the proportions of marriages between Catholics (39. 2 to 40%) & between non-Church members (11. 3 to 12. 5%) & by rises in an 'indifference index towards mixed marriages' for all main denominations. The overall factor behind the rise of mixed marriages is increased Ur'ization. The reasons behind their fall between 1946 & 1957 are less easy to determine; but increased abandonment of the churches & intensified pressures against mixed marriages played their part. I. Langnas.
tags: NETHERLANDS, FREQUENCY OF MIXED MARRIAGES IN

title: Onbehagen en kritische sociologie
abstract: Discontentment is revealed with technical & advising sociol, where its ultimate goal is the efficiency of the existing system. A critical sociol is needed with these characteristics: (A) problem orientation & consciousness of problems, (B) soc involvement, (C) one based on a conflict-model of society (as against functionalism), (D) reflection on the methodology of the obtaining of sociol'al knowledge, & (E) reflection on society. Critical sociol necessarily means a historical approach; it is an isolated 'new' sociol which could have some dangerous consequences. It is advisable to integrate some approaches of functionalism & empiricism into critical sociol. H. van Den Belt.
tags: Discontentment with a technical & advising sociology & the development & qualities of a critical sociology

title: Afbraak van het opbouwwerk? Een beleidssociologische kritiek
abstract: After a survey of the development of the ideology & org'al elaboration of community org in Holland, the question is posed as to the goals & identity of community org. The most important goals formulated in the last yrs are: the fundamental democratization of society, esp by means of stimulating the pop to participate in the policy-making at diff levels of the admin'ive structure of the country. As community org in Holland is sponsored essentially by the gov, it is shown to be structurally impossible to expect fundamental democratization of semi-gov'al bur'cies, ie the org'al form of community org. Official policy documents & interviews with key persons indicate that community org consists for the most part of material equipment (building, financial support) with no relation at all to questions of fundamental democratization. The conclusion is that community org never can build up an identity around fundamental democratization. This goal presupposes a voluntary org (ie pol'al org) & not a semi-gov'al type of org. Modified AA.

title: Industriële democratie en de stand van de theorie in de organisatiesociologie
abstract: Sociol'ts who occupied themselves with the sociol'al problems of industr democracy could be categorized as either structuralists (emphasizing the relation between function & form, eg, T. Parsons, & A. Etzioni), interactionalists (focusing on att's & COMM, eg, C. Argyris, R. Likert), or relationalists (who find a synthesis between structuralism & interactionalism, eg, J. G. March, H. A. Simon, P. Blau, & G. Homans). On the basis of relationalism a systems theoretical paradigm of an industr org can be developed. From this model a system of hyp's on the relation between flexibility, autonomy & the probability of success of democratization in an org is proposed. AA.
tags: Structuralist, interactionalist, & relationalist models of industrial organization & industrial democracy

title: De legitimeringsgronden van het gezag
abstract: In defining the concept of "authority," it is preferable to state that "the one who has authority has the possibility to exercise authority over a subordinate in authority with whom he has a relation of authority." This concept is related to, but not identical with: influence, exercise of power, dominance, exercise of authority, relation of authority, & leadership, which are also defined. Legitimization of a relation of authority has a soc & a personal component. The abstract notion of a relation of authority is specified in a model which focuses on 2 levels of legitimation: (A) the microlevel which is the level of the dyadic relation of authority, & (B) the mesolevel which is the level of the system of authority. With regard to the grounds to legitimate authority, the typology by M. Weber, T. Parsons (legal, traditional, charismatic, functional) can be mentioned; this typology is commented upon by many authors. AA.
tags: Concepts & definitions of authority & a model of the legitimation of authority

title: Het proces van innovatie en verandering in de organisatie
abstract: There is a tendency in the sociol of org's towards a more dynamic point of view, which has resulted in a lot of psychol'al, sociol'al, & org'al descriptions of processes & phenomena, connected with the problems of change within an org. The necessity of an integrated theory of org'al change can hardly be overemphasized. Such a theory could be named the "org'al dynamics." The 2 forms of change are (A) innovation/renewal (fully non-programmatic decisions), & (B) managing the effects of innovation/renewal (continuous questions of adaptations in subsystems of an org after an innovation); there will be, in any org, a continuous sequence of these 2 forms. Taking this sequence as a base, a 6-step analytical model of the process of innovation can be developed. Such a model throws new light on some questions of structure & functioning of an org (eg, relations with environment, COMM networks, structure of power). AA.
tags: The dynamic view in the sociology of organizations & an integrated theory of organizational change

title: Groei en ontwikkeling van organisaties. Een paradigma
abstract: Growth & transformation theories of org's are of importance because they can shed new light on crucial societal problems, as to what will be the direction of org'al development, the alternatives for actual irrational trends in their development, & chances for success of purposive counter-movements & repressed subcultures to influence their course. Evolutionism therefore, has to be reviewed for its utility to the sociol of org's. 3 current models of growth & transformation are discussed, tentatively called the growth-model, the adaptation-model, & the transformation-model. Systems theory, the theory of bur'cy, & comparative theories of org are characterized as growth-models: change can only be viewed as maximization of their basic character. Open system theory & theories on industr change are mostly connected with an adaptation-model, conceptualizing change as an adaptive process in a changing environment. The transformation model uses a dialectical concept of change. It seems to be most suited to deal with actual societal-org'al problems. Org's are viewed as multibonded pol'al systems, as conglomerates of internal & external parties with diff stakes in the org, maintained together & purposively transforming themselves by means of successive coalitions. The model is elaborated through the concepts of alternating regimes (strategy & structure-dominating parties), & alternative projections of the org'al future formed by the other parties. The analysis of these diff futureprojections of each of the constituent parties, even though they might be latent, will reveal the possible alternative regimes for the org. As the parties differ in their prospective explicitness, they are more or less pol'ly active, influencing the course of action for the org. This can either be taken for granted (& the sociol'al analysis would thus sustain the existing equilibrium or order) or the sociol'st can, through his analysis of latent projections, further the pol'al consciousness of each of the constituent parties, activating the pol'al life of the org & thus promoting org'al development. Modified AA.

title: Openheid en geslotenheid
abstract: The terms "openness" & "closedness" are preferable to "deprivacy/privacy" in treating the relations between individual & society. It may be clarifying to the discussion on this subject to state that both privacy & openness are highly valued in our society, though they are mutually exclusive. This can be shown in the relation between the individual & society throughout history. The concepts of openness & closedness must be complicated by introducing diff'ial openness within diff circles in the same society (eg, individual, fam, village, society). Openness & closedness are complementary in the sense that openness is only feasible if there is a certain closedness towards other circles; closedness towards the environment is a condition for inside-openness. This thesis can be illustrated by recent pol'al events in Holland. AA.
tags: Use of the concepts "openness" & "closedness" in studying the relations between the individual & society

title: Theorie, taxonomie en model in de sociologie
abstract: The gap between sociol'al theory & empirical sociol'al res is emphasized, & a "methodology of theory" is developed. There are 3 main groups of theoretical constructions, viz, theories (systems of propositions), taxonomies (systems of defined notions) & models (isomorphic or analogous with theories or taxonomies). Taxonomies & models are the necessary expedients for the formation of theory; tbey are not open to empirical verification. Empirical res is the verification of theory, ie, propositions; any res presented as such will be a contribution to theory. 3 ways are described in the formation of theory by means of taxonomies & models. H. Van den Belt.
tags: The use of taxonomies & models in the development of theory

title: Armers and Disarmers: A False Dichotomy Reconsidered--Some Tentative Designs
abstract: Professional disarmers & armers, the former being in an 'unnatural' or 'marginal' position, the latter showing an ever growing moral umcertainty confronted with the new logic of modern arms, are opposed both sociol'ly & psychol'ly. 2 theoretical continuums are posed: (A) power needs (ie, value orientation to the goals & means of security policy formation), & (B) conservation criticism (ie, role definitions in respect to the practice of security policy formation). Both professional armers & disarmers find themselves in the power/conservation ends of the continuum; the "ethical disarmers" will find themselves at the needs/criticism end; & the dichotomy armers-disarmers proves to be a false typology of personality. The parts of the continuum where a debate between armers & disarmers could be useful is indicated. AA.
tags: The power/conservation continuum & professional armers & disarmers

title: Het proces van innovatie en verandering in de organisatie
abstract: A reprint of J. J. J. van Dyck's "The Process of Innovation and Change in the Organization," Mens en Maatschappij, 1969, 44, 3, MAY, 233 -- 248 (See 0624/73G0687). An essential part of the article, viz, the scheme of the analytical model of the process of innovation, had been omitted. AA.

title: Plädoyer für eine (auch) zukunftsorientierte Wissenschaftstheorie und Philosophie
abstract: Philosophy before R. Descartes & the Cartesians has been a conservative & conserving discipline. The focus of these philosophies was the 'rationalism of justification;' also modern philosophy carries the trait of guaranteeing the certainty of methods & knowledge of the sci's. A philosophy of justification cannot be a future theories & theoretical constructions, ie, which could be derived from the elaborations of K. Popper's theory of sci: 'rational criticism.' Without a reliable method of projection & prognosis, including a method of prognosis of the development of values, planning for the future of this world will not be possible. Searching for this method, however, may not lead to lower standards of logical levels of the present discussion on the theory of sci. H. Van den Belt.
tags: History & a future-oriented theory of philosophies of justification

title: De "Oud-Gereformeerden"
abstract: The starting point of the article is the well known thesis of M. Weber about the selective affinity between Calvinism & capitalism. Weber supposes a relation between SE activity & the uncertainty about his election & salvation which should characterize the Calvinist. An investigation of the religious worldview of one of the more conservative variants of Dutch Calvinism shows, however, that this relation is not so selfevident as Weber supposes, for the members of the 'Old-Reformed' Calvinist groups are mostly uncertain about their election & very passive in their SE behavior. They do not believe that success in business & society proves one's election. Only the right religious experience can give certainty. A short comparison with another variant of Dutch Calvinism-the 'Reformed' Churches-shows that Calvinists who are more certain about their election are more active in business, society & pol. Members of this variant of Calvinsim org'ed Christian pol'al parties, Sch's, a U & many org's. They struggled for emancipation of their group in the liberal society of the 19th cent. They belong now to the comfortable Me while the 'Old Reformed' remained mostly Lc people. AA.
tags: WEBER, MAX, THEORIES OF CALVINISM & CAPITALISM

title: Onderwijsdoelstellingen en onderwijsstructuren
abstract: The process of restructuring educ'al instit's (viz, the U) is necessarily proceeding slowly & with difficulty, because: (A) goals & expectations are diffuse & implicit, & (B) restructuring the U meams also restructuring society. Soc sci could facilitate the discussions by clearing up the goals & expectations. A typology of educ'al org is possible, in which 2 types of references are contrasted: (1) the professional model focusing on "expertness," with a hierarchical structure, & (2) multi-functionality with a 'multihierarchical' structure. The latter structure is better adapted to the new type of student & will open possibilities for spontaneity, flexibility & creativity. Educ by interdisciplinary projects could be the org'al structure to effectuate the self-determination model of educ. AA.

title: Drie modellen van universitaire organisatie
abstract: There are 3 models of U org: (A) the U as an official hierarchy, which is the model proposed by Dutch Gov'al Committees, (B) the U as a professional org, proposed by reform minded members of the U staff, (C) the U as a cooperation, proposed by reform-minded students. Esp treated are the aspects of democracy & danger of manipulation by active & radical groups in the 3 models, based on the typology of org by P. Blau & J. Scott. Before introducing the cooperation model as the general model of org (which is desirable), carefully evaluated small-scale exp's will be valuable & indispensable to gain experience with this type of org. H. Van Den Belt.
tags: A discussion of the university as an official hierarchy, as a professional organization, & as a cooperation model

title: Soziologie und Planung
abstract: Instead of a blind "religion of progress" (in which progress has no other meaning than technological progress) the value system that is the foundation of planning should be focused on forecasting & diminishing the conflicts, which are the products of technological changes. Indispensible for such a value system is a Utopia (the optimal combination chosen from all prognosed possible combinations). Sociol should play an important role in clarifying both the utopian & the present situation. Planning, understood as changing infrastructure, is at present reacting on present needs. The proposed view of planning does not focus on infrastructure as an answer to needs but on infrastructure as a more or less autonomous soc force that is creating new needs. That is why final goals & final utopia should not be too much elaborated, if planning is to remain flexible & dynamic. Planning, with its core of utopia, must make clear the relation between the utopia with the individual Leitbilder (guiding images) & with pol'al decisions. To answer the questions that planning poses, & to realize planning with people (not for people), sociol has to develop a sociol'al theory & logic of planning. H. Van de Belt.
tags: The role of values in the use of sociology in planning

title: Guerrilla en samenleving
abstract: Every army is influenced by (a) the conflict in which it is engaged (or for which it is preparing itself), (2) the society in which it stands. To illustrate this relation of conflict-army-society, guerilla warfare is viewed as a special form of armed conflict. There are 3 phases of armed conflict: rebellion, guerilla warfare, & regulated conventional warfare. 2 types of armed conflict can be distinguished: the 1st, in which military-strategical goals predominate, & the 2nd in which the military action is a pol'al instrument in attaining ideological goals. The core of analyzing guerilla warfare is the predictability of behavior. Unpredictability is a very important basis of power in an armed conflict; it is this power that sometimes makes the numerically & technologically weakest party in the conflict the superior one. Predictability & a fixed strategy depend upon: (a) the extent & complexity of the army org, (b) the nature, extent & complexity of battle equipment, (c) lack of fanaticism & enthusiasm, & (d) professionalization of staff. Besides the influence on an army of the conflict in which it is engaged, the influence of the society in which it stands is important, esp the relation of the army to the elites of the society. This relation can be one of congruency--concentration of power, wealth & prestige--or one of incongruency, in which case the elites have to protect themselves against the army by means of indoctrination, privileges or physical power (police). Another important influence is the society's definition of the conflict. War can be defined as absolute war, instrumental war, & antagonistic war. An essential variable in this typology is the involvement of the pop, largest in the abslute war, zero in the antagonistic war. In absolute warfare a conscription army is the most efficient instrument; instrumental warfare, such as the wars in Korea & Vietnam, lack motivation from society as a whole & cannot be successful with a conscription army. H. Van de Belt.
tags: An analysis of the quality of guerrilla warfare & its effect on armies engaged in it

title: Verslag van een inhoudsanalyse
abstract: As a means to measure the value of content analysis as a qualitative indicator for the sensationality of papers, the coverage of a famous court case (the case of Hans van Z.) by 12 Mostly nat'l) Dutch papers was ranked by measuring 14 aspects such as: length of article, length of headlines, number of photographs, etc. This score was r'ed (Spearman r) with the sensationality score, which was measured by judging the coverage of 7 selected aspects of the court case by 86 judges (Thurstone's equal appearing interval method). A r of .72 was found, & a new hyp was formulated: "There is a more general concept, attractiveness" (re the accessibility of the article), which is described not only by the style of the article (sensationality), but also by its layout. "Attractiveness" of papers appears to have high r's with circulation (.89/.78). Morning papers are more "attractive" than evening papers. The confessional papers, have a 'role conflict'; as morning papers they have to be "attractive," & as confessional papers they do not want to devote too much attention to sensational/erotic matters. They tend to diminish the sexual/sensational aspects of the court case & find some compensation in the violence/sensational aspects. As the conclusions were drawn ex post facto, they are stated as hyp's. H. Van de Belt.
tags: An evaluation of content analysis as a qualitative indicator of sensationalism in newspapers

title: Succes en cohesie in kleine groepen; een replicatie
abstract: A replication & elaboration of the res by K. Vos & W. Brinkman, Sociologische Gids, 1957, 14, 30 -- 40, in which a positive relation between success & cohesion in volley ball teams was demonstrated to be necessary because in that res there was no attempt to diff'iate objective (ie, the state of the team in the nat'l competition) & subjective success. 4 sets of hyp's are developed: (1) Objective success with satisfaction, attractiveness of the group, personal attraction, & a negative r with a tendency towards mobility. (2) Subjective success (defined as: (a) level of aspiration, (b) level of expectation, & (c) imaginary level of expectation minus objective success) will show the same r with these variables. (3) The more the group perceives the activity as important, the stronger the r's between (1) & (2) will be. (4) Successful teams will search for the cause of success within the team, while unsuccessful teams will search for the cause in the outside world. A postal questionnaire (multiple choice) was sent to 682 volley ball players in 82 teams. Response % was 75.7%. Because of the very diff nature of the items in the hyp's & the possibility of testing some of them both nat'ly & by district, a whole series of procedures was followed (Fisher's X2, Kendall's tau, Gordon's X2, point-bi-serial r, test of diff's between X's, signs test, & Mann-Withney one-sided) in drawing the conclusions. The 2 hyp's on the relation of objective & subjective success & satisfaction, attractiveness of the group, personal attraction & mobility tendency are fully confirmed, though the r's between objective success & the variables was larger than those between subjective success & the variables. Hyp's (3) & (4) were not confirmed. H. Van de Belt.
tags: A replication & elaboration of the research of K. Vos & W. Brinkman on the positive relation between success & cohesion on volley ball teams

title: Uncertainty and Power in Organizations. A Strategic Contingencies' Model of Sub-Unit Functioning
authors: Pennings,J. M.,   Hickson,D. J.,   Hinings,C. R.,   Lee,C. A.,   Schneck,R. E.
abstract: A model of intra-org'al power hyp's that org's as interdept'al systems have a power distribution which is determined by the DofL. Instead of focusing on individuals, the sub-unit is chosen as the unit of analysis. The org'al sub-unit's activities are inherently dependent on those of others & the model predicts that the power of a sub-unit is largely determined by the uncertainty which a sub-unit faces & the effectiveness of its coping with this uncertainty. This coping allows sub-units to provide 'pseudo certainty' for other sub-units, thus giving them a basis for power. In addition it may be possible that the sub-unit's power will also be determined by its degree of centrality (immediacy of its activities for others & pervasiveness of those activities) & by the degree to which sub-unit members are substitutable. Finally a survey on the power literature is given & testable hyp's are developed. AA.

title: Determinanten van 'permissiveness' t.a.v. premaritaal sexueel gedrag. Een secundaire analyse
abstract: Both the underlying rationale & the favoring evidence of a theory by Ira L. Reiss (see SA 1940/C0710), postulating a positive relation between SC & premarital sexual permissiveness (PSP) for `liberals' & a negative one for `conservatives,' are challenged. 2 alternative rationales are presented before retesting the theory by way of a secondary analysis of a Dutch survey based on a sample (N=1,704) representative for the Dutch pop. A 6-item liberalism conservatism scale (in the area of marriage & the fam) & a 3-item PSP scale were constructed, by way of cluster analysis (criterion: p

title: Vrijetijd en vrijetijdsbesteding: analyse en heroriëntatie
abstract: Thinking about leisure & the use of leisure is a mirror of the more or less conscious ideas, visions of society, ways of thinking & cultural systems of the authors on this subject. The vision of leisure changes with the length of the working day (from K. Marx's Utopian society with unlimited leisure time to the vision of leisure as a problem). The definition of leisure nowadays could be characterized as: (A) leisure as a problem, (B) a positive valuation of an active use of leisure, (C) an antithetic way of thinking (eg, use of leisure now/use of leisure in the past, & leisure/working time), & (D) an inclusive way of thinking (eg, as including freedom). A diff approach to leisure & use of leisure time is preferable to avoid these biases. A system of definitions based on the free/not free behavior of a free/not free actor can be developed in which leisure is defined as the behavior of a free actor. Then, leisure behavior can be oblition (abolished) or libetion (liberated). AA.
tags: Views of the definition of leisure & a definition based on the free/not free behavior of a free/not free actor

title: Kanttekening. De maatschappelijke behoefte aan sociologen
Kritische bijdragen
authors: Doorn,J. A. A. van,   Houten,B. C. van
abstract: Pleidooi voor een marktsociologie / J.A.A. van Doorn . - Critische en traditionele theorie / B.C. van Houten

title: Het geboorte-interval in de definiëring van patronen van gezinsopbouw
abstract: Introducing length of birth-intervals & length of open intervals as an item in the pop census will be an important means toward a more efficient short- & long-term prognosis of pop. Length of birth intervals is influenced by: fecundity, sub-fecundity & pregnancy-wastage (all r'ed with age & age at marriage), birth control & number of previous births. It is possible to distinguish 6 types of fam-upbuilding, eg traditional, hedonistic, reactionary, rational I, rational II, & a subfecundity-pattern. In a sample of 384 R's, it appeared that these types, except for the subfecundity pattern, show signif diff's in %'s of: practice of birth control, length of birth intervals, number of children 5 yrs after marriage, number of children wanted, religion & educ of wife. H. Van Den Belt.
tags: factors influencing length of birth interval

title: Enkele beschouwingen over prioriteiten op het gebied van het criminologisch onderzoek
abstract: At the request of the secretary of the Council of Europe, some 80 criminologists presented a report on the role & importance of criminological res for the practice & admin of criminal justice. The field of criminology should be categorized as a dichotomy: (a) fundamental res of a purely sci'fic character, & (b) applied criminological sci. A purely sci'fic criminology (or deviology) defines its subject matter not as crime & law (as the applied form does) but as the problems of soc control & the problems concerning the treatment of the individual who behaved contrary to traditional & soc rules. The modern State has monopolized the admin of criminal justice. Its tasks, forthcoming from this monopoly, are: (1) development of substantive criminal law, (2) org & upkeep of the machinery of criminal justice, (3) org & upkeep of the rules of procedure (adjective criminal law), & (4) crime prevention. It was decided that legislation is not a problem of criminal law, criminology or deviology; however, applied criminology has a key problem in this field by explaining the effects of introducing (or not introducing) the possibility of applying criminal sanctions. It is up to applied criminology to construe a rational steering system that can replace the traditional criteria guiding the police & judicial authorities. Legislation, police-officers & judicial authorities are in need of criminological information about the soc implications in the field of adjective criminal law, since (unlike the legal viewpoint) all action taken as a result of a suspicion may function as a sanction. Applied criminology, borrowing its theoretical concepts & thought-systems from deviology & sociol of law, can best tackle the problems of daily practice in a topical way, the topics of criminal policy being formed by way of a tripartition: (A) Traffic offenses & other offenses of small importance. In practice only information about the offense itself is usually available. It would be useful to expand this information with information about the soc context of certain types of offenses. (B) Serious cases--1 yr imprisonment or more: all relevant information is required: information about the offense itself, information about the soc context of certain types of offenses, information about the soc context of the particular offense & information about the offenders' personality & circumstances. (C) Middle-range cases; this group has to be broken up according to a typology of offenses; for each type of offense criminology & law might work out a scheme of information required. AA.
tags: The role & importance of criminological research for the administration of justice

title: Vormen en doelstellingen van vakbondsaktie
abstract: Sociol has not paid much attention to the problems of trade unions. This is caused by the lack of a general sociol'al theory of trade unions. Before such a theory becomes possible a critical analysis of a number of articles by Dutch sociol'ts (viz, M. van de Vall, G. Kuiper Hzn., P. J. A. ter Hoeven, H. Hoefnagels, H. J. van Zuthem & W. Top) would prove useful. In those articles much attention has been paid to: (1) The external circumstances influencing the Dutch trade unions (growth of wealth, changes of mentality, centralization, bur'ization, changes in societal patterns of the formation of groups). Analyses of the nature & background of general developments in society are lacking. Also, the influences exercised by the trade unions on those developments & their direction are not dealt with. (2) Descriptions of some characteristics of Dutch trade unions--special attention has been paid to the following: relation between members/leaders, type of org, decisional structure, & mechanisms of soc control. In general the usual structure & org of the trade union in Holland is accepted as a datum, without historical or internat'l comparison. Further, all the articles focus on one or some aspects of the trade unions & it is not possible to obtain a coherent picture. (3) Lack of interest in analysis of the "core functions" of the trade unions. The analysis of "core functions" is termed too one-sided (eg, job & worker control), too ideological & too vague. H. Van de Belt.
tags: An analysis of research on Dutch trade unions by Dutch sociologists & shortcomings in such research

title: Rome, Byzantium en de Barbaren. Methodologische kanttekeningen bij de sociologie van de militaire organisatie
Naar een nieuwe sociologie. Een discussiestuk
Naar een nieuwe sociologie. Een discussiestuk
Bijdrage van het actionalisme van A. Touraine tot een organisatietypologie
abstract: "Actionalism," as it is developed by A. Touraine in the SOCIOLOGY OF ACTION (Paris, France: Seuil, 1965) is study of behavior as it is oriented towards goals; it is like functionalism (behavior in a certain system of SR) & structuralism (the search for symbolic structure of behavior). Soc behavior can be analyzed as a dialectical relation of "creation" & "control" by a sujet historique (historical subject). All soc & cultural values & orientations have their origins & explication in those 2 central soc processes. Touraine's typology of org is built upon the tension between goals & means & in the relation between leaders & members in an org. From this double dialectic the following is derived: participation/initiative & integration/revendication. There are 4 levels (or types) of each of these 4 processes: (1) org coercive, (2) org instrumentale, (3) org integrative, & (4) org representative. This typology of org's can be contrasted with another by A. Etzioni (see SA 0508/A7172) concerning alienated involvement, calculative involvement, & moral involvement. In both typologies the org (as a polarity of members & manag) is considered as a necessary entrance into the sociol'al problematic (for Touraine this is the value orientation, for Etzioni the order of soc life). The same soc processes are used as criteria for the typologies (forms of authority with their implications). However, Etzioni thinks the power types are observable while for Touraine his types are only instruments of analysis. Etzioni's types are based upon the simple relation of power-orientedness towards power. Touraine's relation is more complex: actors-org-sujet historique. This introduction of the complex interdependency of participation, revendication, initiative, & integration in the sociol of org's which is the value of Touraine's typology offers some critical remarks: (a) actionalism is formalistic because like functionalism, the cadre of relevance itself, sujet historique, becomes the object of study; (b) the subtle dialectical relations between "creation," "control," "relation," "orienting goals," etc, are lacking in his explanation of industr society; & (c) the sujet historique (labor), as being the only goal of society, gives Touraine's theory some metaphysical aspects. H. van de Belt.
tags: The "actionalism" of A. Touraine & its relation to the typology of organization

title: De C-index. De meting van consensus en behandeling van de "derde" antwoordcategorie
Wissenschaft und Verantwortung. Max Webers Idee rationeler Praxis und die totale Vernunft der politischen Theologie
Militaire sociologie: ter inleiding
abstract: This issue contains a selection of 40 papers which were presented at a conference on "The Perceived Role of the Military" in France in Sep, 1970. In a situation in which there is an ever growing relationship between the military & pol'al thought, an undermining of the traditional ideas of the civilian control of the army & a growing tendency towards a professional army, it becomes clear that the interest in military sociol will grow. The articles by M. D. Feld, R. D. McKinley, R. Kroes, M. Lissate, & R. Nauta were selected because they focus specifically on the relationship between the army & society. Respectively, a comparison of the military profession with other traditional professions, the influence of the professionalization of the army on the civilian-military relationship & pol'al thinking in the army, the association of some specific groups within the Dutch army & some pol'ly right-wing groups during the "pol'al actions" against the Indonesian decolonization movement, the role of the army in Israeli society, & the dualism between the images of military action in society & in the army are presented. H. van de Belt.
tags: Some reasons for the rise of interest in military sociology, some areas of interest in it, & an introduction to a number of articles on the subject

title: Professionalism and politicalization: Notes on the military and civilian control
The Israel defence forces as an agent of socialization and education: a research in role-expansion in a democratic society
Military and pragmatism. Ideology as a phenomen of style
Decolonization and the military: the case of the Netherlands. A study in political reaction
Turk revisited, een veldstudie
abstract: The theories of H. Turk (see SA A2752 & A2690), on the r between instrumental status (I-status) & popularity status (L-status) could be summarized in 2 theses: (1) The r between I- & L-status will be greater, as the involvement of group members with the task of the group is greater. (2) There is a causal relation between instrumental & liking behavior. Surveys on the relation between I- & L-status did not produce consistent results. Since the methodology, level of testing operationalization & specificity of the groups (psychiatric nurses) are open to critical remarks, it is useful to retest Turk's important theories. A postal questionnaire was sent twice to the members of 108 volley ball teams playing in the competition in 1967 -- 68. Both I-status & L-status were measured by rating the judgments by all members of the team on all members of their team. 4 hyp's were derived from Turk's theory: (A) An individual who is strongly involved with a group task will show a higher r between instrumental & liking judgments of the members of his group than an individual with a lower task involvement (individual level). (B) The r between instrumental & liking ranking will be greater (group level). (C) In groups with high mean task involvement there will be more liking for the instrumental leader than in groups with lower mean involvement (group level). (D) In groups with high mean task involvement there will be less liking for the instrumentally less useful group member than in groups with low involvement. The hyp's were tested with Kendall's test of concordance, Wilcoxon's matched pairs signed rank test, the Mann Whitney test, Spearman's coefficient of rank r, & Freund's t-test, depending upon the nature of the material, & the level of testing (individual or group level). It was concluded that Turk's theory, tested on the level of the individual, is not confirmed. The theory is confirmed if the hyp's are tested at the group level. Hyp (C) is confirmed, hyp (D) is not confirmed. There is a reasonable ground to accept Turk's first thesis (r between I- & L-structure is a function of task involvement of a group). By the survey the 2nd thesis by Turk (liking in task groups is determined by instrumental valuation) is supported. H. Van de Belt.
tags: An evaluation of H. Turk's theory of the correlation between instrumental status & popularity status

title: Bij de tweede druk van "Über den Prozess der Zivilisation"
abstract: Über den Prozess der Zivilisation (On the Process of Civilization, Munich, Germany: Francke Verlag, 1969), by Norbert Elias was nearly completely ignored even though the book contains valuable points of view re many of the modern theoretical discussions taking place. Originally, Elias expected his book to become the foundation of an undogmatic, sociol'al theory (empirically grounded) of soc processes & soc development. His sociol is actually an outline of a sociol'al paradigm, the elements of which are evident, though it is worked out systematically: (a) people live as individuals in soc configurations; (2) soc configurations have a processual character (these theses, contrary to M. Weber's paradigm as well as E. Durkheim's, give Elias' model a dynamical character unlike T. Parsons' paradigm); (3) the development of soc configurations is mainly unplanned. This thesis fundamentally relates to the discussion between "the idea of human freedom" & the "idea of causal determinedness" of a soc behavior. (4) Sociol is a soc & mainly unplanned business which also has a processual character. Elias' book further enunciates the way of life of the French court & the court's etiquette; its development from the 13th to the 19th & 20th cent; its relation to the formation of states. These elements are integrated into a sociol'al model with the view that all soc phenomena are not eternal & are not caused by an eternal principle; they arise from a structured process of development, the course of which can be studied in a systematical way. H. van de Belt.
tags: An examination of the theses of Norbert Elias

title: Het Talentenproject, een case-study van de beperkte waardevrijheid van sociaal onderzoek
abstract: This case study aims at illustrating the problematics of the soc responsibility of the res'er & the pol'al consequences of his res. The Talent Project, an extended soc survey, did offer some important insights: (1) In passing from primary to secondary Sch, the loss of pupils is not great (from the Wc). (2) Regional diff's in participation in secondary educ are caused by various soc environments. (3) The financial situation of the fam does not have much influence on the passing from primary to secondary Sch. (4) The advice of the teacher has high predictive value. (5) Changes on the procedure of selection (ie, the 11-plus test) do not show real improvement in the participation in secondary educ of the lower soc strata. From these insights some important consequences for the admin (the bridging of classes, the middle Sch, the information to parents) can be derived. Besides some critical remarks regarding the formation of hyp's & concepts, 3 more fundamental remarks can be made: (a) the concept of "fitness for educ" is used as if the soc environment had little to do with those individuals who attain educ'al recognition, (b) the existing content & structure of secondary educ includes some propositions that can be better satisfied by some soc environments & not others, & (c) the Talent Project focuses on the adaptation to an environment that is considered as given without discussing the structures, the content, & the functionality of the educ'al system. This reveals ideological limitation, which would be without objection if it would be extensively explicated & if biased & dangerous policies based on the res were not the result. H. Van de Belt.
tags: Some comments on the problem of values in an educational survey

title: De discussie over de sociologie   Redactie M. en M.
Sex in Nederland, een poging tot evaluatie
abstract: At the initiative of one of the Dutch magazine's for women, an extensive survey by a number of experts (sexologists & sociol'ts) was undertaken in which res into some of the main sexual subjects re masturbation, premarital intercourse, birth control, homosexuality, & influence of some soc factors on sexual norms & behavior was made. Some doubt is cast on the reliability of some of the figures, ie, those on the visits to prostitutes & extramarital intercourse. The res'ers argue that the only way to approach accuracy is to use verbal interview methods instead of the postal interview. However, it would be possible to estimate the reliability of some of the answers by analyses of the answers. With regard to the presentation & analysis of the answers, 4 critical remarks are possible: (1) It is possible that part of the conclusions are invalid (esp on the questions of sexual behavior) because a non-response (don't know, no answer) was rather high & diff per category. (2) Answers on Reiss-questions (5 answers possible) were presented as one figure (ie, % of the R's who "fully agreed with the item"); this incompleteness is a fundamental error. It is suggested that the complementary % presents the R's with an opposing opinion. (3) A number of conclusions are questionable because the statistical signif was not tested by Reans of X2, but loosely interpreted from the %'s. (4) There has been too little attention paid to the problem of possible spurious r's. COMMENT by G. A. Kooy claims that an attempt at evaluation fails because information on the content is not given. But the publication of sex res in the Netherlands, including analysis & the drawing of conclusions (by the special nature of the cooperation between res'ers & women's magazines), was so much hastened that the study could only be called an interim report. H. Van de Belt.
tags: A critique of a survey on sexual behavior in the Netherlands

title: Gottwerdung und Revolution
abstract: One of the most important motives of philosophical activity is man's striving for deliverance from what S. Freud called "burden of reality" (druck der realitat), especially from need, suffering, guilt, & death. The idea arose that man can transfigure himself by means of magic, or later, of philosophical speculation into a divine "self" entirely different from & absolutely superior to empirical reality. But this kind of salvation does not change the misery of earthly human life. For that reason, the idea mentioned above, has been transformed into the doctrine that empirical man can be transfigured by means of revolution into a kind of semidivine, superhuman being, living in a "nonalienated" society. HA.
tags: philosophical salvation through revolution to "divine" self

title: The future of organized religion : analysis of a taken-for-granted opinion
abstract: If the anti-institutional mood, which became manifest in today's youth but has spread out far beyond these limits over all the contemporary Western society, has accomplished anything it is the growing awareness that Western rationalism has not only produced greater efficiency & affluence but also basic human deprivation. Some balance will come about in the future between rationalism & irrationalism (a balance which will limit the nonrational). This has far reaching implications for religion. Irrationally religious man will then search again for institutional rationality, without however, allowing the latter to overwhelm him. For that reason, those institutions that will govern his religious life, may not carry too many characteristics of bureaucratic efficiency & austere rationality, but they ought to carry, nevertheless, the features characteristic of institutions. It is precisely the Roman Catholic Church that is able to offer such an arrangement. Although an organized religion par excellence, the Roman Catholic Church has always claimed & believed to be a mystery that transcends the individual & his fallibility. If the Roman Church yields to the liberal & radical forces, which base their opinions & plans on emotional desires rather than on a long range vision, it would easily end up, after the initial enthusiasm, being just another multinational corporation--modern, efficient, but meaningless. In contrast to this myopia, the Pope's stubborn refusal to abolish the traditional directives which transcend him & every other individual in this Church, might very well preserve a long range vision. Modified Author's Summary.

title: De empirisch-operationele benadering van vervreemding
abstract: A critical theoretical discussion of studies of alienation shows the need for a theory of the concept. Discussed are studies which take an empirical-operational approach. Characteristic for these studies is the partial view of the term alienation & the lack of definition of its content. The studies of M. Seeman, based on a systematic analysis of the concept, seem to form an exception. He considers alienation as the central theme of sociology. He differentiates the concept from a social-psychological point of view: powerlessness, meaninglessness, lack of norm, solitude from isolation, & self-alienation. The systematic theory of alienation at the base of Seeman's work is the theory of social learning & the theory of the mass-society: social learning would be influenced by a feeling of powerlessness caused by the process of rationalization. Lack of control over & understanding of a situation would contribute to the feeling of powerlessness. Seeman verified his statement through experiments in a hospital & in a reformatory. His experiments do not involve concrete questions. He does not specify the nature of the control, & thus has no explanation for alienation of eg, intellectuals in an environment of determinism. The 5 categories are mostly determined by an emotional condition of the individual without relating systematically the emotions & the social conditions. Consequently there is a tendency to mystification. These weaknesses are the result of his nondialectical method. They show also the influence of the ideology of the bourgeois mass society: man controls his own environment or needs to have the impression that he does. K. Dillman.

title: Onafhankelijkheid en controle
abstract: The history of the Cossacks & the Soviet-Partisans in WWII is given as an illustration of how a central government uses its deserters to form armies to protect their country from foreign invaders, & thus prevent their joining the external forces against their own country, or helping internal dissidents in their attempts at revolt. The Cossacks as well as the partisan communities originated from groups who tried to escape the central government, & in due time changed slowly from small, more or less democratic & egalitarian unities to large, severely disciplined groups with vast hierarchies. The Cossacks evolved into an extra-privileged choice corps, & were used by the tsars to control the rest of the army & the population. The partisans were freed after WWII. S. Andrzejewski (MILITARY ORGANIZATION AND SOCIETY, London, England, 1954), gives the most successful classification of military organizations with a combination of 3 variables: the % of soldiers in the group; the measure of hierarchy in the army; & the cohesion of the army. The Cossacks & the Partisans show a conversion from the Tallensic type ('inarticulate subtribal'), to the Mortazic type ('restricted professional'), a strong hierachically organized, very cohesive, & relatively small unity. Andrzejewski's typology does not consider Satelite relations between army types & the possibility that one type can function within another. D. Ridgway.
tags: government control of Cossacks & Soviet partisans

title: Evolutie en opvoeding
abstract: The environment of the school is localized & standardized to make observation possible during classes. The class selected for study had about 30 children, boys & girls. The school was a 1 year old Catholic school in the suburbs of Nijmegen. The following subjects were selected: religion, geography, & history, the analysis of the relevant schoolbooks, observation during class, & talks with the teacher. The results indicate the need for continued research on a broader base, including more classes & schools, & more culture enriching institutions. D. Ridgway.

title: De invloed van militaire dienst op een aantal houdingen
abstract: H. W. Tromp has stated that, "The main function of military service should not be sought in the strengthening of the defense-potential, but in the adaptability-effect to the system; because that is the direct effect of a few years of military service." Without necessarily agreeing with this statement, one recognizes the conservatism in the thinking of men at the higher levels of the military. Military leaders attempt to carry their anti-Communist viewpoint to the conscriptees. Several hypotheses are posed: those that have been in the military have a more negative attitude towards Communism; & a more positive national disposition; a more positive attitude towards the army; a more negative attitude towards their parents; have less political interest, & are less politically aggressive; are more authoritarian; & are more optimistic about the possibility of an outbreak of war, than those who have not been in the service. A representative sample of Dutch youth from 16 to 25 years old was questioned. The data of 534 M R's were used. The sample was divided into 3 groups: (1) men that still had to go into service, (2) those that had served, & (3) those that did not have to go into service because of exemption or disqualification. The analysis did not support any of the hypotheses. Attitude toward the military appeared more negative than positive. Attitude toward institutional aspects of the army (discipline) & superiors is generally more negative, except that in the category of younger recruits with lower intelligence & SE background there was a change toward a positive direction. As far as the attitude towards the army in a broader sense, the lower-ranked men had less ideological thinking & whatever changes occurred in attitudes were not maintained. Other research regarding attitudes toward the military is cited. 3 Tables. D. Ridgway.
tags: attitudes in & toward the Dutch army

title: Rectificaties
authors: Ende,H. W. van den,   Rossum,W. van

title: Some problems in the concept of the "proletariat"
abstract: 2 common usages of the concept proletariat are explored. The 1st concept is that advocated by David Lockwood & John H. Goldthorpe, & the 2nd, that purported by Marx. Internal inconsistencies in the theory of Lockwood & Goldthorpe include its uncertain theoretical status, inadequate causal modeling, the gradual change of emphasis in their approach, & "the surreptitious introduction of historical assumptions into what is supposedly a purely sociological ideal-type without historical reference by the use of the word 'traditional'." In Marx's view, the proletariat possesses the power of possibility as well as the negation of possibility. "Such a class has the motive, the means, & the necessity to make a revolution." When the 2 theories of the proletariat are compared it can be discerned that Lockwood & Goldthorpe's proletariat is most like Marx's conception of 'estates.' Neither theory projects a definition of the causal chains constituting the proletariat. The utilization of a positivist or an axiomatic solution do not alleviate or clarify the ambiguities inherent in the 2 theories. "Indeed 'meaning,' as in the case of the proletariat, may be a content of the concept which restarts the problem of translation which we were trying to leave behind." J. Grimes.

title: Technologie, organisatie en arbeidsbeleving
abstract: In the empirical search for the motives that play a part in work-experiencing, 3 clearly distinguishable dimensions appear: instrumental, social, & task-intrinsic. A. N. Turner & P. R. Lawrence (INDUSTRIAL JOBS AND THE WORKER, Boston, 1965) maintain that all work in an industrial context has certain distinctions: needed interaction; interaction by choice; variety, autonomy, knowledge & capability, & responsibility. R. Blauner (ALIENATION AND FREEDOM, Chicago, 1964) finds a clear connection between technology & work experiencing, as well as the 4 dimensions of alienation-impotence, insanity, isolation, & self-alienation. Joan Woodward (INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATION: THEORY AND PRACTICE, London, 1965) has arranged production systems in 3 main categories: production by the piece, mass production, & continued production. The more complex the production process, the more routine & predictable the work. A summary of studies concerning the effect of automation on work circumstances (P. Sadler, SOCIAL RESEARCH ON AUTOMATION, London, 1968, p.37), gives the following picture: less need for heavy physical labor; improvement in the cleanliness, physical comfort, & the attractiveness of the surroundings; fewer risks of health & safety; disappearance of the most repetitive work; relations with colleagues & superiors must be more satisfying; a reduction of nervous tension caused by excessive responsibility & the need to stay awake during long periods of inactivity. A. Touraine (L'EVOLUTION DU TRAVAIL OUVRIER AUX USINES RENAULT, [The Evolution of Unskilled Labor in the Renault Factories], Paris, 1955) feels that technology should be more or less the autonomical factor of the cadre between technology, structure, & labor experiencing. The structures & orientations are functions of the purposes of the organization. D. Ridgway.
tags: technology & work experience in industrial organizations

title: Contemporary Soviet Sociology
abstract: Literature concerning the analysis of industrial problems has always been prevalent in the USSR, & more recently, sociology & empirical investigations are gaining recognition. Although there is, to date, no sociological journal, a 2 volume work SOCIOLOGY IN USSR, G. V. Osipov, Ed, Moskva: Mysl', 1965 & 1966, devotes 20 chapters to theory or empirical investigation of work-related problems. Other sources indicate that the thrust of Soviet sociological work concentrates on complex organization & industrial production. Other topics of interest include job mobility, leisure time activities, & invention. Conclusions drawn from this brief survey include: (1) there exist obvious omissions in Soviet sociology re studies of labor organization, bargaining, strikes; (2) to date, the problem of increasing output has been the major concern; (3) the investigation of the leisure activities of employees is a central issue under investigation; (4) the importance of the Soviet-Polish research project SOTSIAL'NYE PROBLEMY TRUDA I PROIZVODSTVA. SOVETSKO-POL'SKOE SRAVNITEL'NOE ISSLEDOVANIE (Social Problems of Work and Production) G. V. Osipov & Ja Szczwpanskij, Eds, Moskva: Musl' & Ksiazka i Wiedza, Varshava, 1969, is emphasized as an important innovation in world sociology. J. Grimes.
tags: Soviet sociology & emphasis on work-related problems

title: Studentenparticipatie en studentenradicalisme. Eerste verslag van een sociologisch onderzoek
abstract: An attempt is made to gain insight into the ideology of left & right wing political activists. These activist elements comprise a small minority of the student population--the left wing consists of about 2% of this population. 23 S's from the ASVA (A Dutch student organization with a left-oriented political ideology), & 14 S's from the OBAS (a Dutch student organization in protest against the politicizing of the ASVA) provided the sample. A control group included 210 students from the general student population of the U of Amsterdam. When questioned about the differences in society, the left-radicals consistently answered in terms of social inequalities, point to the differences in income, education, & class distinction, & differences in power & independence. The right-radicals & the control group, after mentioning differences of income education, & class distinction, fell back to individual, non-commercial differences. The 3 groups were asked to show which of the following had the most power: trustees, professors, staff members, students, technical-administration, ASVA, or industry. The right-radicals thought the trustees had the most authority, immediately followed by the professors. The left-radicals had a strongly different view, indicating that the trustees had the most authority followed by professors & industries. Staff members, students, technical administrators & ASVA had little to very little power. The control group furnished a curious central point, although their views have much in common with the right-radicals. Comparing the power-deprivation & power-increase for the 3 groups, only with the left-radicals is there a power-inflation; with the control group the total power structure is about even; & the right-radicals have a power-decrease, as with their parents. The right-side does not particularly care for naked power, & the left-side has an ambiguous fascination for it--ambiguous, because they do not condone power in other peoples' hands, but their own allies-in-power are hailed. 2 Tables. D. Ridgway.
tags: concept of power in student political radicalism

title: Maten voor de interne consistentie van de Guttmanschaal
abstract: The most well-known measurements of internal consistency of the Guttman scale are reproduction, the chance-reproduction, & Green's index of consistency ("A Method of Scalogram Analysis using Summary Statistics," Psychometrics, 1956, 21, 79 -- 88). J. Loevinger ("The Technique of Homogeneous Tests Compared with some Aspects of 'Scale Analysis' and Factor Analysis," Psychological Bulletin 1948, 45, 507-530) has developed some homogeneous coefficients. It is curious that Greens' index of consistency is more well-known than Loevinger's coefficients, but that could be because Greens' measurements are closer to the original Guttman idea. Green & Loevinger's measurements are basically the same, but differ on the counting of the errors. The probability of the model & the weakening of the demands lead to the question concerning now much more advantageous the cumulative idea in the model is than the common Likert scale. 1 Figure. D. Ridgway.
tags: measuring internal consistency of the Guttman scale

title: Socioloog als structuurvernieuwer
abstract: A. C. Zijderveld (Mens en Maatschappi, "Socioloog en Struktuurven- nieuwer," [Sociology & Structure], 1971, 46, 1/2, Win, 141-148), does not recognize that the narrow-scientific view of science is just as important as the dialectical scientific view. The unity of action is also present in both situations; the unity in the narrow-scientific situation is not transparent. Zijderveld does not recognize the fact that leftists have the right to make the U emphasize dialectical science as the right movement has the right to fight this action. D. Ridgway.
tags: sociologists' right to emphasize dialectical science

title: Cybernetica en Ideologie
abstract: The American mathematician Norbert Wiener first defined cybernetics as the information-transfer in the governing process, which he applied to 'animal & machine' (CYBERNETICS OR CONTROL AND COMMUNICATION IN THE ANIMAL AND THE MACHINE, Paris, 1948, 19). A much later definition by Hermann Schmidt, "Beginn und Aufstieg der Kybernetik" (Beginning and Rise of Cybernetics), VDI-Zeitschrift, 1964, 17, 106, 751, opens new perspectives in the cybernetic view in sociology. The principle of 'feedback' is the most central cybernetic lesson. In 1943 Wiener used the 'feedback' system in designing target-seeking mechanisms in the servicing of anti-aircraft guns. In 1947 he suggested that 'feedback' was essential in biological-individual as well as sociological-collective 'life.' By reinserting into it the results of past performance the activity of a system can be controlled or the system can regulate itself. 2 model ideas play an important part in sociology in the symbolic reconstruction of world & society--mechanism & organism. The first supports the search for general social law moderation, the second has more to do with the dynamic aspects of growth, change, & evolution. Although the structural-functionalism depends formally & materially on system, functional, & structural conception, it can hardly profit from the cybernetic system-&-information theory, nor from the expansion that the analytical & conceptial instrumentation underwent with it. N. Luhmann feels that an important aspect of a sociological system theory is the concept 'handeling', that does not admit the principal separation of praxis & technique. J. Habermas recognizes a system-theoretical concept of target-rational handeling, but the real human-social handeling lies within the unreachable area of subject, free of all objective impertinence. Once given, the dialectics of subject & object repeats itself in the anti-thesis of praxis & technique, interaction & labor, communication & manipulation. The system-theory of of Luhmann appears to be a new form of ideology; while the position of Habermas stays completely unaltered. D. Ridgway.

title: Patterns of rioting in Israel
abstract: An analysis of collective-violent outbursts in Israel, an exception rather than rule, is presented. Through an examination of the various kinds of riots, conclusions concerning the values & prejudices, & social dynamics of Israeli society may be reached. The following observations are discussed: the hooliganistic element is often a stronger participant than the 'official' motivation; extreme ideological & religious fanaticism exists among the people raised in the Shtels; "direct economic rivalry as a motivation of anti-Arab violence" is not an issue; due to the general carnival-like atmosphere of pre-election weeks, various types of rioting occur; Jewish ethnic riots can be categorized into violent riots among clans of different Oriental communities, occasional demonstrations of the socially deprived, & the riots of 1959; the behavior & attitudes of the police. In general, prosecution of offenders is negligible & punishment tends to be lenient. Given the small magnitude of the riots, in short term policy this tendency to avoid facing problems does work. From a longsighted viewpoint, however, this approach may prove a dangerous fallacy. J. Grimes.

title: Kiesstelsel en leider : volgelingrelaties in Ierland
abstract: The political parties in Ireland are Fianna Fail & Fine Gael, in addition to a small Labor Party. The Irish politician's role is thrust upon him by the election-system, so that the politicians of one party are just as competitive with each other as with the opposite party. The majority of the politicians are interested in local politics; they function as intermediators between the voters & the bureaucrats. B. Chubb ("Going about Persecuting Civil Servants: The Role of the Irish Parliamentary Representative," Political Studies, 1963, 11, 3, 272-86) calls them "consumer representatives," "contact men," "message boys," & "hawkers of local interests." Political groupings, based on recruiting with a controlling transactional element are more susceptible to tensions & divisions, than others. Leaders of the larger political groupings are in need of semiprofessional help to solve their communication & management problems; & this brings a potentional weakening in the position of the leaders, & strengthens the transactional element in the recruiting of followers. D. Ridgway.
tags: political leaders & election system in Ireland
