title: Proscription and acceptance of drugs-taking habits in the Netherlands
abstract: In an effort to collect data on illicit drug use in the Netherlands, questions on illicit drugs were combined in a questionnaire along with patterns of medication & consumption of medical drugs. 1,622 R's from 73 Dutch communities were interviewed & given a questionnaire, in their homes. Results suggest: (1) positive attitudes about drugs appear to coincide with positive attitudes about sex, & a greater emphasis on leisure as opposed to work; (2) the drug-user does not fit the stereotype image of the drop-out; (3) individuals from small parental families tend to report more permissive attitudes, more factual knowledge, & more actual use of drugs; (4) no association was evident between drug use & the evaluation of one's youth; (5) no r was found between drug use & indications of oral fixation; & (6) neuroticism shows a slight (but significant) r with drug use. Combined, the evidence points to the fact spreading to the general population, & that a slow trend toward a more lenient perception of the use of drugs is evident. A discussion of the functional aspects of drugs, as well as their future is included. 4 Tables. J. Grimes.
tags: growing acceptance of drug use in the Netherlands

title: De Hongaarse etnografie en het onderzoek van Atány
abstract: Atány lies on the border area in Hungary where the structure of cities & villages characterize the Grote Hongaarse Laagvlakte (The Great Hungarian Lowlands); & is a typical example of a unique structure in which the origins go back to the winter quarters of the half-nomads of the Euro-Asian prairies. The old social structure of fraternities has virtually disappeared because of the rapid changes of the last 20 years, but in 1971 there were still a few brotherhoods to be found in Atány. There is a very strict state's surveillance of the village with the accompanying terror. The well-to-do farmers have been virtually eliminated with long prison sentences for the correction of their uncooperation, confiscations, collectivity of agrarian products, fiscal changes, forced delivery of all agricultural products, & the slavery-like daily labor for the big state's factories. The state of mind of the people has changed--even the homes & gardens are different. Like the fields they are neglected. There is very little left of the old structure that strangers thought was so captivating. D. Ridgway.
tags: Hungarian ethnography & social structure of Atány

title: I. A. Bláha's systeem van sociologie
abstract: Innocenc Arnost Bláha, the founder of the 'Brno School of Sociology,' finished writing his Sociologie in 1958; it was posthumously published by the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences, in 1968. Bláha sees the origin of social phenomena in the social situations: under a shared need (assimilation) people get associated & coordinate their activities. Groups can be identified by their functions, ie the needs of their members which are taken care of collectively (of the association of chess-players, a trade union, etc). Sociology cannot be seen as a science of society since mankind does not form a cultural system, as yet. It is actually the local community or a national group where culture is being perpetuated. These 2 categories thus form the basis of the social pluriform order. The pluriformity is borne out by the variety of social institutions that coexist, in accordance with the principle of "federative functionalism." A nation can be seen as a federation of functions. While a group 'survives' by actively fulfilling its members' needs, the individual acts in a 'moral way' by functioning within the cultural order. 'Freedom' in Blaha's view means to act in harmony with the cultural order (ethical, aesthetic, scientific, linguistic, etc). The central role which is ascribed to 'nation' in this system of sociology can be traced back to Bláha's existential background: a Czech, born in German dominated state (Habsburg dynasty of Austria). AA.

title: Etzioni's synthesis in organization theory: a case of defective construction
abstract: An attempt is made to examine the construction of one organization theory for logical consistency. The exercise is a case study of what is called the structuralist theory of organization contained in 2 books by Amitai Etzioni: A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF COMPLEX ORGANIZATIONS (1961) & MODERN ORGANIZATIONS (1963). The first book tells about the tools Etzioni uses while the second one enables the reader to identify more clearly than reading of the first book would do the conceptual framework within which the tools are used. Specific topics covered include: the theoretical possibilities of the great synthesis; identification of the means of control; the different types of power & zones of involvement, the identification of lower participants (re the intensity of their involvement); alienating creating factors common to organizations; & the explication of Etzioni's alienation generating process. Conceptual differences may arise when opposing views attempt to adjust to the insularity of the system. The approach to conflict may spark this conceptual difference, but on this point there is no doubt where the Structuralists & Etzioni stand. Modified HA.
tags: structuralist theory of organization, Amitai Etyioni

title: Technologie binnen de organisatiesociologie: een literatuurstudie
abstract: An extensive overview of that part within organizational sociology which is concerned with technology is presented. The overview proves that the field is a vague & troublesome one because of a lack of clear definitions & a lack of consistency within & between models. It is only possible to make a crude classification of diversity of technology-approaches: they can be categorized in models which stress: (1) the kind of the product(s); (2) the kind of the (raw) materials; (3) the type of the production process; & (4) specific knowledge regarding one or more of them. This means that implicit definitions or connotations of the concept of technology are divergent to a high degree. On the contrary, global "theories" & hypotheses tend to converge to some extent, comparable with classical typologies. On the other hand, it seems rather unrealistic to describe organizations & also organizational technology along only one basic dimension. A systems theoretical approach has much more plausibility because of 2 advantages: (A) all literature about organizational technology can be reinterpreted from this view, & (B) the concept of technology gets logically a much wider definition & applicability than usually is assumed. AA.

title: Determinanten van seksuele bevrediging en frekwentie van geslachtsverkeer van de gehuwde Nederlandse vrouw
abstract: In connection with the results published by A. C. Kinsey (with W. B. Pomeroy, C. E. Martin, & P. H. Gebhard, SEXUAL BEHAVIOR IN THE HUMAN FEMALE, Philadelphia, 1953), the following factors were selected: (1) age, (2) length of marriage, (3) sexual permissiveness, (4) education, (5) wealth, (6) size of residence, (7) premarital intercourse, (8) sexual instruction, & (9) religiousness. Data given by 635 F's, married or once married, were analyzed. 62% of these women felt they were sexually satisfied, 22% were not completely or not at all, & the rest did not answer. Concerning frequency, 45% felt that having intercourse twice or more per week was adequate, 37% thought less than twice a week was infrequent. Sexual satisfaction was correlated with a young marriage, frequent intercourse, & youth. Wealth, size of residence, premarital sex, & sex education were not related to sexual satisfaction & frequency of intercourse. 1 Table. D. Ridgway.
tags: sexual behavior & satisfaction of married Dutch women

title: Some cautionary notes on sociological research: with special attention to survey studies
abstract: Several critical remarks are made about sociological research, especially survey studies. People's willingness to report or admit certain feelings about themselves is affected by one biasing factor: their assessments as to the social desirability of such feelings or information. This means that the validity of certain sociological measures is called into question, & so is the validity of the findings involving the measures. One of the major reasons that sociological researchers have been unsuccessful in explaining the amount of variance is their failing to recognize the fact that the collection of social scientific data constitutes a social process. The consequences for viewing controlled data collection as a social process are that perfect control (no variables other than those of explicit theoretical & empirical interest) is not possible. The replication of procedures (not to vary anything which makes a systematic difference in peoples responses) is more difficult than is usually acknowledged. Finally then studies which are based on the utilization of procedures which are neither controlled nor replicable will now allow for empirical results that can in some way be added up or built upon. Derek L. Phillips states 2 reasons for doing "research on research," the first one is to discover the sources of error & invalidity so that they can be controlled or eliminated, & secondly to demonstrate the inadequacy of contemporary social science research & the impossibility of bias-free research in situations where human beings collect data from active thinking people like themselves. The sociologist's own views & biases will always intrude to some extent in the selection of his problem & the procedures for collecting data pertaining to that problem. The answer to this problem lies with new theories & new conceptual schemes, & one should look at the world through one's own eyes & not through scientific instruments that frequently cloud vision. P. Tucker.

title: Derek L. Phillips' research to end the research
abstract: The research of D. L. Phillips is examined, with special attention paid to his theories concerning the process of data-collection in sociology. In KNOWLEDGE FROM WHAT? (Rand McNally & Co: Chicago, 1971) Phillips attempts to demonstrate ways in which to improve sociological methodology. His assumptions re the social desirability set are examined, & it is suggested that the researcher should look upon the "interview situation as an experimental setting in which standardized stimuli are administered to the S's." The use of schedules, questionnaires, & various scaling items are encouraged as ways in which to reduce desirability bias. Phillips' frustrations over methodological aspects of sociology are based on an apparent application of the pars pro toto logical fallacy. It is also evident that Phillips work demonstrates egocentrism & subjectivism, clearly symptoms of a personal crisis. J. Grimes.
tags: the sociological work of D. T. Phillips

title: Ideologie en wetenschap: Alvin Gouldner over de crisis in de sociologie
abstract: Sociology is a means to get better insight into the problems of society, & the most eloquent evidence of this is Alvin W. Gouldner's work (see SA 19:7/71F2160), even though controversial & beset with problems, it is of great importance to sociologists. Sociological thinking, according to Gouldner, was inspired by the intellectual confusion as well as the moral disturbance that resulted from the French & Industrial Revolution. Comte, de Tocqueville, & Marx were recognized as the first sociologists. A self-evident axiom for many 20th century sociologists is the separation of scientific insight & moral valuation. If the sociologist can teach one thing, it is to show human actions in a developmental perspective. The present-day standing of sociology is a phase in the development of a still young & chaotic science. Gouldner's work is an excellent stimulation. D. Ridgway.
tags: Alvin Gouldner on the crisis in sociology

title: Traditionalisme en sexualiteit
abstract: In 1968, the weekly Dutch ladies magazine Margriet ordered Attwood Statistics to do a study on 'the attitude of the people to sexuality & the sexual behavior pattern' of the Dutch people between 21 & 65 years. For this research 1,284 people were used of which 585 were M's & 699 were F's. The questions used were in connection with 5 subjects, namely: (1) tolerance towards sexual revelation (telling of 'dirty' jokes), (2) attitude towards self-satisfaction, (3) (dis) belief in romantic love; (4) attitude towards premarital sex; & (5) (un) natural behavior & symptoms. 2 specific factors can be identified, namely, the inclination to give too many injunctions & taboos towards sexual behavior, & the inclination to see the sexual standard as an unchangeable, matter-of-fact, & metaphysical function. Some sexual behavior variables were clearly influenced by background, namely, premarital sex, use of birthcontrol, & talking about sex in the family context. With F's, age is important, while M's thought solidity of the relationship with the partner was important. The liberation of the sexual standard does not necessarily mean that changes can be expected. 8 Tables. D. Ridgway.
tags: Dutch attitudes on sexuality & sexual behavior

title: Demografische ontwikkeling van de Joden in Nederland sinds 1830
abstract: A steady increase is evident about (40,000 in 1795 to 115,000 in 1920), in the Jewish population. After WWI there was a decrease to 112,000 in 1930, without any reasons given. Since 1830-1910 the Jewish population had a stronger increase (over 129%) than the entire Dutch population (over 114%). The strong growth between 1869-1889 was due to the immigration from Poland & Russia. Amsterdam has always been the largest power of attraction for the Jews. The fertility rate in the Jewish population has decreased & there are more childless couples among Jews, 5.5% as against 4.5% for all the Netherlands. Birth control has been accepted by the Jewish population since before 1940, & the birth rate has thus been smaller than the death rate. Intermarriages occur frequently, & the most important explanations are: the small size of Jewish communities & their geographic isolation; a disturbed age structure; the influence of social & psychological structure; contacts from during the war years; & weakened religious involvement in connection with the secular processes. With the high mortality rate & low birthrate, a negative population growth has resulted, but it is certain, that the demographic circumstances after 1945 are more advantageous for a change than before 1940. D. Ridgway.
tags: demographic basis for Jewish population increases in the Netherlands

title: Over onderzoek naar demokratie en politieke participatie: het verschijnsel politieke tevredenheid
abstract: Modern political science research into the level of democracy of a given political system typically has some of the following shortcomings: an operationalization of the concept of democracy in terms of political participation; an explanation of political participation in terms of political efficacy; & a method of scaling that makes any conclusion about the aggregate level of participation rather arbitrary. Some modern research shows that (1) the level of political satisfaction, both with specific output of government & with the more diffuse processes within the political system, is high, (2) the levels of political participation are rather low, & (3) both 1 & 2 may occur at the same time in the same population. More research is needed into the meaning of the phenomenon of political satisfaction. Theories of the "new political economy" (eg A. Downs, R. Curry, & L. Wade) give important thoughts about that meaning. AA.

title: Over de mogelijkheid en de wenselijkheid van een "kritische sociologie"
abstract: The results of sociological research are not the logical consequences of the application of strict standards of scientific inquiry. The reason for this can be ascertained in the dilemma to which sociology, as the science of social reality, is faced. Because sociology is itself a part of social reality it must make a choice to either adjust the object of the inquiry (society) to the established methods of scientific inquiry, or develop a method that comes to terms with the object of inquiry. The first alternative suggests the usual method of sociological inquiry--utilizing positivistic methods. The other choice leads to a dialectical sociology as practiced by the 'School of Frankfort' (Horkheimer, Adorno, Habermas). This last form of sociology is in itself critical. Dialectical sociology, conscious of being a part of society, tries to be the medium by which society is made conscious of its own situation. It reveals to what extent the present situation of society is in line with that which society, given the present possibilities, could be, & to what extent present society is in line with the ideas concerning what society as a hyman reality should be. For the sociologist who wants to uncover the truth about social reality, it should be quite evident that his choice should be that of dialectical sociology. It is in this way that he tells people the truth about their own social life, & he avoids contributing to the process in which the truth about society is hidden from its members. Modified AA.

title: Representatie en demokratie
abstract: The choice between direct or indirect democracy is closely related to the question of presence & representation. Democracy is a form of government where the people can participate, to a degree, in the decision-making process, also in the integral power. The word representation has several meanings, in all of those meanings however one can find the element of "being present." One can distinguish 4 aspects in the representation by people: the symbol, the expectation, the substitution, & the legitimation aspect. In political representation, the symbolic aspect is under pressure, as the politician will represent so many issues that a symbol overburdening overload exists. A politician is expected to represent his voters as well as his party. The aspect of legitimation is the most difficult. The citizen sometimes asserts his influences thereby pushing the representative to the side & limiting his mandate. Although there are problems related to representeation it can not be abrogated. N. Hirschsohn.

title: Ivan Gadourek's criticism to end criticism
abstract: In replying to Ivan Gadourek's article "Derek L. Phillips' Research to End Research" (Mens en Maatschappij, 1972), a comment is made on Gadourek's assumption that the author's frustrating experiences were the sole basis for the attack on social research. In KNOWLEDGE FROM WHAT: THEORIES AND METHODS IN SOCIAL RESEARCH (Chicago: Rand McNally, 1971) the question of whether research really contributed to sociological knowledge was posed. Gadourek takes for granted the several research methods questioned, & states that criticisms are based entirely on personal research although a dozen other studies are referred to. A third element of Gadourek's comments is his inability to recognize & acknowledge the very problematic nature of some of the terms which he utilizes in his remarks. Gadourek, a gifted methodologist, turned to a variety of arguments in defending the possibility of sociology as a an objective science. It was the quality of these arguments that stimulated the reply. N. Hirschohn.

title: Het bepalen van een nulpunt van een attitudeschaal met behulp van de intensiteit van een attitude: kritiek op een methode
abstract: L. Guttman & E. A. Suchman ("Intensity and a Zero Point for Attitude Analysis," American Sociological Review, 1947, 12, 57-67) attempted to find the zero when attempting to measure the intensity of an attitude; often the extremity of an attitude is measured instead of the intensity. The effect of this supposition leads to the prediction of a u-shaped relation between scale scores & intensity scores, & also to the prediction that individuals will react with more intensity the more distant they are from their scale position or their scale score item. It is also hypothesized that the zero-points of scales with predominantly popular items, & those with predominantly unpopular items will differ. The results support these predictions. This model is only valid for the single question technique. 3 Tables, 3 Figures. In KOMMENTAAR OP EEN NULPUNTBEPALING (Comment on the Zero-Decision), P. G. Swanborn states that the ability to distinguish between the percentages of R's with a negative opinion & those with a positive opinion is only useful when the measuring of attitudes is used for the prediction of one certain behavior. 2 Figures. In ANTWOOD (Reply) W. Koomen & H. J. van Daal maintain that it is useful to know the percentages of pros & cons. N. Hirschsohn.
tags: measuring & predicting the intensity of attitudes

title: Kommentaar op een nulpuntbepaling
authors: Swanborn,P. G.,   Koomen,W.,   Daal,H. J. van
abstract: L. Guttman & E. A. Suchman ("Intensity and a Zero Point for Attitude Analysis," American Sociological Review, 1947, 12, 57-67) attempted to find the zero when attempting to measure the intensity of an attitude; often the extremity of an attitude is measured instead of the intensity. The effect of this supposition leads to the prediction of a u-shaped relation between scale scores & intensity scores, & also to the prediction that individuals will react with more intensity the more distant they are from their scale position or their scale score item. It is also hypothesized that the zero-points of scales with predominantly popular items, & those with predominantly unpopular items will differ. The results support these predictions. This model is only valid for the single question technique. 3 Tables, 3 Figures. In KOMMENTAAR OP EEN NULPUNTBEPALING (Comment on the Zero-Decision), P. G. Swanborn states that the ability to distinguish between the percentages of R's with a negative opinion & those with a positive opinion is only useful when the measuring of attitudes is used for the prediction of one certain behavior. 2 Figures. In ANTWOORD (Reply) W. Koomen & H. J. van Daal maintain that it is useful to know the percentages of pros & cons. N. Hirschsohn.

title: Werkoriëntering van filmakademiestudenten
abstract: A study of students in the Nederlandse Filmakademie in Amsterdam is presented. Emphasis is on work orientation, & data were accumulated through verbal interviews & standardized questionnaires with 70 S's. 75% were M's & the average age was 23; the parents of 52% of the students paid for their own schooling, while 24% were dependent on scholarships. 53% came from the UMc, 32% from the Mc, & 18% from the Lc. The most preferred profession was director, with screen writer & assistant director following. Professions in the manufacturing section were the least popular. Most of the students liked to free-lance, & 74% preferred free films to assigned work. TV networks were a popular choice for future employment, & 45% of the R's felt they would be able to find work in the Netherlands upon graduation. 2 Tables. N. Hirschohn.
tags: students & workers in the film production field in the Netherlands

title: Bijdrage tot theorievorming over de 16e- en 17e-eeuwse Europese heksenvervolgingen
abstract: H. R. Trevor-Roper, Robert Mandrou, Alan Macfarlane, & Keith Thomas describe the European persecution of witches in the 16th & 17th centuries. Trevor-Roper is concerned with witchcraft in Europe, the incorporation of these beliefs by educated men into the unorganized peasantry, who consequently became the persecuting forces. Mandrou's primary concern is the change in mentality of the French judges regarding the witchcraft trials. Macfarlane & Thomas analyze the development of the witch performances in Essex & England. Problems encountered in the study of 16th & 17th century witch persecutions include: (1) the scarcity of material & the difficulty in finding & locating the available material; & (2) the formation of theories concerning the Scottish & Continental witch persecutions are in the formulative stages. The differences between mass & local witch persecutions are discussed, as well as the character of the accusation, the presence of the snowball effect when one witch accuses another, witch legislation & jurisdiction, & the number of accused & death penalties per period per area. The similarities & differences between other mass, as well as local, persecutions are explored--for example, the persecution of the Jews. Witch persecutions in general & mass witch persecutions in particular are still a mystery, which can be solved through combined & systematic research. N. Hirschohn.

title: Pretenties en problemen van de sociologie
abstract: Sociology developed with discovery of societies where scientific research could be used, development of research methods, & the rising number of specialists in the field. Similarities of ideology may limit the science of sociology. E. Durkehim warned against the propensity to project the ideal society into sociology. M. Weber warned against the external pressures of politics & government. Can sociology be as precise & systematic as the natural sciences? N. Hirschsohn.

title: The case of the Weathermen: social reaction and radical commitment
abstract: Present analyses of deviant behavior describe, stereotype, stigmatize, & dismiss with triviality behavior no longer motivated by need for external reaction. Much deviancy theory perpetuates reification by accepting an estranged society as normal; transactionalists stress negative labeling of behavior rather than analysis. Analysis of the politically militant US Weathermen suggests deviancy theories are insufficient: the Weathermen (1) were purposely deviant, (2) chose separation & alienation from external society, (3) were committed to a conscious volitional choice of transgressing law & order, & (4) were concerned with goals of the deviant behavior rather than personal identity with the deviancy. Labeling or social reaction theories obfuscate the role of intellectual thought; this blurs roles of belief in & commitment to deviant behavior. The Weatherman's commitment to an extreme deviant position marks direct interplay between beliefs & acts in a situated context. The rise of contemporary political deviancy necessitates reevaluation of theories of deviant behavior. T. Babitsky.

title: Simulatie in verandering
abstract: Simulation models & their changes are discussed. The models are divided in 3 groups: (1) man-machine models, (2) machine models, & (3) man models. Man-machine model dissatisfactions lead to more extensive & expensive possibilities. The machine model--computer simulation--is popular for practical & theoretical research. These models do not give answers to concrete questions or they assume more regularity in the system than really exists. Man-models include 'frame-games' & the 'nexus model', consisting of a framework of empty tables; up to 80 variables can be manipulated & a game-model can originate. 'Nonsimulation games' are designed to ease problems in teaching mathematics & computer languages. Validity of a model is determined by the objective from which the model is designed & used. Simulation models have the ability to predict; not to produce proof. It is necessary for specialists to understand the limitations of model simulation. 1 Figure. N. Hirschsohn.

title: Disciplinaire straffen en militair tuchtrecht
abstract: A military commander has authority to use disciplinary punishment for light offenses. Military discipline law is not analyzed in the social sciences. Psychology & criminology focus on the punished person; disciplinary punishment is seen as an indicator for criminal behavior. Disciplinary rules are one element in a social control system; disciplinary punishment indicates types of rulings & the amount of coercion from higher ranked military personnel. Military sociologists claim this coercion has less influence with present technical military units. Sanction is seen as a way to influence behavior related to leadership. A sociological vision should include that the function of sanctioning is to maintain order. 1 Table. N. Hirschsohn.

title: Naar een kritische wetenschapssociologie
abstract: A situational sketch of the sociology of science betrays a onesided emphasis on science as an autonomous system at the expense of present, more urgent problems in relation to the position & the effects of science in society. An attempt has been made at a systematic approach to a sociology of science that is aware of its social responsibility. Scientific knowledge, the scientists, & the social organization of science are successively being discussed, each from the following points of view: as autonomous system, as object of social influence, & as agent of social effects. The following aspects may be considered to be the leitmotivs: the relation between scientific work & political action, the need for democratization & distribution of scientific information, & the personal responsibility of the scientist. AA.
tags: autonomous system of science & its social responsibility

title: De krisis in de sociale wetenschap: het probleem der vooronderstellingen
abstract: The crisis in social science originates in epistemology as well as in SofK, & can be called the problem of presuppositions. The epistemological character of the crisis manifests itself by the fact that scientific thought itself had become problematic. The sociological aspect shows itself by the incompatibility between the social role the sociologist wants to fulfill on one side, & the methodological possibilities of prevailing paradigmata on the other. 3 groups of presuppositions can be distinguished in social science, corresponding to the main directions of the philosophical tradition, namely social metaphysics, theory of knowledge, & theory of value. Social metaphysics offers a diversity of assumptions which are categorical distinctions within social processes. Social epistemology shows that perception can be taken as an empirical foundation of social thought. But social action can also afford a foundation & so can the logical resources of natural & artificial language systems. Values manifest themselves as the aims of social thought. The aims of traditional theory center on the conditions of human communication & reliable information. Critical theory is concerned with ethical problems in relation to social science & especially with emancipatory processes. Interpretative theory is an elaboration of the quest for self-knowledge in respect to social events. The diversity of these presuppositions makes a social theory of knowledge necessary, which can show the interrelations between them & can serve as a foundation of social thought. The possibility of resolving the current crisis of social science depends on the elaboration of such a theory. Modified AA.

title: Studentenaktivisme in Nederland en in de Verenigde Staten
abstract: The causes & reactions to student protest are found in value conflict. As discrepancies increase between home-centered values & U-centered values, evidence of a strongly oppositional student culture rises. US activists generally come from a higher, intellectual & the Dutch from a lower, labor class. US activists are politically involved in "Students for a Democratic Society" & "Young Democrats" & come from nonreligious or Jewish families rather than Protestant & Catholic backgrounds. In Holland, the left & right activists are overrepresented in religious groups. US & Dutch students view the U as impersonal & feel alienated & dissatisfied. The accent on structural factors of U's & cultural backgrounds of the students helps interpret student unrest & activism on campus. D. Ridgway.
tags: review of literature on student activism in the Netherlands & US

title: Nieuwe ontwikkelingen in de socialisatie-theorie
abstract: E. Durkheim considered education the method through which man is changed from a biological to a cultural-social creature. T. Parsons continued this thesis with S. Freud's theories & viewed the individual anticipating possible-probable reactions of others in a social situation. Emphasizing role attitudes of individuals, he developed a role-expectation-sanction system. Dennis Wrong questioned the possibility of social order & oversocialized conceptions of man seeking acceptance & status from others. Wrong claimed sociologists approached S. Freud's super-ego concept never separating it from the Freudian Id. The question of active role interpretation, role definitions, role interpretations, & the authenticity of the individual exists in the identity theorem. E. Goffman in ENCOUNTERS, (Indianapolis, Ind, 1966), sees large areas between poles of overattachment & alienation; in both extremes interaction is impossible. J. Habermas ("Theses zur Theorie der Sozialisation" [Thesis on the Theory of Socialization] Vorlesungsmanuskript, [Lecture Notes, 1968), views socialization as a system with self-regulatory mechanism; the differences between role norms & behaviors determine role conformity; roles are directed by rules. The Habermas & Goffman concepts enable sociologists to include system coercion & individual autonomy in 1 concept. D. Ridgway.

title: A typology of value orientations
abstract: Sociological work on values falls into 1 or more of the following areas: conceptual clarification; construction of fields or categories of values; empirical identification of values among selected populations; correlation of values with other variables; discussion on the relevance of a sociologist's social values to his scientific work; the sociologist's role in social policy & social action. Focus is on the construction of a typology of value-orientations. 3 theoretical assumptions structure the field of the typology: (1) As value orientations are conceptions of the desirable within the total area of social action & relations, the 4 Parsonian functional categories of integration, pattern maintenance adaptation, & goal achievement are used as a first & horizontal differentiation of this area. (2) A vertical division of each of the 4 horizontal subareas is achieved on the assumption that social engagement allows for the differentiation of 4 dimensions: social time, social space, social movement, & social involvement. (3) Value orientations are conceived as dichotomous choices. A paradigm locates 16 dichotomies & 32 unitary value orientations within the field, derived by the logical intersection of the 4 functional or problem complexes (IPAG) & the 4 dimensions of social engagement. The 32 unitary value orientations are defined. The developed typology should be applied in empirical identification & measurement of value orientations through the use of value statements to which individuals must react. Modified AA.

title: Besprekingsartikel: H.J.M. Hermans, Prestatiemotief en faalangst
Symbolisch interaktionisme. Een overzicht en een poging tot evaluatie
Sociologen over doodsproblematiek: een literatuuroverzicht
authors: Eynden,T. van den,   Kabel,M.,   Peters,J.,   Sloot,Jan B.
abstract: English, French, German, & Dutch language studies are researched about death. A review of sociological studies & the most important philosophical, theological, psychological, & psychiatric studies about death are presented & inventoried. The disruptive results of death are summarized under 3 headings: the social vacuum, the corpse, & the contradictory demands of taking leave of the departed while maintaining a living memory of him. In our society these disruptive elements are successfully channeled via bureaucratic principles. This rationalization of death, while appreciatively reducing the social disruptiveness, strengthens the disruptive effect for the individual. The reality of death as an acknowledged social phenomenon is minimized by the supporters of the "repression thesis." The opposition to this point of view deals with death as a discernable factor with undeniable social consequences. T. Parsons (1967) rejected out of hand that modern society represses death & dying, but later (1972) admitted to "denial" as a form of apathy. The contributions of psychology to the social comprehension of death are presented under 4 headings: view toward death & awareness of death, the stance taken in regard to death, fear of death, & belief in a life after death. Attention is paid to death as dealt with by practitioners of medicine, nursing & pastoral care (especially as to guidance of the dying). Studies of funeral & mourning practices are systematically presented. The sociology of dying has generally not progressed beyond the forming of hypotheses. Modified AA.

title: The sociology of deviance in the United States: a critical appraisal
De theorie en methodologie van de problemen, toegelicht aan de hand van de theoretische problemen van de sociologie
abstract: The following schema relative to scientific discovery was proposed by K. R. Popper (Objective Knowledge, an Evolutionary Approach, London, 1972): problems generate scientific theories that attempt to solve them; theories give rise to experiments that falsify them; this in turn generates new problems, etc. They are investigated here from a critical standpoint. A formal-logical theory of problems is proposed that should help in formulating & handling scientific problems. Methodological rules, principles, & recommendations are derived from the theory, & illustrated by means of problems taken from the field of sociology. The theory of problems has a critical aspect as well as a constructive one. It can be used to eliminate unscientific practices as well as to criticize the practices of a particular science at a particular time & place. This is what should be done for the particular case of Dutch sociology today. One branch of it remains faithful to the old tradition of empirical research, & can be criticized for dealing with problems that are too fragmented, & for not paying enough attention to general theories that have a high information content. The other tendency is in the direction of a social philosophy, where rambling & the failure to define problems adequately seem to be prevalent. A. Orianne.
tags: formal-logical approach, sociology, criticism, objective knowledge

title: An approach to the problem of systematic measurement error in survey research
abstract: A solution to the problem of measurement error is introduced. It is agreed that most research is oversimplistic in assuming perfect measurements. The solution that consists in using partial correlations is shown to be only occasionally successful. Typically, multiple indicators are needed, & once there are at least as many known as unknown r coefficients, all path coefficients can be estimated. Tests of the global theory can be carried out, once there are more knowns than unknowns. It is pointed out that, although the procedure has been explained in terms of r coefficients & path coefficients, this is unlikely to be the best procedure when making comparisons between populations or when overidentified systems are dealt with. 5 Model Diagrams. A. Orianne.
tags: multiple indicators, path coefficients, cross-population comparisons

title: Die studentische Mitbestimmung im Licht der Integrations- und der Produktionsfunktion der Universität
abstract: The U is seen from the standpoint of an open system, which is decisively influenced by the environment & internal power structures. In regard to production, the U makes wide use of the mechanism of exchange to reach its goals, whereas integration is a means whereby the U seeks to extend its influence & increase its potential. The facts about student participation in decision making in the U are taken from a study of a Belgian U from 1969 to 1973, which consisted largely of research of official documentation & interviews. In 1968, it was determined to give students the right to greater participation in U affairs. The implementation of this, however, was left up to the respective departments. Participation took on various forms: (1) co-option, where students were given not only more say, but also more administrative duties, (2) conditional participation, where students were represented on decision-making bodies, but not proportionally, & (3) formal integration, which generally involved representation in name only. It was found that there was a positive r between the importance of the exchange function & student participation in specific departments. It is not true that student participation can always be equated with democracy. Formal integration may, in fact, involve the opposite, in that it is a device that ultimately is designed to discourage participation. Even in the case of co-option, the delegation of some power to the students may have the function of giving new legitimacy to the powers that be. Whether student participation will lead to democratization is something that must be determined individually in each case. P. Tiersma.
tags: production, integration functions, input forms, co-option, democratization

title: Over de legitimiteit van het hedendaagse politie-optreden
abstract: The police have received little attention in the Dutch sociological literature. Examined is the relationship of police & the public in a changing Dutch society. The information is taken largely from the personal experience of police officers. The legitimacy of the police is based primarily on political organizations. Its authority was greatly weakened in the 1960s, however, & its task was further complicated by the citizenry becoming less willing to cooperate in enforcing laws. Despite the public lessening of confidence, the police still have at their domain the power to violently carry out the stipulations of the law, although this leads to further erosion of legitimacy in the view of the public. One means the police have at their disposal to increase their public acceptance is the exchange of services for public respect. In return for protection & other services the police can render, the citizens increase their acceptance of & cooperation with the police. The police have gained a measure of public support by forming a certain constituency, an "ingroup," contrasted to an "outgroup," & have tried to make themselves independent of political authority. P. Tiersma.
tags: Dutch police, legitimacy, political organizations, citizenry cooperation, enforcement, public respect, support, in-group formation

title: Padanalyse : uitgangspunten en basisbegrippen
abstract: Path analysis allows propositions to be represented in context by means of a formal model, which makes possible testing of its various aspects. The technique was developed for genetics by Wright & Li & was made applicable to the social sciences by Boudon & Blalock. It is assumed that variables are all measured on ratio or interval level, that the connections are linear & monocausal, & that there are no interaction effects. remainder variables of endogen variables are assumed not to be correlated to exogene variables. Using these assumptions, the theory & technique are explained. Complications such as those having to do with 2-sided causality & the problematics of unmeasured variables are discussed, & the Blalock procedure (partial r analysis) is compared to path analysis whose advantages offer the opportunity to measure the strength of diverse influences, as well as indirect effects. P. Tiersma.

title: Traditionalisme in de sportwereld
abstract: For years the Olympic movement has resisted attempts to change the rule allowing only amateurs to participate in the games. This is in the face of increasing difficulties for the participants to prepare for the fierce competition & at the same time engage in their work, study, etc. The most important organization opposing the change is the International Olympic Committee, which is a conservative, independent body of dignitaries. The 1st amateur rule dates from England in 1939, where it was imposed on participants of the Henley regatta. Its origins lie in the fact that sports were previously something engaged in by "gentlemen," & the rule of amateurism excluded the LC, who could not afford the time to participate if there were no monetary rewards involved. This was similarly the case in The Netherlands, where in 1895, some 96% of the soccer players were from the UC. When professional sports increased in number, the amateur rule served to keep certain of the competitions more exclusive. By means of the same rule, the members of the International Olympic Committee, almost all from the UC, have managed to retain the "honor" involved in the gentleman's participation in sport. P. Tiersma.

title: Kommentaar op Jouberts 'Typology of value orientations'
abstract: D. Joubert in "a typology of value orientations" (Mens en Maatschappij, 48, 268-280), makes the distinction between value orientations & attitudes. Therefore it is disturbing that he uses attitudes to define many of his value orientations. Certain categories, such as social room (territory) contain many, diverse phenomena. Joubert is also unclear as to what the exact criteria are for evaluating the typology. Serious difficulties of interpretation will be encountered in the application of the typology. P. Tiersma.

title: Economische sociologie of sociologische economie? De betekenis van de ruiltheoretische sociologie voor de neoklassieke economie; een interdisciplinaire werkelijkheidsconceptie
abstract: Human activity is the subject of investigation of both economics & sociology, although from different perspectives. Within sociology there is a movement which synthesizes these 2 fields, known as trade theory & represented mainly by G. Homans & P. Blau. Their theory is based on the same concept of reality as that of neoclassical economics. Homans was influenced by Pareto, who distinguished rational human behavior (economics) & irrational behavior (sociology). Social behavior is explained on the basis of hedonism (satisfaction is provided for by trade), rationalism (which controls trade), & atomism (individualism determines social behavior.) Prices in an economic situation fulfill the same role as norms in a social context. Power & income differences may, but do not necessarily have to lead to conflicts in the system; more often they are the result of change. This interdisciplinary approach is illustrated on the basis of a social & economic phenomenon--inflation. Further work still needs to be done in the area of change, which has not been defined very well within this theory. P. Tiersma.
tags: Trade theory of human activity in sociology & economics

title: De dimensies van het sociale denken
abstract: Dimensions in social thought are mutually incommensurable aspects of scientific thought. They are founded in normative attitudes towards cognitive structures. Most people think of scientific thought in terms of oppositions, restricting themselves to one dimension: scientific-unscientific, Marxist-bourgeois, romantic-classicistic. If these oppositions are analyzed a logical space of 3 dimensions can be constructed. The 1st dimension is directed towards intersubjective validity: the abstract structures of mathematical models illustrate the direction of growing developments in this sense. The 2nd dimension is a tendency towards decentration: cognitive structures are progressively disclosed as a result of a social learning process. The boundaries of our theories are the boundaries of our world & the world becomes larger. The 3rd dimension is a tendency towards creativity: cognitive structures are increasingly related to a meaning system which is socially developed & which can be distinct from the factual world, although not unrelated. Any scholar can be situated in this logical space of a topological nature, indicating the conditions under which scientific work is done from the point of view of a social epistemology. 1 Figure. AA.
tags: cognitive structures vs normative attitudes, intersubjective validity, decentration tendency, creativity aspects

title: Een systeemtheoretisch paradigma van een sociaal interaktienetwerk. Een verkenning op het gebied van de kwalitatieve systeemdynamika
abstract: Recent developments in information theory, cybernetics & general systems theory have inspired theoreticians in behavioral science to translate the general concepts into a language of social-behavioral relevance & to move to a process-oriented kind of social theory. However, the best examples of such endeavors, although well developed in the axiomatic sense, have not yet been formalized. The social scientist in the field however, will only be able to put the newer theories to the test if all the basic concepts & their significance in the context of a social process are well defined. The aim here is to present a paradigm--a set of related concepts--& to also take, on the issue of the concept of "utility" or "value," the form of a theoretical model. According to this model the value of an input is a function of the degree in which various interaction cycles to which the input components refer, sustain or impede each others' completion. 7 Figures, 1 Diagram. AA.
tags: input value vs various cycles completion smoothness

title: The counter culture on the move. A field study of youth tourists in Amsterdam
abstract: A field study of the "counter culture" tourists in Amsterdam was conducted during Summer, 1971. General characteristics about this group are examined from 5 theoretical perspectives. The primary data were derived from 3 major sources; an interview-survey, a participant-observation study, & a consumer-oriented research project. Secondary material came from project workers, reports, & first/second-hand knowledge. The population was predominantly from Germany & the US, with trickles from other European nations. The age range of R's was 19-25, with a SES higher than the general population. Most attended schools. This group is classified as "alternative" or deviant, marked by their negation of established institutions. Interpretations of the group's lifestyle are derived through sociocultural, recreational, psychosocial, problem-oriented, & deviance perspectives. Each views the social organization of the group. Certain characteristics of the country & its history, in addition to the popular political philosophies of the 1960's, are examined. D. McGuire.
tags: alternative vs deviant classifications, life style vs sociocultural, psychosocial, recreational, problem-oriented, deviance perspectives

title: De nieuwe visie op de wetenschap. Een overzicht
abstract: For many years logical empiricism dominated the philosophy of science. Recently this has begun to change, major proponents of the newer vision being T. Kuhn, M. Polanyi, J. Ziman, & W. De Groot. Science is seen not as a system of statements, but rather as a "skillful knowing." There have always been a large number of presuppositions in science, which cannot be articulated & which originated from certain experiences or were taken over implicitly from other scientists. A scientific paradigm is defended according to accepted norms & thus is virtually impenetrable as long as those norms are maintained. The autonomy of a theory is strengthened by the separation of observation & meaning. It is therefore necessary to develop a new theory before the old one can be refuted. The fact that each theory has its own set of facts to support it means that differing theories generally cannot be compared to each other. Whether changes in theories constitute progress is a debated issue. Skeptics such as P. Feyerabend maintain that no progress is made. Kuhn, Ziman, Polanyi, & De Groot take the elitist position, which states that progress can only be judged & evaluated from within the scientific community itself. A 3rd group, called demarcationists, say that is is possible to evaluate scientific progress from without. P. Tiersma.
tags: traditional logical empiricism vs T. Kuhn, M. Polanyi, J. Ziman, W. De Groot, paradigm vs accepted norms defense, theory development, demarcationists

title: The sociology of organizations. Some problems emerging from research in shipbuilding
abstract: An industrial organization is based upon contracts of employment. Such contracts are suprisingly indeterminate & processes of negotiation develop around them as employers & employees attempt to exercise control & secure order within the on-going organization. Negotiation takes place both within industrial relations channels & in daily interaction, & is concerned both with the regulation of levels of effort & pay, & with the allocation of tasks & responsibilities. The strategies adopted by different groups of actors & the ends they pursue can only be understood by taking account of their orientations to work (which are influenced by both work & nonwork factors & experiences); & many of their conditions of action are determined by the nature of the context & environment within which the organization exists, for example the labor & product markets. Thus in analyzing the changing pattern of SR in an English shipyard, aspects of the approaches of industrial relations & the theory of organizations could be usefully combined; it was essential to consider the social & economic environment; & an attempt was made not to reify the organization while recognizing the systemic nature of SR within it. AA.
tags: employment contracts, negotiations, actors' ends, strategies vs work orientations, industrial relations approaches

title: De daling van de huwelijksleeftijd. Enkele opmerkingen naar aanleiding van 'Huwelijksleeftijd in Nederland', onder redactie van H.J. Heeren
abstract: Critical comments are presented on a collection of articles, "Huwelijksleeftijd in Nederland" [Marriage Age in the Netherlands], (see SA 1837/I1260 & I1269). The most important of these essays is an analysis of an investigation made by the sociological Instit of the U of Utrecht in 1969. Women married in 1958, 1963, & 1968 were asked questions about the premarital period (the N & length of various relationships), conception of marriage, & circumstances at the time of marriage. The goal was to determine factors which influence marriage & to explain the declining marriage age. Data indicated that the majority of the women who married in 1968 agreed with statements centered on the man's ability to financially support the couple. However, no significant relationship was discovered between the expansion of employment & increase in income & the decline in marriage age. These economic changes have made it easier to marry at an early age, & have also resulted in a greater participation by young people in higher education, & a sharper division between working & living environments. This may have caused an increasing need to form an independent life-style. In Een antwoord aan Corpeleijn (A Response to Corpeleijn), B. W. Frijling claims that much of Corpeleijn's criticism derives from the fact that the original data concerning the marriage age were collected as part of a project to investigate the birth pattern. The premarital phase was covered exhaustively & presented some insight into the marriage age. Corpeleijn's criticism that there was too little emphasis on SE factors may well be valid, a weakness that can be attributed to research undertaken for another purpose. Modified AA.
tags: decline explanation, women interviews, premarital circumstances, work vs living environments gap, Corpeleijn's criticism

title: Van theoretische oriëntaties naar verklarende theorieën
abstract: If the goal of empirical-theoretical science is to formulate true & informative theories, the preoccupation with analyzing & comparing theoretical orientations in contemporary theoretical sociology is to be seen as a prelude to the construction of testable theories. Theoretical orientations such as symbolic interactionism, behavioral sociology, functionalism, or historical materialism may appear to be more or less fruitful starting points for theory construction, but they are not falsifiable themselves. Presented here is an examination of how theoretical orientations can be elaborated into explanatory theories. Since theoretical orientations consist for a large part of orienting statements, their logical structure is analyzed as being partially specified (& hence not falsifiable) statements. In sociology, orienting statements are usually treated in 2 ways: one can look for the background assumptions implied, or one can elaborate them into testable hypotheses. The 2nd way is recommended because it increases criticizability & therefore contributes to the growth of knowledge. There are 2 strategies for the elaboration of theoretical orientations into explanatory theories. The 1st starts from one orientation & results in different theories. The use of this strategy is shown by sketching the elaboration of symbolic interactionism by W. P. Archibald, of behavioral sociology by K. D. Opp, of functionalism by H. G. Schutte, & of historical materialism. AA.
tags: statements vs logical structure, elaboration strategies

title: Political Efficacy, Satisfaction, and Participation
abstract: Testing the relationship between satisfaction & political participation points to the importance of not considering satisfaction alone, but rather examining it in connection with other relevant variables, particularly political efficacy. Voting & party activity were analyzed from a stratified random sampling, interviewing 1,747 persons. Satisfaction & efficacy have been shown to be positively related to participation, however concerning the level of participation, satisfaction was shown to be important in determining the manner of participation. Certain methodological distinctions need to be made for further measurement. 2 Tables, 1 Figure. D. McGuire.
tags: voting, party activity analysis, manner determinants, methodological distinctions

title: Fenomenologie en sociologie. Schets van de geschiedenis
abstract: A historical study aimed at working out the essential contributions of phenomenology to sociology compares the initial intentions of E. Husserl, founder of phenomenology, with the actual course that phenomenologically-oriented sociology took in the work of A. Schutz, P. L. Berger, & T. Luckmann--the ethnomethodologists. The mutual interest of phenomenology & sociology in each other originated in the objectivistic interpretation that dominated 19th century sociology. One of the first attempts to overcome this objectivism was made by M. Weber, however the philosophical basis of his methodology was not altogether sufficient. This task could only be fulfilled by a philosophy as radical as Husserl's phenomenology, ie, that the role phenomenology should play for empirical sociology could be defined as epistemological. It had to answer the basic questions of how to know the social world & where to find the central concepts for its description & explanation. On the general basis of the principle of the intentionality of human consciousness & action, more specific answers to these questions were to be given in a "regional ontology of the social world" &, as Husserl formulated it later in his career, in the "eidetic analysis of the lifeworld" (Lebenswelt). In the work of Schutz, this latter notion of "lifeworld" played an important part. He used it, however, in a different context & with a different meaning: lifeworld was the specific outlook or reality-interpretation of a concrete group or individual, that could serve as the explanation for this group's or individual's action. By reducing lifeworld to subjects' knowledge, Schutz stood at the origin of that development in the contact of phenomenology & sociology which took form especially in Berger & Luckmann's "social construction of reality" on the one hand, & H. Garfinkel & A. Cicourel's "ethnomethodology" on the other. This development can best be described as a SofK. 2 critical points are made: (1) modern phenomenologically-oriented sociology seems to neglect the collective or superindividual dimensions in social life, & (2) its conception of phenomenological sociology as a SofK--although very fruitful--leaves unanswered the fundamental epistemological questions that were focused by Husserl, & thereby makes sociology once again susceptible to the old danger of objectivism. Modified AA.
tags: E. Husserl, initial intentions vs A. Schutz, P. L. Berger, T. Luckmann, social world knowledge, lifeworld concept, objectivism danger

title: Problemen bij de analyse van panelgegevens
abstract: In spite of the overwhelming amount of literature on the "regression artefact" many analysts of panel data still tend to ignore the consequences of unreliability for the measurement of change. This is illustrated by 2 recent Dutch studies. The regression artefact is explained by confronting the substantive interpretations of the results of these studies with an interpretation in terms of unreliability of measurement. In the first panel study among boys & girls from high schools, questions were asked about their plans for the future. Among other things the figures indicated that those who intended to go to a U had relatively more stable plans than others. Assuming a very slight degree of unreliability & using the fact that the majority planned to go to a U, these results could be explained without assuming that there was any real difference in turnover between the several categories. The other study attempts to determine, among other things, why students fail an exam for the 1st time & pass it a 2nd time. Indications are that among those who failed the 1st time, students with the worst results improved the most. Instead of the substantive explanations previously offered, an interpretation in terms of regression artefacts is made plausible. 6 Tables. AA.
tags: change measurement unreliability, Dutch studies examples

title: Traditioneel-interpretatieve en rationeel-reconstruerende geschiedschrijving van de sociologie
abstract: It is pointed out that the history of sociology is of greater importance to sociology than the history of the natural sciences is to physics, chemistry, etc. Two kinds of historical writings are distinguished: traditional-interpretive, & rational-reconstructive. Two questions are asked: (1) What use does a sociologist have for the history of his field? (2) What kind of history is more suitable? A history is considered traditional if it selects authors & ideas in accordance with commonly received opinions as to their importance. It is interpretative inasmuch as it clarifies ambiguity through use of the context, & the personality, the social background, or the philosophical presuppositions of the author. Interpretation is distinguished from explanation. When the selection of the material is done according to philosophical criteria only, the history is rational. It is reconstructive if it presents the material according to philosophical standards, rather than with a view to provide a "correct" interpretation. It is shown that rational reconstructive history can have a more important impact on sociology than traditional interpretive history, since sociology is not merely a tradition, but also a science. It is pointed out that one should expect a considerable distance between the history & its reconstruction, & that the gain in clarity should be considerable. A. Orianne.

title: Three psychological theories of a classical sociologist
abstract: It is shown that, despite E. Durkheim's theoretical pronouncements to the contrary, he makes explicit & abundant use of psychological theories. Three of his psychological theories are considered: (1) the vitality theory, (2) the duality theory, & (3) the deliberation theory. It is shown that all three are involved in the concept of mechanical solidarity & in his social explanation of suicide. It is also shown how they are part of his social explanation of religion. It is hoped that sociologists will follow Durkheim's example of applying psychological theories to the explanation of social phenomena. A. Orianne.
tags: vitality, duality, deliberation theories, mechanical solidarity concept, social explanation of suicide

title: Verkerkelijkingstendenzen in de Chileense pinksterbeweging
abstract: The Chilean Pentecostal sects are conversion sects, in the sense of B. R. Wilson's definition (see SA 7:4/6630). Past experience indicates that such sects tend to become churches in the course of time. This, however, is not obvious in the Chilean case, even though the movement is already fifty years old. There is still a charismatic leadership, voluntary recruiting, & considerable distance from the community. The two main explanatory factors are: (1) that the number of converts is still greater than that of people born in the church & (2) that the social mobility of the members of the church is limited. They explain the fact that even though church formation tendencies can be detected, the phenomenon is still very limited. A. Orianne.
tags: charismatic leadership, voluntary recruiting maintenance, members' social mobility

title: Pretenties van protocol-uitspraken
abstract: The notion of claim value is introduced, in order to analyze the meaning of protocol sentences. Four kinds of claim values are distinguished for scientific statements: (1) directive (analysis of a concept), (2) identifying (relates an object & a concept), (3) demonstrative (demonstrates the correct use of the concept), & (4) alethic (gives a description of reality). Protocol sentences are introduced in order to stop the infinite regress involved in justifying the truth of one sentence by appealing o another. A similar regress is at play in the definition of words by means of further words. An analysis of the claim value of protocol sentences shows that they do not give a description of reality, but have as their content the meaning of a term. The claim value of protocol sentences is either demonstrative or identifying. It is shown that within a language, expressions can function at different levels, so that a sentence can be a protocol sentence at one level & the same sentence express something about the world at another level. A. Orianne.
tags: directive, identifying, demonstrative, alethic statements, expressions, levels of functioning

title: Anomie en inflatie
abstract: An interdisciplinary approach to inflation is used which considers inflation as the economic manifestation of a wider social imbalance. Specifically, there is a significant relationship between rising inflation & increasing anomie in society. While neoclassical macroeconomics is mainly an equilibrium theory, the various theories of inflation currently proposed are derived from economists who criticized the equilibrium concept. Inflation, itself, is an imbalance phenomenon par excellence. The concept of anomy is derived from E. Durkheim who derived a typology of anomy in modern societies. He provided the theoretical foundation for a hypothesis that treats inflation & anomie as two aspects of the same process of social change. More precisely, it is hypothesized that there is a positive, significant relationship between the yearly rate of inflation & the yearly measures of several statistical data relative to the period 1955-1974 in the Netherlands, & the period 1960-1973 in the US. The anomie indicators are: violent crimes, crimes against property, suicide, homicide, & divorce. An extrapolation of the present trends leads to a forecast of economic disintegration. Inflation could be fought at the social level, through a concerted effort toward greater social integration. This could be best accomplished at the micro & meso levels. 8 Tables. A. Orianne.
tags: societal imbalance manifestation, Netherlands, US, statistical data comparison

title: Mens en maatschappij 50 jaar. Enkele opmerkingen over verschuivingen in de inhoud van het tijdschrift
abstract: Statistical data regarding the number & types of articles published in Mens en Maatschappij are presented. The number & overall types of articles are fairly constant over the whole period considered. Breakdown by subjects reflects the near disappearance of historical articles, articles in cultural anthropology, criminology, law, sociography, social geography, physical anthropology, & eugenics. New centers of interest are political sociology, general sociology, & methodology. Speculative-theoretical articles gave way after WWII, to more empirically oriented studies. 7 Tables. A. Orianne.
tags: subjects, changing emphases, theoretical vs empirical orientations

title: De sociologie van het lekkere gevoel
abstract: The recent influx of phenomenology in sociology is deplored. The works of A. Schutz & P. Winch are examined to show the objectionable consequences of the phenomenological perspective. The phenomenological critique of sociology is that the latter uncritically accepts its own relation to society. Phenomenology's alternative is to adopt "suspension of belief" as its starting point. The consequences of this position are: (1) the object of sociology is a social reality that is constituted on the basis of subjective meaning, (2) sociological concepts originate in the Lebenswelt, (3) sociology is itself a "finite province of meaning" within the Lebenswelt. By attempting to protect themselves against all interferences from natural sciences & various ideologies, Winch & Schutz have fallen prey to serious misconceptions regarding the natural sciences & to an unjustifiable optimism in phenomenology's power to defend one against ideology. Their philosophical stance leads to a conservative sociological viewpoint. Given the phenomenological conception of the relationship between science & common sense, phenomenology is unable to contribute to the growth of sociological knowledge. A. Orianne.
tags: A. Schutz, P. Winch, suspension of belief, Lebenswelt, philosophical stance, misconceptions

title: A Shortcut to Progress? Commentary on Wippler's View of Development in Theoretical Sociology
abstract: An article by R. Wippler is considered (see SA 25:4/77I7494). There are three points of agreement with Wippler: (1) the goal of empirical theoretical science is to formulate true & informative theories, (2) theoretical sociology must be brought closer to this aim, & (3) current preoccupations with 'perspectives', 'approaches', & 'orientations' must come to an end. However, Wippler's suggestions in this direction are far too modest. What is missing is a definite way to move from theoretical orientations to explanatory theories, & from orienting statements to testable propositions. This means that the relationship between theories & theoretical orientations is left unclear. As a consequence, explanatory theories seem a mere collection of disjointed propositions. This will not convince anyone that sociology should be advanced in that direction. A. Orianne.
tags: science goals, perspectives preoccupation critique, explanatory theories, testable propositions creation

title: Mens en maatschappij vijftig jaar. M & M in de bezettingsjaren
abstract: A number of articles issued in Mens en Maatschppij during the years 1940 to 1945 are surveyed & extensively quoted. They are grouped under five themes: (1) the reaction of a scientific journal to war time, (2) everyday business totally removed from external circumstances, (3) racism, (4) an early caricature of sociolinguistics in support of racism, & (5) the heredity hypothesis. No attempt at completeness is made & no statistics are presented. The choice of articles was guided by a particular conception of what was important during that period. A. Orianne.
tags: war time response, racism, sociolinguistics caricature, heredity hypothesis

title: Een empirische toetsing van gangbare hypotesen over stakingen en stakingsgeneigdheid van arbeiders
abstract: The testing is based on material relative to workers trade unions in Peru. The data pertain to the Cerro de Pasco Corp, an American mining outfit established in Peru in 1902 & nationalized in 1973. Fifteen trade unions were established there in 1945 even though some of them had already been active for a long period. These unions informally joined together in 1958 & formally federated in 1969. The data were provided by the archives of the company & by the Peruvian Dept of Labor. All instances of strikes & uprising between 1902 & 1973 are considered, as are all collective & individual grievances for the period 1956-1973. The first hypothesis tested (& verified) is the "cycle-interpretation" based on the works of Lenin--according to which conflicts evolve from short unplanned protests to large planned actions. This is explained by an increasing awareness & organization that is the subjective correlate of the objective process of proletariat-formation. The hypothesis--according to which the cause of the strike determines its result--is disproven; the determining factor is the interaction between state & company. A third hypothesis--that intersector factors determine the propensity to strike--is eliminated in favor of the intrasector hypothesis. Finally, the hypothesis that the various forms of industrial conflict are alternative to each other is rejected in favor of a hypothesis from R. Luxemburg, according to which strikes are the peaks of more general protest movements involving other protest activities. 6 Tables, 1 Figure. A. Orianne.
tags: Peruvian trade unions, collective, individual grievances, cycle interpretation, intrasector hypothesis

title: The Decadent Performance of the Jet-Set. The Leisure Class Revisited
abstract: A culturo-sociological analysis of the behavior & consumption patterns of the "jet-set" finds it is a group of colorful, but primarily decadent, individuals. Difference & similarities between the jet-set & T. Veblen's leisure class are noted (The Theory of the Leisure Class, New York: 1953). Structural & cultural changes that have taken place since the publication of that work are taken into account. The jet-set constitutes a power elite. The behavior patterns of the members of the jet-set are analyzed with reference to E. Goffman's theories in The Presentation of the Self in Everyday Life, Hammondsworth, 1972). The jet-set is the logical product of the status system in a decadent society that makes consumption a fetish. A. Orianne.
tags: behavior, consumption patterns, T. Veblen's leisure class, power elite, decadence

title: Objectkeuze in de wetenschapssociologie. De betekenis van het vakgebied
abstract: The question is to decide whether the sociology of science should primarily occupy itself with problems from the science of sociology itself or whether it should avoid such problems altogether. The three alternatives are: (1) give priority to sociology, (2) avoid sociology, & (3) give equal time to all sciences. The choice of subject is a matter of importance & alternative (3) should be rejected. Alternative (1) receives partial support as there may be cases when a choice of subject from within sociology may be necessary. Alternative (2) receives incomplete support as it is not to be followed in all cases. The choice of subject matter for the sociology of sciences is, itself, an important subject for a sociology of science. A. Orianne.

title: Besprekingsartikel. M. Rijkeboer en H. Verhallen (red.),  Valkuilen in de organisatieontwikkeling
Vooruitgang in kleine stappen. Een repliek op Lindenbergs commentaar
abstract: This is a reply to S. Lindenberg's critique ("A Shortcut to Progress? Commentary on Wippler's View of Development in Theoretical Sociology," Mens en Maatschappij, 1973, 3, 302-314, of R. Wippler's "Van theoretische orientaties naar verklarende theorieen" (Mens en Maatschappij, 1975, 50, 1, 4-23). Lindenberg's criticisms would be valid if his aim had been to resolve all or most of the important problems related to theoretical orientations & explanatory theories. However his goal was much narrower. It consisted in trying to show how theoretical orientations can be worked out so as to yield testable hypotheses. A number of more specific points of criticisms are dealt with & it is concluded that a valid strategy for progress in sociology has been provided, although it does not constitute 'the answer' to the question of knowing what the shortest way to progress is. A. Orianne.

title: Jubileumnummer 1925-1975
abstract: Deze selectie van artikelen uit de vroegste jaargangen van 'Mensch en Maatschappij' werd door de redactie samengesteld ter gelegenheid van het 50-jarig bestaan van het tijdschrift.Ter Inleiding door De Redactie van ‘M. en M .’ (Uit: jrg. 1, 1925), 1-2Nieuwste Duitsche Sociologie door S. R. Steinmetz (Uit: jrg. 1, 1925), 3-11Wat is sociographie? door S. R. Steinmetz (Uit: jrg. 1, 1925), 12-14Naar aanleiding van den Duitschen Sociologendag in Weenen door S. R. Steinmetz(Uit: jrg. 3, 1927), 15-21Van anthropogeografie tot sociografie door H. N . ter Veen (Uit: jrg. 3, 1927), 22-36De rechtsontwikkeling in Sovjet-Rusland gedurende de afgelopen tien jaren (Nov. 1917 - Nov. 1927) door J. Valkhoff (Uit: jrg. 4, 1928), 37-43Maatschappelik milieu, algemene intelligentie en de selectie voor het middelbaar onderwijs door T. Kuiper (Uit: jrg. 6, 1930), 44-50De oorlog als sociaal verschijnsel door J. J. von Schmid (Uit: jrg. 6, 1930), 51-58Mathematiese Psychologie door J. Tinbergen (Uit: jrg. 6, 1930), 59-69Socialisme en sociologie door A. Lysen (Uit: jrg. 6, 1930), 70-73Enkele opmerkingen naar aanleiding van het artikel van Dr. Lysen door S. R. Steinmetz (Uit: jrg. 6, 1930), 74-76De verspreiding der Joden over Nederland 1830- 1930 door E. Boekman (Uit: jrg. 10, 1934), 77-99De ‘Nederlandsche Sociologische Vereeniging’ door W. A. Bonger (Uit: jrg. 12 (1936), 100-111Advertentie Problemen der demokratie door W. A. Bonger, Noordhoff (ca. 1934-1936), 112

title: Causale analyse van paneldata
abstract: In survey research, panel analysis has the same function as the experiment in psychological research: the determination of causal relations. Here, the historical development in the techniques of panel analysis is sketched. The "cross-lagged panel-correlation technique" & the "sixteen-fold-table technique" are compared, & some extensions & corrections are given. Path analysis, one of the most recent developments in the causal analysis of (panel) data, is introduced. Path analysis has the advantage of giving extra possibilities in testing the causal model, eg, in the case of correlated error-terms. This leads to "conditional" estimations of the model parameters. The techniques are illustrated throughout, on the basis of the well-known panel data on vote-intention & attitude. 8 Tables, 3 Diagrams, 2 Figures. AA.
tags: causal analysis, path analytic models, parameters estimation, illustrations

title: Moderne wetenschapstheorie en symbolisch interactionisme: Enkele problemen
abstract: There is a continuing debate in sociology on theoretical pluralism, stimulated by a continuing contest of schools of thought, & nursed by a scientific research program, based on the necessity of a pluralism of theories for the progress of science. When the achievements of this research program in particular, & modern philosophy of science in general are applied to sociology, some problems occur. Most sociological 'theories' are only proposals for theory construction. One such proposal--symbolic interactionism--is discussed. When symbolic interactionism is examined in the contexts of modern philosophy of science & the research program, difficulties arise. (1) Is it possible to elaborate the symbolic interactionistic perspective & obtain an explanatory theory?
