(2) What can be done about the rejection of some symbolic interactionists of the covering law model of explanation? Is their rejection solidly grounded? These problems concern intertheory relations. Some reconstructed symbolic interactionistic explanatory theories are congruent with the symbolic interactionistic observational theory which leads to severe problems of testing & measurement. However, using the achievements of modern philosophy of science, satisfactory solutions for these problems can be found. AA.
tags: theoretical pluralism, explanatory vs observational theories, testing, measurement

title: A sociological critique of an organizational theory of power
abstract: Recent developments in Organization Theory have been concerned with developing "contingency" models of organization systems. They have been criticized by J. Child for neglecting power processes in organizations ("Organization: A Choice for Man," in Child, J. [Ed] Man and Organization, London: 1973). Recently, a "Strategic Contingency" theory of power in organizations has been presented (Hickson, D. J. et al, "A Strategic Contingencies Theory of Intraorganizational Power," Administration Science Quarterly, 1971, 16, 2, 216-229). It is argued that the reformulated concept of strategic contingency does not obviate the types of criticisms that might be made of such a theory from a sociological stance. The concept of contingency explanation in organization theory is rejected. A sociological perspective on organizations is proposed. Strategic contingency theory may then be seen as a theory of managerial influence in an unexplicated & taken-for-granted context of power. The critique of the Strategic Contingency theory is related to the sociological insufficiency of exchange and pluralist theories in general. Alternative directions for theorizing are suggested. Modified HA.

title: Over pretenties gesproken
abstract: A criticism of H. P. Gallagher's thesis ("Pretenties van protocol-uitspraken" [Pretentions of Protocol Sentences] Mens en maatschappij, 1975, 172-189) that the truth value of a statement could only be determined with the help of other statements. It is argued that in every empirical theory, the truth value of most propositions is determined by experimental investigation, observation, etc, ie, by human actions, & not with the help of other statements. A statement of which the truth value is determined only with the help of other statements cannot be but a logical consequence of those other statements; & it is well known that empirical sciences are not purely deductive. In empirical theories, one can discern alethic propositions (protocol sentences, hypotheses, etc), & ostensible definitions that are not alethic, & this methodological feature holds for sociology as well as for any other empirical discipline. Gallagher's distinction between protocol sentences of degree 1 & degree 2 is no distinction at all, since every protocol sentence of degree 1 is also of degree 2, & vice versa. Furthermore, a consequence of that distinction is that the conjunction of two nonalethic propositions would be an alethic proposition--a paradoxical result. According to that distinction, every empirical proposition would be either a protocol sentence or a conjunction of protocol sentences. This is obviously not true, eg, for statements involving theoretical terms. In Pretenties van protocol-uitspraken II. Antwoord aan A. H. de Wild, (Pretentions of Protocol Sentences II. Answer to A. H. de Wild) Hugh P. Gallagher (State U of Leyden, Netherlands) states several objections to Wild's criticism: (1) Empirical investigation, observation, etc are necessary conditions for determination of the truth value of a given statement, but they are not sufficient; verification requires the empirical information to be expressed into other statements--verification is a relation between sentences, not between sentences & experience. (2) To count protocol sentences as alethic propositions is unsatisfactory, because by definition any alethic proposition can turn out to be false, due to its empirical content; to function as a foundation of certainty, a protocol sentence must lose its alethic character & become immune to revision. (3) Gallagher does not distinguish between protocol statements of degrees 1 & 2, but makes a distinction between alethic propositions of degrees 1 & 2; an alethic proposition of degree 1 is any proposition that is the logical product of two or more protocol statements; an alethic proposition of degree 2 is any proposition that will be implied by two or more alethic propositions of degree 1; it is not clear why the idea that the conjunction of two nonalethic propositions is an alethic proposition would be a "paradoxical result." On the contrary, it gives the only satisfactory solution to the problem of 'ultimate verifiers'. (4) Statements involving theoretical terms have to be regarded as theoretical statements & not as empirical statements; theoretical statements do not interfere with the relationship between empirical statements & protocol statements. Modified AA.

title: Pretenties van protocol-uitspraken II. Antwoord aan A.H. de Wild
Anomie en inflatie: Een commentaar op een artikel van T. Huppes
abstract: It is argued that T. Huppes, in "Anomie en Inflation" ([Anomy and Inflation] see SA 26:4/78J4579) ignores recent developments in economic theory & only presents a caricature of the neoclassical theory. He confuses equilibrium & static situation. Inflation can be explained in a model of full competition, & imperfect competition need not lead to inflation. Huppes's social theory is an exchange theory. This is the social equivalent of the neoclassical theory in economics. It is surprising that he should adopt it after having so strongly criticized neoclassical economics. Even if there is a theoretical reason for believing that prices & norms are related, why should it be assumed that price increase is correlated with norms decrease? The anomy-inflation hypothesis is formulated differently in different places. This makes it more difficult to determine exactly how to test this hypothesis. It is even possible that anomy & inflation are linked by definition in such a way as to make testing irrelevant. Finally, it is noted that the correlations presented between anomy & inflation fail on two counts: (1) according to Huppes's statement of his hypothesis, increased anomy should be correlated with an increase in the rate of inflation, & (2) the same correlations could have been found for any such series. In You Can Bring a Horse to the Water, but You Cannot Make It Drink. Repliek aan K. Groenveld en B. S. Wilpstra (You Can Bring a Horse to the Water but You Cannot Make it Drink. Reply to K. Groenveld and B. S. Wilpstra), T. Huppes (Groningen U, Netherlands) states that a relation between anomy & inflation might be shown to exist, proceeding from an interdisciplinary conception of society. In this approach, several key concepts of economics & sociology are united. Prices & norms, for instance, figure as similar phenomena, both restricting alternative modes of behavior in the quest for satisfaction of wants. It is particularly the process of accelerated social change, so distinctive a feature of modern western society, that causes both prices & norms to lose their regulating function. Findings supporting the hypothesis that anomy & inflation are related phenomena are cited from Huppes's previous article. Modified AA.

title: You can bring a horse to the water, but you cannot make it drink. Repliek aan K. Groenveld en B.S. Wilpstra
Vertrouwenslieden, bedrijfsbesturen en bedrijvenwerk: Een historisch-comparatieve beschouwing over het bedrijfskader binnen de 'moderne' en syndicale vakbeweging
abstract: Recent developments in Dutch trade unions that could lead to restructuring of the unions on an industry basis are considered. Historical predecessors of this movement are described. The immediate causes of this recent movement are also considered. Similarities & differences between previous attempts & the present one are analyzed. The specific functions of "Industry work" are the promotion of internal communication & the democratization of union structures on the one hand, & the promotion of workers' interests on the other. The historical continuity of the present movement is emphasized. Two conditions are required for a continued fruitful evolution of the movement: (1) internal democratization of the unions, & (2) a reevaluation of its formal grievance procedures. A. Orianne.
tags: restructuration, industry work, democratization, present movement

title: Actor Analysis and Depersonalization
abstract: A new kind of analysis (action/analysis) is suggested & applied to the investigation of entities relevant to various studies of depersonalization. Five kinds of actors & recipients of actions (targets) are defined: individual, supra-individual, abstract/situational, anonymous, & residual. Changes in the perception of these entities are tapped through changes in the relative frequency of these actors & targets in front page newspaper reports. A content analysis of the New York Times in sample years from 1852 through 1969 shows that relative frequency changes in the following ways: (1) it declines for individual & residual actors & targets, (2) it sharply increases for supra-individual actors, but remains constant for supra-individual targets, (3) it remains constant for abstract/situational actors, but sharply increases for abstract/situational targets, & (4) it declines for anonymous actors, but increases for anonymous targets. An analysis of these changes shows that only the frequencies of supra-individual actors & abstract/situational targets reflect genuine cognitive changes, so that one can speak of a supra-individualization of actors & of abstraction & anonymization of targets. It is further found that over time, actors became independent of targets & vice versa. This indicates that particular actor-target links vanish. The joint structural effect of all these tendencies is a dichotomization of the actor-target structure into an active node (supra-individual actors) & two passive nodes (abstract/situational & anonymous targets). Two possible counterarguments to the interpretation of the data are discussed & refuted. 5 Figures, 4 Tables. Modified HA.
tags: individual, supra-individual, abstract-situational, anonymous, residual types, perception changes, relative frequencies

title: Het toepassen van statistiek voor enkelvoudige aselecte steekproeven terwijl de steekproef niet enkelvoudig aselect is
abstract: For financial reasons, the samples derived from the Dutch population are usually not simple aselect. However, the statistical methods used with those samples are those developed for simple aselect samples. The question is whether the use of these statistical methods results in a lesser reliability of the estimated population parameter. This difference in reliability is computed for a sample of 1,622 Dutchmen 16 years & older, from 1970. Following one of the usual methods of Dutch surveys, the sample has 2 levels, one composed of 7 sublevels (large municipalities) & the other composed of 67 clusters (from the smaller municipalities), weighted according to size. In the English language literature this is usually referred to as 'two-stage sample'. It results in estimated proportions being rarely underevaluated by the use of statistical methods designed for simple aselect samples. However, correlations of 'product moment' type were found to be slightly underevaluated. 5 Tables. HA Tr & Modified by A. Orianne.
tags: typical approach, reliability results, product-moment correlations underevaluating

title: Sociological analysis of organizational power: comment to Stewart Clegg
abstract: Suggestions by S. R. Clegg in "A Sociological Critique of an Organizational Theory of Power," (an abstract of which appears elsewhere in this journal) are applied to M. Crozier's analysis of a cigarette factory in The Bureaucratic Phenomenon (see SA 13:2/65B5078). Crozier noted that, despite the overrigid organization of the factory, rank & file maintenance men had managed to retain a large amount of "parallel" power. The application of Clegg's insights to the situation yields the following points: (1) power differences among workers must be understood as consequences of the overall power structure, (2) such power differences can only be small & the result of applying different rules to different participants, (3) applying L. Karpik's logic of action (see SA 21:4/73G3244) allows to determine that 'production' logic best describes the operation of the factory. Next, it is argued that it is the seniority system & their fixed salary that is the reason for the maintenance worker's power. Finally, an appeal is made to M. Weber to help understand the bureaucratic nature of the factory organization. A. Orianne.
tags: M. Crozier, S. Clegg, factory study, workers, L. Karpik's logic of action, M. Weber

title: Clusteranalyse
abstract: Cluster analysis is defined as the search for a classification. The objects to be classified may be Rs as well as objects, psychological properties, etc. The analysis may be applied to fields as varied as psychiatry, education, political science, or biology. A number of methods of cluster analysis are described. The notion of an algorithm is discussed with respect to stepwise multiple regression, which is characterized as a purely heuristic method. The dangers of any stepwise optimalization are stressed. Examples of cluster analysis are given. A method of evaluation of a given classification is provided. There is also a survey of literature as well as of existing computer programs for cluster analysis. A. Orianne.

title: Producing Citizens
abstract: In recent political theory the concept of democracy has replaced that of citizenship. The two concepts, however, are not coextensive. It is argued that focusing on the concept of citizenship might allow for comparison between political systems whether they are labeled democracies or not. A brief history of the idea of citizenship is presented, from the Greeks to the Marxists, through Hobbes, Rousseau, Locke, & Paine. It is shown that the mistake of the liberal tradition is to assume a voluntaristic conception of citizenship with the related assumption of a center of politcial power. A cybernetic model of a self-governing system is offered as an alternative to the liberal-democratic model. The assumption that agreement on basic values is a precondition for rational interaction among citizens is criticized as well as the rational choice theory & the technological rationality theory. Three conditions are given for rational action by citizens: (1) adequate understanding of the social reality, (2) respect for responsible discussion, & (3) enhancement of decision-making opportunities. A cybernetic critique of parliamentary democracy is presented & an extension of the sphere of citizens' activities is advocated. A. Orianne
tags: history, liberalism, model, self-governing alternative system, rational action

title: Gevraagd: een sociologie der techniek
abstract: As a rule, sociologists consider technology as merely one among many factors that develop according to their own rules & that partially determine the social situation. Sociologists study the consequences of technological changes, but do not, in general, consider technology as a social institution with its own sociocultural significance. The creation of a sociology of technology is advocated. This would fill the need for a fact-based insight into the ways in which, given primary goals & values, technology can best serve the community. This effort might serve as a foundation for the necessary cooperation between the technical & the social sciences in intermediate sociology & technology assessment. HA Tr & Modified by A. Orianne
tags: consider technology as a social institution

title: Psychologisme: dit keer als resultaat van naïef concretisme. Een antwoord aan A. Th. Derksen
abstract: A comment on A. Th. Derksen's "Sociologisme: een produkt van een misleidende zegswijze" (see SA 26:5/78J5860). Derksen tried to refute what he calls "sociologism," ie, "the conviction that every explanatory sociological proposition can't be at the same time psychological in nature, nor can be transferred into a psychological one without loss of meaning." He argues that this conviction could have arisen out of "misleading expressions." These are expressions which, due to their grammatical or syntactic form, lead to faulty convictions. Derksen's argument does not hold, because it is based on the assumption that only expressions that refer to concrete, visible objects deal with realities, whereas expressions that refer to abstractions do so analogous to the former, but are faulty & misleading. Explanations solely in terms of (concrete) persons do not suffice to cover the social world. One also needs sociological concepts, concepts that refer to phenomena that are as real as the will of persons. Sociological concepts, such as institution, group, & structure, stand for more than indications of collections of individuals. They can be used as indications of a reality, because the actions of individuals in a network of relations generate, through processes of objectivation of meaning, undesired results, which in turn control further actions. In Sociologisme: een produkt van een misleidende zegswijze II (Sociologism: The Product of a Misleading Expression II), A. Th. Derksen claims that van Poucke misrepresents Derksen in several respects. Van Poucke does not reduce sociology to psychology, nor can his critique of sociologism be reduced to a mere linguistic matter. Furthermore, van Poucke implicitly agrees that sociological explanations must sometimes have a psychological content. Van Poucke also claims that only concrete persons, not mere social positions, can determine another person's behavior. Norms do not exist apart from individuals that uphold them, & therefore, one cannot speak, in a literal sense, of norms determining the conduct of any individual. Modified AA.
tags: every sociological proposition also psychological, misleading expressions, van Poucke

title: Schaarse waarheid: argumenten in overvloed. Een analyse van het Club-van-Rome-pessimisme
abstract: Collapse of D. L. Meadows's standard-model (Rapport van de Club van Rome, Utrecht: Vitgererig Het Spectrum, 1972) resulted from pessimism about future technological possibilities & rigidity related to possible changes in social values. Comparison of critique & countercritique makes clear that truth is scarce & that in this situation, the results of model-building are in large measure determined by prescientific optimism/pessimism. Meadows softened rigidity by simulations in which "mankind" decided to stop population-growth, etc. Conflicts between groups, however, were ignored & attachment to pessimism remained. The purpose here is to uncover possible conflicts between groups by locating this pessimism in society & relating it to opinions about progress. Ss were from Dutch associations of employers & workers, & political parties -- English conservatives, social democrats, & communists. Data were taken from reports published by these groups. Comparison was made of arguments about eight items: (1) population (stable), (2) industry (no growth), (3) food (emphasis on production), (4) natural resources (bringing down use of product), (5) pollution, (6) technology (cannot substantially shift barriers, (7) private car/roadbuilding (bringing down sharply), & (8) atomic energy (no building of plants). Modified AA.

title: Humor en andere vormen van 'short-term' - compensatie
abstract: Is humor -- laughter, jokes, farce, clowning, satire, fables, & fairy tales -- capable of being reduced to a common denominator? Emphasis is laid on the function of short-term compensation of group stress & frustration, which humor often fulfills. Humor is laughing despite all the misery, seriousness, sanctity, & grandeur of the world. It is a part of culture: a transferable group possession whose author is often unknown. Unacceptable but immutable situations induce the urge to escape from reality: a joke lifts us out of our predicament & makes it bearable. The situation itself remains the same. A joke can have a short-term compensation function: in the short term, a situation of disrupted equilibrium is restored. Jokes in repression situations (wartime jokes), for example, can at once compensate inferior positions by putting both superior & inferior positions into perspective, thus making the situation bearable (by inducing a sense of superiority in the oppressed). The same applies to the Jewish, Catholic, or Negro joke, & to ecclesiastical hierarchy or religious rigidity. Religious commandments & proscriptions inspire jokes if their sense is in doubt or if they cause annoyance. AA.
tags: group stress, frustration, immutable situations, repression situations

title: Durkheim vs. Bentham. Anmerkungen zu zwei soziologischen Programmen
abstract: The relationship between empiricism & anti-individualism in the work of E. Durkheim makes him a successful critic of the utilitarian program. He is able to falsify certain implications of the utilitarian doctrine, as far as they relate to the problem of optimal satisfaction of needs by competition on the market & DofL. His theory of anomie is a progressive problem-shift & shows that maximization of utility in a competitive system can have undesired consequences for the web of social relations as a basis of morale. But his conclusions regarding an autonomous sociology do not lead to the wanted result, because he is not able to criticize central principles of utilitarianism on an anti-individualistic basis. Though his empirical criticism is a valid correction of the ideology of a liberal market system, it does not lead to a really theoretical alternative. AA.
tags: empiricism, anti-individualism, utilitarianism, theory of anomie, liberal market system

title: Pad-analyse of de Lisrel-procedure voor paneldata?
authors: Pijper, W. M. de,   Saris,W. E.
abstract: An article by J. Dessens & W. Jansen (see SA 26:5/78J5770) is criticized. Their method of extraction of pathcoefficients is considered time consuming, inefficient, too involved, & lacking in generality. It yields incomplete or incorrect results. This is illustrated by treating the problems raised by Dessens & Jansen, first via path analysis, & then through the Lisrel procedure. A more general model for the analysis of panel data is worked out, using the Lisrel notation. The Lisrel procedure allows the analysis of problems that are too complex for path analysis. The disadvantages of the Lisrel procedure are that its notation is more difficult & that it requires the extra assumption of a multivariate normal distribution. These are a small price to pay for the strength of the method. A. Orianne.
tags: J. Dessens, W. Jansen's "Causal Analysis of Panel Data" criticized

title: Over de relevantie van de individualistische traditie voor de integratie van economie en sociologie
abstract: W. Arts's article on integrating economics & sociology (abstracted elsewhere in this section) is considered. In view of the present world economic crisis, a new interdisciplinary approach to economics is needed, & Arts's article is a step in the right direction. Arts shows that in the past, the individualistic tradition has been fruitful, but the examples he gives are not particularly relevant to the present economic situation. Furthermore, the authors he considers are sociologists, not economists. An alternative view on how to operate the integration of economics & sociology is proposed, based on the remarkable congruence between neoclassical economy & exchange theory in sociology. It is shown how neoclassical economic theory merely extends to the macrolevel the utilitarian model of individual behavior. It is suggested that the present concern of economics with developing a theory of imbalance situations could be extended in an interdisciplinary fashion to cover phenomena of social imbalance as well. A. Orianne.
tags: individualistic tradition, congruence, classical economy, exchange theory, imbalance situations

title: Twee sociologieën: een onmogelijke keuze?
abstract: W. C. Ultee's analysis of the individualist & collectivist traditions in sociology (abstracted elsewhere in this section) is considered. Ultee is criticized for not defining what he considers individualism & collectivism to be. As a consequence, he lumps together authors whose views are extremely different from each other. The sociological alternatives cannot be reduced to individualism & collectivism; a third approach is suggested. In this approach, social phenomena must remain recognizable as typically human without thereby falling into psychologism. It must be possible to understand the social origin of human behavior without reifying society. A. Orianne.
tags: criticizes classification, psychologism, humanity of social phenomena

title: Enige kanttekeningen bij "Groepsgrootte als randvoorwaarde voor twee theorieën over afwijkend gedrag"
abstract: In his article on group size & deviant behavior (abstracted elsewhere in this section) H. de Vos focuses mainly on the behavior theory & the labeling theory as explanations of deviant behavior, & he tries to combine them. The behavior theory cannot by itself discriminate between deviant & nondeviant behavior, & de Vos presents a modified version of the behavior theory. His attempt at humanizing behaviorism meets with approval. However, as formulated, his new eclectic theory has lost some of the theoretical strength of behaviorism, & might prove unfalsifiable. A. Orianne.

title: Sociologisme: een produkt van een misleidende zegswijze II. Antwoord aan W. van Poucke
Sociologisme: een produkt van een misleidende zegswijze?
abstract: Sociologism is defined as the view, held by E. Durkheim & others, that sociological explanations can never have a psychological character. It is shown that Durkheim's own theory of suicide does not satisfy his definition of a sociological explanation, since it involves the psychological link that men's unhappy feelings cause them to commit suicide. Then, it is argued that phrases such as, 'The social environment determines ...' are systematically misleading in G. Ryle's sense ("Systematically Misleading Expressions," Proceedings of the Aristotelian Society, 32, 1931-1932). Their syntactic form implies the existence of an agent (the social environment) while they merely express a r between a type of situation & a type of action. Durkheim in particular reifies social situations as if they were phenomena having an independent existence. It is said that all explanatory sociological statements are equivalent to statements about human nature, because the characteristics of the objects of sociology (groups, institutions, structures) can be entirely reduced to characteristics of the individual members of these groups. A. Orianne.
tags: E. Durkheim's definition, suicide theory, social situation reification

title: The use of magnitude estimation in large scale survey research
abstract: A rarely mentioned problem in social science research concerns the discrepancy between the measurement level of variables & the mathematical properties & requirements of the techniques with which the data are analyzed & compiled. Some researchers have attempted to measure social science concepts on a ratio scale level through use of a method called magnitude estimation, which has been used mainly in small-scale research. Research is carried out to determine whether it can be applied in large-scale survey search. After a training period Rs were asked to estimate a magnitude with respect to a standard, on the basis of a number of stimuli. Two types of social science stimuli were used: (1) number of subordinates, from which the leadership capacity necessary to lead such a group was to be estimated, & (2) number of years working at a job, from which the workers' skill level had to be estimated. Eight stimuli were presented for each topic. The stimuli & the attitudinal magnitude judgments of the Rs were related by a power function. The fit was no worse than that found in small-scale studies. In cases of consensus between Rs, as well as in cases of lack of consensus, magnitude estimation is a useful technique to improve the measurement level of variables. 6 Figures, 12 Tables. Modified HA.

title: De mens achter de telefoon. Recente ervaringen met het interview per telefoon in de Verenigde Staten en mogelijke toepassingen in Nederland
abstract: A traditional view of the advantages & drawbacks of telephone surveys is presented, from which it follows that this kind of survey is rarely suitable for sociological research. Some reasons explaining use of this survey method in the US are presented: (1) the high % of nonresponse in traditional interviews, (2) the high cost of these interviews, (3) the fact that most people have a telephone, (4) telephone interviews can last any length of time, & (5) they are fitted to almost any kind of questions. Elaborated are the random digit dialing procedure, & the fact that the reliability of the results appears to be as high as those in traditional interviews. Some of the technical aspects of the procedure, as it is currently used in the US are described including the possibility of computer directed interviews. Applicability of the method in the Netherlands is discussed. The low % of Dutch households having access to a telephone (63%) is the only factor which makes the use of the technique impossible at this time. In an Appendix a cost comparison between telephone & face-to-face interviews is made. The random digit dialing procedure is inapplicable because the structure of telephone numbers is not homogeneous throughout the Netherlands. 4 Tables. A. Orianne.

title: Koloniale en neo-koloniale vormen van dualisme
abstract: The empirical & heuristic value of the concept of dualism is examined in relation to underdeveloped societies. A survey of the literature is made & a number of different interpretations of the concept are presented. The concept originated in the works of J. H. Boeke. The controversy between Boeke & J. van Gelderen on the cause of dualism (colonialism vs capitalism) is presented. Other critics of Boeke are also considered. A distinction must be made between dualism in the colonial & in the neocolonial period. Within the neocolonial framework, dualism may be analyzed primarily in social & cultural terms or in economic & technological terms. Dualism can only be understood on the basis of a historical analysis, starting with the colonial period. Hence, any explanation of dualism, merely in terms of internal or external power structure, is insufficient. A. Orianne.
tags: underdeveloped societies, J. H. Boeke's concept, his critics

title: Bedrijvenwerk en werkplaatsonderhandelingen. Valt er iets te leren van de Britse ervaringen?
abstract: Within a nationwide centralized industrial relations system, trends will occur toward forms of decentralized workplace bargaining. Recent trends within the Dutch trade unions to revive shop floor organization are discussed. There is a growing tension between this form of organization & the existing industry-based negotiating system. The latter is judged too rigid to effectively coordinate growing shop floor activity. A short overview is given of the British system of workplace industrial relations, particularly the dominant forms of bargaining on the shop floor. The principle of a relatively independent shop stewards organization is discussed as an introduction to an analysis of management's & workers' bargaining positions. Also discussed are Goodman & Whittingham's (Shop Stewards, London: Pan, 1973) nine factors that explain the considerable growth of workplace bargaining in Britain since the war. Each factor is discussed in its relevance for the Dutch situation. Although the negotiating systems in both countries differ widely, five or six of the factors are at work in Holland as well. Goodman & Whittingham's nine factors mainly work to stimulate the growth of an already existing workplace bargaining system, far less to bring about its birth. The tradition of postwar industrial relations in Holland is a strong force to resist the take-off of trends towards decentralized bargaining. These trends will occur because of the growth of trade union organization on the shop floor & its continuing frustration with the impotence of West-European type joint-consultation as its only means to confront management. AA.
tags: system overview, Goodman, Whittingham's Shop Stewards, Netherlands application

title: Discussie. Nogmaals: Academici, loonafhankelijkheid en klassepositie. In antwoord aan drs. B.A.G.M. Tromp
abstract: A reply is given to a review of "Politiek bewustzijn van academici in een loonafhankelijkheid situatie" (Political Consciousness of Academics in a Wage Dependent Situation). In that review, the social & scientific integrity of the writers & of Marxist scholars in general was discussed. Those criticisms are answered as are more substantial ones concerning the operationalization of the concepts of political consciousness & of proletarization, the position of the managers & the possibility of measuring changes through a single survey. The original study suffers from too schematic an emphasis on economics alone; factors such as social milieu, dominant ideology, & salary differences between blue- & white-collar workers should have been considered. A. Orianne.

title: Conservatieve gedachten over wetenschap en maatschappij
abstract: Progress based on scientific developments has been the dominant political ideology since the eighteenth century. It is central to both the liberal & the Marxist tradition. Today's welfare state is the final accomplishment of the eighteenth century's dream of the greatest happiness for the greatest number. People, however, are increasingly dissatisfied with their lives. This dissatisfaction can no longer be alleviated by "more of the same" remedies (more education, medicine, appliances, etc). A conservative viewpoint is advocated, but it is noted that it is nearly impossible to define what constitutes conservatism. Conservatism is not opposed to science, but rejects a formal & artificial social order. Scientific truth is not absolute truth, & true scientific attitude requires constant open discussion of social issues. A. Orianne
tags: liberalism, Marxism, welfare state, dissatisfaction, conservatism advocated

title: Achtergronden van militantie onder arbeiders en syndicaatsleiders: een methodologische case-study
abstract: A typology of labor activists is presented, in terms of the most important background variables suggested in the literature. A study was made of the workers at the Cerro de Pasco Corp, a Peruvian mining industry. Stepwise discriminant analysis was used. The characteristic traits of blue- & white-collar workers & of trade-union leaders are compared. White-collar workers are most dependent on the company & union leaders are the most militant. Differences in level of activism are explained in terms of the level of dependency on the company: one's chances of being militant increases as his level of dependency on the company decreases. The variables related to the technological DofL explain the level of militancy only to a small extent. The criterion "centrality of the camp location" is a better predictor. A. Orianne.
tags: Cerro de Pasco Corporation, mining, background variables, level of activism

title: Een pleidooi voor karteren
abstract: In the social sciences, there is discussion of theoretical stagnation. Some impute this to a pluralism in ways of explanation: they make a plea for theory-monism. Others say it is owing to the form of statements in the social sciences: there are mainly theoretical orientations & few theories. They make a plea for the transformation of these theoretical orientations into theories by means of formalization. Here, a case is made for an important intermediate step: the mapping of theoretical orientations. T. S. Kuhn's analysis (The Structure of Scientific Revolutins, The International Encyclopedia of Unified Science, Chicago: U of Chicago Press, 1962) is criticized. The inevitability & the fruitfulness of pluralism are pointed out, with arguments derived from the SofK & methodology: the influence of lay-images, the institutional context, the complementarity & contrariety of theories, & the indirect testing of theories. Five related function sof mapping are summarized through a systems analysis: uncovering & interrelating the different kinds of cognitive elements -- presuppositions, assertions, concepts, criteria, norms, methods of analysis, etc -- which play a part in theoretical orientations. These are: (1) to restrict communication disorders, (2) to determine the extent to whic h theoretical orientations meet methodological criteria such as internal consistency, empirical testability, scope, & precision, (3) to create possibilities to compare theoretical orientations, (4) to facilitate an efficient & valid formalization later on, & (5) to propagate orientations that have, on epistemological & methodological grounds, the highest potential for theoretical development. Attention is drawn to the problematic nature of transforming theoretical orientations into theories in the social sciences. Advanced arguments are the complexity of the object of study & the limited possibilities to experiment. Modified AA.
tags: theory-monism, formalization, T. S. Kuhn's The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, mapping functions summarized

title: Ik word ziek van de statistiek, of: er van weten zonder er naar te handelen
abstract: A discussion of some well-known methodological issues leading to incorrect use of statistical inference by many social scientists. Frequent misuse of statistical techniques is partly due to a concentration in textbooks on technical issues instead of methodological foundations; such misuse should not be a reason for deleting statistics from social science curricula. The foundations & applications are far more controversial than the purely mathematical theory of statistics & probability. Introduced is the paradigm of "the two spans of the bridge of inference" (Cornfield, J., & Tukey, J. W. Annals of Mathematical Statistics, 1956, 27, 912) showing how a statistical generalization to the operational population (from which a sample was drawn) is often followed by a generalization to a wider target population. This second step is mathematical, but should be based on the substantive insight of the investigator or the reader. The pitfalls of applying results valid for simple random sampling to all kinds of cluster samples, systematic samples, or haphazard samples so frequently used in practice, are warned against. Opposed is statistical decision theory, in which two decisions & their losses can be symmetrically viewed, & hypothesis testing, in which the null hypothesis survives unless clearly contradicted. The issues of one-sided vs two-sided tests & of situations where it is desired to prove the null hypothesis are discussed. The confusion of "large enough for statistical significant" with "large enough to be of practical importance" is deplored. It is demonstrated how the use of confidence bounds can be informative on both significance & importance, & Bayesian methods are discussed. Overambitious projects in which too many variables are measured, unreliably or invalidly, by a failure to concentrate on a few well-designed problems, are warned against, & some threats to validity commonly met in sociological research are discussed. Modified AA.
tags: J. Cornfield, J. W. Tukey's "two spans of the bridge of inference, " generalizations, random sampling, Bayesian methods

title: Enkele kanttekeningen bij het artikel van Knol
abstract: Comments are presented on an article by H. R. Knol on the use of statistics for simple random samples when, in fact, the sample is not of the simple random type (see Mens en maatschappij, 1976, 51, 2 [no title given]). The use of the terms "strata" & "stratify" & the purpose of stratification are discussed. Stratification is used as a means of attaining more homogeneity, at least within the strata, to arrive at closer confidence; but whether or not these closer confidence limits & greater homogeneity are arrived at depends on the relation between the invested phenomena & the criterion of stratification. Knol describes the stratification procedure but does not mention the criterion of stratification. In fact, he describes seven strata & an eighth stratum comprised of implicity stratified clusters. The implicit stratification had been done along province & degree of urbanization. But in the arithmetic he neglects the consequences of stratification in the eighth stratum. Due to this neglect, Knol arrives at "method-effects" which are overestimations of the real "method effects." The effects he computed are most strong for religion & level of education. These phenomena are (at least in the Netherlands) strongly related with degree of urbanization, the stratification criterion in the eighth stratum. If Knol had decided to account for the stratifications within his eighth stratum, the computed method effects would be smaller than those he found now. Knol overestimated the underestimating of variance because of the use of simple random statistics in nonsimple random samples. In Nawoord Bij de kanttekeningen van Cozijn (Reply to a Note by Cozijn) Hans R. Knol claims that Cozijn's criticisms are based on a misunderstanding. He took a note that was meant to apply to the 1974 sample to apply to the 1970 sample as well. Hence, his conclusion that the method-effect is overestimated does not apply. Cozijn's remark that stratification is used to obtain greater homogeneity within strata is discussed. In answer to Cozijn's doubts, it is claimed that stratified sample statistics are always justified in the case of a stratified design. The rule of thumb of multiplying by two the simple random variance estimate is discussed. The value of such a rule is doubted, & it is pointed out that Cozijn should not have applied it to a result coming from the whole sample, but rather to the stratified part of the sample only. A. Orianne.

title: Nawoord bij de kanttekeningen van Cozijn
De Schiedamse rel. Een exploratief onderzoek naar enkele organisatie-aspecten bij collectief geweld
abstract: In Aug 1976, in Schiedam, a Dutch town, a violent encounter took place between two Turkish & at least five Dutch youngsters. One of the Dutch boys was killed by one of the Turks, who then escaped & could not be traced by the police. For five days afterwards, groups of Dutch youngsters attacked Turkish property & some persons. The Schiedam riot was studied to collect some information about a neglected aspect of collective behavior: the organizational part of it. Two questions were posed: (1) How does a collectivity get its form? (2) Is there a division of tasks to achieve the objectives of a collectivity, & if so, what is the nature of these tasks? Data were collected in 96 interviews with people who were involved in the riot (mostly Dutch youngsters) who participated in the collective actions, but also policemen & members of the Turkish community. The most important aim was to formulate some hypotheses at the end of the study. A detailed description of the events of the riot is presented. Findings are confronted with a number of theoretical orientations in the field of collective behavior. Several hypotheses are formulated: (A) if a group thinks its norms are seriously violated by a member of another community & that there is little chance that the violator will be punished by the authorities, the aggrieved group will take action to punish him or have him punished; (B) if a collectivity has the intention of punishing a person held responsible for serious violation of norms, & it it is composed of persons who traditionally are physically violent, this collectivity will punish the violator with physical violence; (C) if an aggrieved collectivity undertakes action to punish a norm violator, the recruiting will be based on friendship & acquaintance preexistent to the riot; (D) if a collectivity is composed of subgroups preexistent to a riot, the leadership group will be recruited from members of these subgroups, & then the leaders will do most of the tasks themselves; (E) if the leadership group of a collectivity is mainly recruited from subgroups, the general leader (acceptable for all participants) is not a member of one of these groups; & (F) if the original objectives of a riot have been achieved, then the expressive objectives will grow more important than the instrumental ones, to make the riot last, & further, as the riot endures, the objectives & tasks will be more bound to the subgroups & also more directed against the controlling agencies. 1 Table. Modified AA

title: De grove of de fijne zeef; of: waarom zou je het gemakkelijk doen als het moeilijk kan
abstract: A book by J.M.A.M. Janssens (Begeleiding van ouders van geestelijk gehandicapte kinderen [Attitude of Parents of Mentally Retarded Children], Swets en Zeitlinger, 1977) is criticized. It is pointed out that the results that are obtained by means of an elaborate path analysis could have been reached much more simply. Such unnecessary complication is objected to on four rounds: (1) it renders a text unnecessarily long, (2) it builds a smoke screen around the utility of the results, (3) it capitalizes on accidents, & (4) it favors the replacement of thought by computer programs. A. Orianne.

title: De sociologie in roerig water
abstract: A general complaint is that in the last ten years there has been too much survey-oriented research & too little policy-oriented research at a macrolevel. Regarding public policy research, the failure of coordination at a national level between the Dutch Us is striking. Scarcely any feedback exists between the U & social scientists in public functions. The societal crisis, characterized by structural problems such as the disturbance of the ecological balance, population growth, permanent inflation, chronic unemployment, & the energy crisis, requires an integrated government policy directed at a long-term development of society. The changing role of the government, recently formulated by the Dutch Secretary of State Meier, asks for a sociology which at a macrolevel is policy oriented & pragmatic. To meet the demand of qualified social sicentists, the U sociology departments have started an interdisciplinary program of policy-relevant reserach of high equality, specializing in planning techniques such as gaming, simulation, consequence analysis, scenarios, public forecasting, & modeling. Greater coordination & interchange of programs is needed, as is an institutionalized consultation of social scientists & government officials. AA.
tags: failure of coordination, societal crises, Secretary of State Meier, interdisciplinary programs

title: Vervreemding onderzocht
abstract: In 1970, after a period of intensive study of the scientific literature on alienation & related concepts, & the empirical development of measuring instrument, nearly 2,000 Dutch people age 18 & over were interviewed, to get an insight into the backgrounds, components, & outcomes of alienation from society & from politics. Four years later, many questions were repeated in more than 1,000 interviews. Many of the earlier findings were reaffirmed. Alienation is the absence of a feeling of positive connection of a person with a social system to which he belongs, based on one or more experiences of imperfection in the role the person has or wants to fulfill in the social system. Goals, norms, & means are distinguished as the main elements of every role. The person may perceive each of tehse elements as absent, as unclear, or as unacceptable to him. Basically there are at least nine different possibilities of experienced imperfections in a role. The measuring instruments try to cover these sets of experiences in the person's role in society as well as in politics. Guttman-scales measured powerlessness, normlessness, & purposelessness, distinguished as to achievement- & success-powerlessness, indicating a lack of influence & a lack of result, respectively. For both years of investigation a number of hypotheses could be verified, which led to the following conclusions: (1) people with little education & those with misanthropic thoughts are more prone to feelings of achievement-powerlessness with respect to society than other people; (2) persons who think misanthropic also experience much purposelessness in society; (3) achievement-powerlessness proves to be related with success-powerlessness as well as with purposelessness, coinciding with normlessness, in the sense of unclear social norms; (4) both misanthropy & little education foster feelings of political achievement-powerlessness -- however, only via social achievement-powerlessness; (5) in both years, there was a relationship between little education & political purposelessness; & (6) political participation tends to be negatively connected with alienation. Protest behavior is less popular among people with negative social or political experience than among the self-confident, understanding, & idealistic persons. There were no signs that any alienation component leads to withdrawal from associations, clubs, & organizations, though the most active members tend to be those with a firm feeling of self-confidence. 5 Tables, 5 Diagrams, 2 Appendices. Modified AA.

title: Differentiation among people: Blau's revised view of sociology
abstract: Reversing his own former position, P. Blau calls for a reorientation of sociology towards the macrosociological analysis of social structure. To this end, he suggests a new framework for such an analysis. Upon closer inspection, the framework & the hypotheses it generated are very weak. Why is this so? Blau bases his framework on three typical elements of present-day sociological 'approaches': (1) a selective revival of classical traditions under neglect of what has been done in sociology since, (2) a conception of macrosociology that denies the relevance of individualistic propositions, & (3) a spurious claim that the small set of independent variables considered suffices to explain virtually every important social phenomenon. All three elements are bound to weaken Blau's framework to the point where he even becomes unable to relate a simple message: that it is important to study differentiation among people. AA.

title: Prestaties en problemen van Molukse leerlingen in het Mavo-onderwijs
abstract: Two specific questions are investigated: (1) How well do Muluccan children perform in the present school system compared to Dutch children? (2) Which factors are influencing the educational problems of Moluccan children? A brief survey of the relationship between the Netherlands & the Molucca Islands is given. The position of the Moluccan family in the Netherlands is considered with respect to rights, habitation, & job market. The position of the young Moluccan generation is treated separately. The increasing aggressiveness of Moluccan youth is noted & is attributed to frustrations, adaptation problems, unemployment, & a traditional tolerance for aggression in young Ms. A survey was conducted among 59 Moluccan schoolchildren (23 Ms) & 35 Dutch children (16 Ms). All belonged to Lc families. Their school results were compared. Muluccan girls were found to perform almost as well as Dutch boys especially in languages. Moluccan boys receive the lowest overall scores & the Dutch girls receive the highest. Both Moluccan girls & boys tend to be older than the average for their grade. More individualized teaching & more emphasis on active participation are recommended. 1 Table. A. Orianne.

title: Sociologische theorievorming door middel van historisch onderzoek: een voorbeeld
abstract: An attempt is made to show the usefulness of historical investigation for sociological theories. The hypothesis, that people in a conflict between their material interests & their ideology act in conformity with their material interests & in contradiction with their ideology, does not hold in this investigation. The textile workers in Lancashire behaved in conformity with their ideology ("against slavery, in favor of democracy") by choosing the side of the North in the American Civil War. They acted by this in contradiction with their material interests, because they were, for their incomes, dependent on Southern cotton. Data have been collected from historical studies concerning Lancashire in the years 1860-1865 & concerning the American Civil War. A distinction must be made between long- & short-term material interests. Based on this distinction, two new hypotheses are formulated. AA.
tags: example, material interests vs ideology, Lancashire/slavery issue

title: Het versomberde toekomstbeeld in Nederland (1958-1975). Toepassing van Log-Lineaire analyse en van hiërarchische modellenbouw op gegevens uit twee steekproeven
abstract: A method of statistical analysis of trends is presented. It consists in taking, as the basis of evaluation, the logarithm of ratio of odds. When the same question is presented to the same population at two different times, one gets a changing ratio of odds. One must then construct a model in which the interaction of all the factors that effect this change are identified. This method is illustrated by an example: the analysis of the changing perception of the future in the Netherlands. The answers to a number of questions from a survey done in 1958 are compared with the answers to the same questions asked in 1975. The results indicate an increase in pessimism over the seventeen-year period. This result is all the more striking in that questions directed at the Rs' perceptions of their own future yielded answers as optimistic or even more optimistic in 1975 than in 1958. Pessimism is not a characteristic of the younger generation alone. Increased pessimism is paralleled by an increase in levels of formal education & a decrease of the church-affiliated population (particularly among Roman Catholics). 3 Figures, 11 Tables. A. Orianne.

title: Theoretische sociologie en maatschappelijke vraagstukken. Individueel handelen en participatie in de voorziening van collectieve goederen
abstract: Nowadays it is widely recognized that the state of theoretical sociology is characterized by the fact that although there are some explanatory theories on determinants of human behavior, there are almost no attempts to apply these theories to urgent social problems. Social problems, eg, environmental pollution, unemployment, income distribution, overpopulation, have a common basic structure. One of the central elements of this basic structure is the discrepancy between individual behavior & individual decision processes on the one hand, & the social outcomes of these processes on the other ("externalities"). This basic structure is analyzed by using M. Olson's The Logic of Collective Action (New York, 1965). Moreover, some modifications to this theory are proposed (network theory, cognitive dissonance theory). Described are an application of the theory of collective action & the proposed modifications to the problems of environmental pollution & overpopulation. From this application, some policy recommendations are derived. 4 Figures, 2 Tables. AA.

title: Enkele sociaal-psychologische factoren die een voorspoedige ontwikkeling van het bedrijvenwerk in de weg kunnen staan
abstract: The Dutch labor union's attempts at building workplace organizations for its members are longstanding. Social psychological processes may hamper progress in this area. If member's acceptance of union arguments in favor of workplace organization is low, the members in a particular company will not participate in its development. If members are about equally divided pro or contra these arguments, the groups will polarize after discussion. If member acceptance is low & local union representatives are in line with the members, these officials will not stimulate workplace organization & will not mediate the union arguments to the rank & file. Twenty-two union representatives & 79 randomly selected labor-union members in two electro-technical plants were interviewed with a structured questionnaire. Workplace organization in both plants had stagnated. Acceptance of the official union arguments was measured by Likert-type attitude scales concerning company democracy & employer-employee relations, & by questions about the union's general strategy toward companies. Among members & union representatives in both plants alike, acceptance of the union's arguments appeared to be low with respect to company democracy. Acceptance was moderate (about even) on employer-employee relations & general union strategy. In one plant, union representatives' opinions agreed completely with the rank & file. Representatives in the other plant were in agreement with members on all issues except one. These results were tentatively interpreted as contributing to the stagnation of workplace organization in these plants. The relationships between the three attitude measurements indicated that acceptance of the official union arguments concerning employer-employee relations & acceptance of the union's general strategy were strongly associated. Acceptance of arguments concerning company democracy was not correlated with acceptance of the union's general strategy & was only moderately associated with acceptance of arguments concerning employer-employee relations. 2 Tables. AA.

title: Mythes en misverstanden rondom ontwikkeling
abstract: Development is a concept that is used in a variety of ways. It is a normative concept; there is a danger that the attempts to reach development goals are seen as a realization of the goals. Five development goals are distinguished: (1) economic growth, (2) the growth of scientific knowledge; (3) a more equitable distribution of income & wealth, (4) a more equitable distribution of knowledge, & (5) a more equitable distribution of power. It is argued that these goals cannot be realized all at the same time, because they imply structural contradictions. The development process, therefore, will be dialectical. AA.
tags: five goals concerning economics/science/wealth/knowledge/power, dialectical process

title: Wetenschapstheoretische vernieuwingen in het agogisch denken, geïllustreerd aan het paradigma der orthopedagogiek
abstract: The concept of paradigma of T. S. Kuhn is the starting point for examining what epistemological renewals are elaborated in the field of social pedagogics in general & in orthopedagogics in particular. A new paradigm is developing, starting from practical problems, in each of the three dimensions characterizing scientific revolutions in the work of Kuhn. There is a new definition of the field of empirical inquiry, resulting in a view of the category of deviance & in an analysis of the social conditions under which deviants are labeled. In the dimension of practical action, the model of correction is replaced by a model of development, leading toward an emancipatory engagement. In the dimension of value orientation, a new model of man & society arises, characterized by the value of the autoregulative individual in relation to society as a learning process. AA.

title: Kanttekeningen bij recent Amerikaans onderzoek naar stratificatie in school en beroep
abstract: A review of recent US research into educational & occupational stratification is presented. Special emphasis is put on longitudinal designs. (Wisc Study of High School Seniors; Explorations in Equality of Opportunity; National Longitudinal Study of High School Class of 1972; National Longitudinal Surveys; Panel-Study of Income Dynamics; Retrospective Life History Study). Findings from these data sources are difficult to compare, due to many differences in design & analysis. Thus, one should also be careful in applying such findings to non-US situations, as is often done. Some conclusions are drawn & a research strategy is presented with respect to stratification research in the Netherlands. AA.
tags: US research, educational/occupational stratification, Dutch examination

title: Bureaucratie in het ziekenhuis. De theorie van Hall empirisch getoetst binnen één type organisatie
abstract: In a study of 6 general hospitals in the Netherlands, R. Hall's dimensional model of bureaucracy was tested for its applicability within one type of organization. A pilot study with a group of 99 staff nurses generated a reliable version of the original questionnaire, translated & adapted to hospital organization. Individual analysis showed that the dimensional model was only partly represented by the facts & the 6 dimensions were not found to be independent. In the main study, only 5 dimensions, corresponding to 32 items, were kept. Nurses (number of cases = 442) representing 31 departments in 6 hospitals were interviewed. Of the respondents, 50 to 60% were students. Data were analyzed at the group level. Results show that the dimensions of hierarchy of authority, interpersonality, & rules/procedures are reliably measurable. Again, independence was not found. It is suggested that within this type of organization, bureaucracy might better be handled as a unit concept. The scale is judged valid to an acceptable degree. Before firm conclusions about the applicability of the dimensional model can be drawn, further research within other homogeneous groups of organizations will be needed. 7 Tables. Modified HA.

title: De rol van dooppeet. Of over de integratie van een niet-familiale rol in de structuur van het verwantschapssysteem
abstract: The original significance of the role of godparent as a guarantor of his godchild's loyalty to the Roman-Catholic Church & as an educator of his godchild has waned in modern society. How then can its persistence be accounted for? Despite the fact that the catechumenate, to which originally godparenthood related most closely, entered a period of progressive decay after the persecutions of Christians by Roman authorities, godparenthood continued an independent existence without instrumental significance, because it had gradually gained a sufficiently important place in the system of expressive symbols of the Christian community to compensate for & survive the loss of its manifest functionality. The integrative function of the institution of godparenthood has been transferred from the ecclesiastical to the familial social system: godparenthood mainly functions as a channel of expressive-symbolic interaction among the members of a family of orientation after some of them, namely the children, have formed their own family of procreation. This development is directly related to the normative regulation of the allocation of the godparent role. Finally, the problem is put in a wider theoretical perspective, namely in the context of E. Durkheim's 'law of contraction.' AA.
tags: Roman Catholic Church origins, kinship system/nonfamilial role of E. Durkheim's law of contraction

title: Theorie van het collectieve handelen (II). Kritische kanttekeningen bij de theorie van Olson
abstract: Comparison of M. Olson's & J. M. Buchanan's theories of collective action (M. Olson, The Logic of Collective Action, Public Goods and the Theory of Groups, Cambridge, Mass, 1965; & Buchanan, J. M., The Demand and Supply of Public Goods, Chicago, 1968). Both authors fail to distinguish clearly between market & group relations. The implications for Olson's theory are explored. Three points of criticism are: (1) Olson's theory seems contradictory as a consequence of the author's formal definition of the 'fraction' of benefits accruing to group members; (2) certain assumptions limit the generality of his theory; (3) Olson's conception of 'rationality' is not consistent. Olson's theory being a theory of the free rider more than a theory of collective action, is of more limited validity than the author assumes. Fruitful application of the theory is to be expected where groups or organizations develop market analogous behavior in producing collective goods. This part of the theory is of major importance for sociologists. Small-group behavior, particularly where the collective good consists of collective property rights, is not explained satisfactorily by Olson's theory. 3 Tables. AA.
tags: M. Olson's The Logic of Collective Action, Public Goods and the Theory of Groups, J. Buchanan's The Demand and Supply of Public Goods

title: Theorie van het collectieve handelen (I). De theorie van Olson
abstract: Discussed is M. Olson's theory of collective action (The Logic of Collective Action, Public Goods and the Theory of Groups, Harvard U Press, 1965 & 1971). Collective goods are defined as those that cannot be divided among individual consumers & for which there is no price/use relationship (eg, dikes, roads). There is no competition for their consumption & they can be used by individuals regardless of their contribution. It is argued that it is possible to exclude categories of persons from some public goods (eg, water service) & that there may be competition for others (eg, public health). From the production viewpoint Olson adopted a methodological individualism consisting of treating groups as single agents. This obscures the decision-making process. J. M. Buchanan's model (The Demand and Supply of Public Goods, Chicago, 1968) of supply & demand for collective goods is described & discussed. Olson claims that individuals must be coerced to act in their collective interest. Voluntary cooperation is possible in small but not in large groups. Small groups are more efficient but lead to the exploitation of weaker members & tend to provide a suboptimal amount of collective goods. Olson's typology of groups is described. 2 Figures. Modified AA.
tags: analysis, J. Buchanan's The Demand and Supply of Public Goods

title: Ongelijkheid bij orthodontische hulp; een analyse met log-lineaire modellen
abstract: Causal relationships between orthodontal care & parental income, education, & insurance type were investigated by log-linear models in 534 families. The essentials of the log-linear model are explained. Results indicate that the main explanatory variables in predicting orthodontal care are income & insurance type. Some alternative analysis techniques are considered. 8 Tables. HA.
tags: orthodontal care, income/education/insurance, log-linear model investigation

title: Sociale wenselijkheid als validiteitsprobleem
abstract: Rs' tendency to give socially desirable answers influences research data validity. This tendency can be tentatively quantified with social desirability items. The validity of these items is investigated. Analyzed are answers given by 14- to 15-year-olds (N =590) & their mothers (N =530) to questions regarding the children's dental health behavior. The aim was to find a connection between inconsistent answer patterns & social desirability items responses. Five questions were investigated to find whether those who gave more desirable answers also scored higher on a three-item desirability scale. The expected connection was found for 4 children & 1 mother. The total score of inconsistent answers to 5 dental health behavior questions was calculated & compared to the social desirability scale. Children who scored high on the desirability scale also gave more socially desirable answers to questions concerning their health behavior. No such correlation was found among mothers. 9 Tables. Modified HA.

title: Schoolkenmerken en leerlinggedrag. Enkele methodologische merkwaardigheden in het onderzoeksbedrijf
abstract: A research anomaly is pointed out: while it is habitually recognized that multivariate analysis requires the random selection of a large number of individuals, most studies that deal with the influence of a particular group or context on individuals are satisfied to deal with a nonrandom sample of ten or twenty groups, schools, or neighborhoods. Yet, there seems to be no reason why group studies require a different sampling procedure from individual studies. Problems connected with the use of a small number of contexts are examined. It is argued that these problems cannot be solved by taking group members rather than groups as units of investigation, since deviations are multiplied by the same coefficient as the number of Ss. The problem of selecting the contexts to be studied are examined. It is noted that contexts are usually not randomly selected, & that the results obtained are, therefore, not generalizable. Further aggravating circumstances are considered. Measures of context or group characteristics are not as well developed as those of individual ones. Context effect studies need to use random samples of at least 100 contexts. A. Orianne.
tags: group/context studies, multivariate analysis, nonrandom samples

title: Molukkers in Nederland: beleid en onderzoek
abstract: In 1978, the Dutch government presented a paper called "De problematiek van de Molukse minderheid in Nederland" (The Problems of the Moluccan Minority in the Netherlands). In this booklet, an overview was given of the governmental policy for the near future toward the Moluccan minority. Also, the Dutch position concerning the Moluccan wish for an independent Republic of the South Moluccas (the Republik Maluku Selatan) was stated, & an explanation was given for the adherence of many young Moluccans to that ideal. These three points are criticized here on the grounds of research done on the Moluccan community. The standpoint of the Dutch government concerning an independent Republic of the South Moluccas is that on juridical, historical, & factual grounds, no support will & may be given to this aim. Some comments are presented on the juridical & historical aspects, but the focus is on the view of the government of the factual situation. The continuing aspirations of many Moluccans to realize a South Moluccan Republic is explained by the Dutch government by means of the "disappointment-hypothesis." This explanation is as follows: many Moluccan youngsters could not meet the demands of the modern Dutch society; so, in their disappointment they turned away from it & looked for a compensation that was quickly offered to them by the dream of a Moluccan Republic. The Dutch government infers from this hypothesis that adherence to the Moluccan Republic is only at the individual level. It tries, therefore, to eliminate those things that stand in the way of an assimilation of the Moluccan into the Dutch society, supposing that the Moluccans will forget their political aspirations & become real citizens of the Dutch society "without giving up their Moluccan identity." The policymakers fail to consider that the movement to establish a free Moluccan state could also be regarded as an effort for collective emancipation. This viewpoint is especially emphasized by many Moluccan organizations. The Dutch government considers the isolationist tendencies that can be observed in the Moluccan community as a hindrance for the individual Moluccan to find his way into the Dutch society. The government fails to see this isolation as a necessary phase of an emancipation process. If research will be done in the future into the Moluccan minority, it has to start from the symbolic-interactionist point of view & pay due attention to the different definitions of the situation. Modified AA.

title: Discussie. Voor de laatste keer: Academici, loonafhankelijkheid en klassepositie
Markets and Organizations: Towards an Individualistic Theory of Collective Action
abstract: From recent theoretical contributions in the economics of public choice & property rights an outline is presented of some analytical fundamentals of an individualistic theory of corporate actors (organizations). It is shown that such a theory can more fruitfully use the "combining resources model," proposed in recent publications by J. S. Coleman, instead of the exchange model that traditionally has been central to an individualistic social theory. The exchange model -- while being appropriate for the analysis of market structures -- is less fruitful when applied to organizational structures or corporate bodies. The differences between markets & organizations as two types of social networks are specified, & the combining resources model is outlined & applied to an analysis of the two basic features characterizing corporate bodies: (1) the problem of "social distribution" (of distributing the "corporate product"), & (2) the problem of "collective decision." Some final remarks are made on an interpretation of the state as a corporate actor. AA.
tags: J. Coleman's combining resources model vs exchange model, social distribution, collective decision

title: Bedreiging en punitiviteit
authors: Anjou,L. J. M. d',   Cozijn,C.,   Toorn,L. v. d.,   Verkoeyen,C. M. R.
abstract: The clamor for severe punishment of illicit behavior is a phenomenon that has almost eluded systematic investigation. Since the desire to inflict punishment can be conceived as a form of violence, explanation is sought through the aggression in self-defense theory of R. Wentholt (Het agressierraagstuk [Paper on Aggression], Rotterdam: Erasmus U, 1972) that threat induces direct or indirect violence -- including the infliction of punishment -- or flight. A survey of the literature indicates that it must be assumed that threat & violence are interrelated. This explanation is supported by data resulting from the secondary analysis of a research project sponsored by the Dutch Dept of Justice of feelings of unrest caused by criminality. An experiment was conducted using 25 self-employed persons (considered threatened) & 25 tenured nonacademic U employees (considered unthreatened) & measures of punitiveness, direct aggression, & flight were compared. Results indicate that feeling threatened is likely to be related to the desire for severe punishment. 6 Tables. Modified HA.

title: Mathematische sociologie
abstract: An attempt is made to clarify the conceptual confusion surrounding the dispute over qualitative vs quantitative sociology. It is noted that quantitative & mathematical sociology go hand in hand, & that the latter is far older than academic sociology & can already be found in England in the sixteenth & seventeenth centuries, when it was largely confined to demographic studies. Modern statistical studies originate with the British biologist F. Galton in 1888. With respect to the application of mathematics, sociology today can be divided into two parts: the elaboration of linguistic systems & the construction of models. The first area uses mathematical logic, set theory, game theory, graph theory, information theory, & mathematical linguistics; the second uses techniques designed to evaluate how closely a set of data matches a model. Models can be predictive or interpretive, deterministic or stochastic, static or dynamic. They have a specific field of application, & make use of specific algorithms & analysis methods. The techniques used are derived from statistics, error analysis, sensitivity analysis, linear algebra, & calculus. Sociological fields in which mathematics is of most use are: demography, social geography, social psychology, & econometrics. A. Orianne.
tags: 16th/17th-century origins, F. Galton, linguistic systems, model construction

title: Kritische bijdrage. Europa als cultureel-antropologisch studieveld. Contradictio in terminis of pure noodzaak?
Werklozen en werklozenbeweging
abstract: Unemployment research has failed to investigate the affected persons' perceptions of the causes of unemployment & participation in related in social movements. Forty-one construction workers (who had been unemployed for a period of 2-30 months) were quetioned about their well-being, financial deprivation, experiences with social service agencies, perceived reactions of family & neighbors, expectancies about trade union actions & appeal of the unemployeds' movement. Those susceptible to the movement's appeal (as measured by a susceptibility index) were compared to those who were not. The former show greater well-being than the latter. This is interpreted as indicating that participation in the movement is a matter of ^being unbroken' rather than pauperization. Financial deprivation & the perceived reactions of one's family accounted for most of the well-being variance. Expectancies about collective action by trade-unions accounted for most of the variance in susceptibility to the unemployed movement's appeal. Financial deprivation did not correlate with susceptibility. Relative deprivation is not a sufficient condition for movement participation. 6 Tables, 2 Figures. Modified HA.

title: Leiblichkeit und Sozialität: Ein Grundproblem der phänomenologischen Soziologie
abstract: The role of the body in social interactions has not been sufficiently investigated. The most important aspects of this role are determined & some theoretical consequences are formulated. The thoughts of A. Schutz, M. Merleau-Ponty, & G. H. Mead are followed. The general framework of these considerations is the opposition between individual & collectivity which keeps emerging in sociological theory. The phenomenological criticism of these & other concepts occurs through a structural analysis of everyday experience where sociality is given without prior concept formation. In his description of the everyday social world, Schutz reduces social life to a mutual exchange of individual meanings; hence social cohesion becomes an unsolvable problem. It is argued that Schutz's problem stems from his negative conception of the body & its role in interactions. In Merleau-Ponty's analyses of immediate experience the fundamental signification of the body in subjective & intersubjective life is recognized. The basis of intersubjectivity is not an active meaning imposition in which the individual experiences himself as cause but is found in the bond with the environment which the body creates. Using insights from Mead, this perspective can be expanded to a view of sociality as an interbody functional circle or a functional coordination of body movements. The most important consequence of this conception is that the theoretical opposition between individuals & society is shown as an abstraction from the medium in which body interaction takes place. HA translated & Modified by A. Orianne.
tags: A. Schutz's/M. Merleau-Ponty's/G. Mead's ideas, individual vs collectivity, theoretical consequences

title: De beul als paria: Een historisch-sociologische aantekening
abstract: An attempt is made to determine the hangman's identity. Emphasized is his attribute of pariah from social life. The hangman is comparable to the 'impure' caste in Hinduist India described by M. Weber. Weber compared the impure caste to Medieval 'dishonorable' professions, typically the hangman, but did not further analyze the executioners' position in contemporary society. This undeveloped idea of Weber is elaborated here. HA translated & Modified by A. Orianne.

title: Van den Doels gewijzigde doelstellingen. Over verschillen in de eerste en tweede druk van J. van den Doel: ^Democratie en welvaartstheorie'
